urn:contentItem:5YC4-VDX1-JBYT-H061-00000-00Biden stages a Super Tuesday comeback as Sanders fights for the rest in the West2020-03-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBiden stages a Super Tuesday comeback as Sanders fights for the rest in the WestNew Delhi, 2020-03-05 22:25:05

March 05 -- In a newly narrowed four-way contest, Super Tuesday's broad delegate pool enticed Democratic primary contenders with race's biggest prizes yet. Fourteen states voted in Tuesday's primaries, with the key states of Texas and California alone accounting for a combined 643 delegates.


Former Vice President Joe Biden notched important wins early in the evening, taking Virginia and North Carolina, the third most delegate-rich state in Tuesday's contest. Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders won his home state early in the night, but failed to carve out a foothold in the East Coast and Midwest.
"Just a few days ago the press and the pundits had declared this campaign dead," Biden announced in a triumphant speech mid-way through the evening. "I am here to report, we are very much alive."
As of 8:45 p.m. Pacific Time, Biden had collected Alabama, Arkansas, Minnesota, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Massachusetts and Virginia with Sanders taking Colorado, Utah and Vermont. At the time of writing, a winner has yet to be declared in Maine, Texas and California, with the latter state leaning toward Sanders.
 
 
 
Biden stormed into Super Tuesday with new momentum, fresh off a vital win in South Carolina over the weekend and some swiftly collected endorsements friom his former rivals, including Amy Klobuchar, Pete Buttigieg and Beto O'Rourke. That momentum created a spate of decisive victories for Biden, as the moderate vote appeared to flow easily to him, overwhelming Sanders in some states the Vermont senator was favored in, including Oklahoma, Minnesota and his neighboring state of Massachusetts.
Lacking endorsements from former candidates but not momentum, Bernie Sanders entered Super Tuesday with 60 delegates to Biden's 54 and Elizabeth Warren's eight. His results in early voting states, consistent debate performances and grassroots support marked Sanders as the candidate to beat, but those strengths failed to translate into boosted turnout for Sanders in some key states.
In spite of early narratives, delegate totals before Super Tuesday represented just a sliver of the 1,991 delegates necessary to secure the nomination at the Democratic National Convention this July. A total of 1357 delegates are up for grabs on Super Tuesday.
 
 
Super Tuesday marked the first time Bloomberg appeared on a ballot, but his massive cash spend still resulted in an underwhelming night, with the former mayor only picking up a small handful of delegates in American Samoa. Former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg entered the formal race with more than $400 million spent on ads but zero delegates. Warren also underperformed Tuesday, with a more competitive race than anticipated even in her home state of Massachusetts, which ultimately went to Biden. Oklahoma also showed no loyalty for Warren, who was born in the state-after choosing Sanders in 2016, Oklahoma opted for Biden in Tuesday's contest.
Tuesday's results will reshape the race for the Democratic nomination, much as Biden's long-promised win in South Carolina breathed new life into a flagging campaign. Beyond likely narrowing into a two-person race, the new dynamics emerging out of Tuesday will shift the framing of the contest as a whole. That change is likely to pit political Biden's promise of incremental political change more directly against Sanders and democratic socialism.
The 2020 race has challenged the tech industry in more ways than one. With both Trump and Bloomberg stress-testing social platforms with a deluge of ads, tech companies are still trying to figure out where to draw their respective lines on political advertising. Those efforts are on top of the imperative for major platforms to avoid a repeat of 2016 by fending off coordinated disinformation campaigns seeking to roil Americans politics.
Beyond platform manipulation concerns, candidates like Warren and Sanders successfully tapped into mainstream backlash against big tech over the course of their campaigns, cultivating even more criticism for companies already under scrutiny from other parts of the government. Depending on which wing of the party seals the nomination, tech could be facing a very different regulatory environment in the event of a Democratic win come November.

urn:contentItem:5W9T-SWC1-DY4X-T00N-00000-00Biden, Trump Descend on Iowa2019-06-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBiden, Trump Descend on IowaMatt Holt

After months of jabbing each other from afar, President Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden will overlap Tuesday in Iowa, a state thats critical to their political futures. The battle for the Democratic nomination is early and fluid, and Biden has plenty of work ahead to hold his lead among Democrats in Iowa and nationally. But the two mens convergence in a state that has swung between Democrats and Republicans over the past two decades could offer a glimpse into what a Trump-Biden matchup would look like if the former vice president prevails in his quest for the nomination. On Tuesday, Biden will criticize the presidents economic policy as hurting those very voters who helped elect him. Excerpts from Bidens prepared remarks: He thinks hes being tough.

Well, its easy to be tough when someone else is feeling the pain. How many sleepless nights do you think Trump has had over what hes doing to Americas farmers? Zero. (AP) BIDEN IN IOWA. When he first launched his presidential bid in April, Biden promised hed visit Iowa so often the state would be sick of him.Theyre still waiting. After making just four appearances during a two-day swing here in late April, Biden has been AWOL from a key early state thats accustomed to seeing presidential candidates in the flesh. Hell be returning to Iowa Tuesday and Wednesdayand recently announced plans to add 50 paid staffers in the state by the end of the monthbut Democratic officials say Biden has already fallen behind in organizing and needs to accelerate his efforts. (Politico) Biden rolled out eight Iowa endorsements Tuesday, including Betty Brim-Hunter, Former Political Director, Iowa Federation of Labor; Teri Hawks Goodman, Community Leader; Bruce Hunter, State Representative; Jim Lykam, State Senator; Mary Maloney, Polk County Treasurer; Jackie Norris, President CEO, Goodwill of Central Iowa; Former Assistant to the President and Chief of Staff to First Lady Michelle Obama; Tom Powers, Former Councilman, City of Waterloo; and Ken Runde, Former Dubuque County Sheriff Obama Administration United States Marshal. release) MORE BIDEN. A month after Biden announced his bid for president, several Fox News stars have already begun quietly pushing rumors that the 76-year-old ex-veep is in poor health. Since the end of May, Fox Business Network and Fox News star Lisa Kennedy Montgomery and Fox News prime-time host Sean Hannity have speculated on-air, on at least four separate occasions, that the current Democratic presidential frontrunner is secretly dealing with health issues, often comparing his condition to illness-related conspiracy theories the network pushed about Hillary Clinton during the 2016 election. (Daily Beast) Bidens reversal on his decades-long support for a law that prohibits using federal funds to pay for abortions could bring him more in line with Democratic primary voters, according to a new POLITICO/Morning Consult poll (June 7-9; 1,991 RVs, +/- 2%). Nearly a third of voters who say they plan to participate in a Democratic presidential primary or caucus, 32%, say they are more likely to vote for Biden after he changed his position on the Hyde Amendment Just 19% of potential Democratic primary voters say Bidens flip-flop makes them less likely to vote for him. (Politico) Biden, speaking at a fundraiser in D.C., reiterated his call to work with Republicans: With Trump gone youre going to begin to see things change. Because these folks know better. They know this isnt what theyre supposed to be doing. (release) BETO. "It grates every time Antonia Morales and Romelia Mendoza hear former Rep. Beto ORourke (D-TX) talk about the awful plight of immigrants. Its not that theyre unsympathetic to the families coming across the border in record numbers. They are immigrants themselves and live a few blocks from the line between Texas and their native Mexico. What infuriates the two women is that the homegrown presidential candidate wont talk about themthe last two residents living in the path of an arena that wealthy developers backedeven though O'Rourke helped put their immigrant neighborhood in Duranguito in the crosshairs for redevelopment when he served on the El Paso City Council. While ORourke touts a sweeping new immigration plan on the campaign trail, back in his old council district there is a giant chain link fence, wrapped in green mesh and covered with no trespassing warnings, surrounding the heart of Duranguito. Inside sit crumbling artifacts of El Pasos historycherished by activists and preservationists, but standing in the way, arena proponents say, of its future. (Texas Tribune) ORourkes campaign released a voter registration toolkit to empower more people to engage in their democracy by providing them the resources they need to register themselves and members of their communities to vote. (release) BULLOCK. Montana Gov. Steve Bullock (D) has been barnstorming across western Iowa, telling caucus goers wherever he can find them that he's the one who can beat Trump in 2020. But Bullock won't have the opportunity to make that case before a national audience later this month at the first Democratic primary debate. A new rule announced last week by the Democratic National Committee disqualified a Washington Post/ABC poll that had previously been included in the debate qualification criteria. (CBS News) BUTTIGIEG. South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg (D) will give a major address on his national security and foreign policy platform Tuesday morning at Indiana University, delving into details on a policy front that offers presidents wide latitude but which has gotten relatively little attention from Democratic 2020 candidates so far. It could be a standout issue for Buttigieg, a former Navy intelligence officer who served in Afghanistan and is the only veteran polling in the top half of the Democratic presidential primary. And its also a topic that Buttigieg can frame in general election terms by contrasting himself with Trump, whom Buttigieg has criticized for making up a disability to get out of serving during the Vietnam War. (Politico) Buttigieg has picked up one of the most influential Hollywood financiers as a backer, as he continues to surge in the 2020 fundraising battle. Nicole Avant, one of President Barack Obamas lead bundlers during his first run for president, has decided shes going all-in to back Buttigiegs run for president. (CNBC) CASTRO. Former HUD Secretary Julian Castro (D) wants to eliminate lead poisoning. He laid out the first dedicated plan on the issue of any 2020 candidate after a visit to Flint, Michigan, over the weekend. Castro is proposing to set up a presidential task force on lead, which would be charged with eliminating lead poisoning as a major public health threat, and the plan would include a national assessment of communities at risk of lead poisoning. (BuzzFeed) GILLIBRAND. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY) said Monday that it hit the 65,000 unique donor threshold to help her shore up her spot on this months' debate stage, a mark the campaign reached after spending heavily on Facebook ads this past week. Gillibrand's campaign spent more than $200,000 on Facebook ads between June 2 and June 8, according to the platform's Ad Library.(NBC News) Gillibrand will return to New Hampshire this weekend, and will hold several meet greets across the state as well as headline a New Hampshire Young Democrats grassroots fundraiser along with Connie Britton. (release) HARRIS. Five years before a major scandal on her watch as San Francisco district attorney, Sen. Kamala Harris (D-CA) confronted a choice that pitted two of her most important constituencies against each other. Aides to Ms. Harris in 2005 recommended adopting a policy popular among progressive criminal-justice reformers to disclose past misconduct by law enforcement in order to help ensure defendants received a fair trial. At the same time, police unions, who were already critical of the novice politician, opposed such a move as invasive and unnecessary. Harris didnt enact the policy at the time. That ended up backfiring years later in 2010, when her offices lack of whats known as a Brady policy was central in a scandal in which around 1,000 criminal cases were dismissed and a judge criticized Ms. Harris for violating defendants rights. She backtracked and enacted a policy in the aftermath. (Wall Street Journal) WARREN. As the 23 candidates seeking the Democratic nomination struggle to distinguish themselves, Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) has set herself apart with a series of sweeping proposals that would significantly remake the American economy, covering everything from tax policy to student debt relief and offering a detailed portrait of what her presidency might look like. Many of the proposals from Ms. Warren, a former Harvard law professor and hawk on financial regulation, could face a difficult path to winning over moderates in a general election, and to gaining approval in Congress if she did take the White House. But the sheer volume of her plans, and their detail and variety, is forcing her rivals to play catch-up and stake out their own positions. A review of the policy rollouts the 2020 Democrats have made since entering the race shows that Ms. Warren has issued the largest number of detailed plans among the major candidates roughly 20 in all, on subjects as varied as Big Tech regulation, housing costs and Pentagon contracting. Most of her rivals have released fewer than half a dozen; Biden, who leads in early polling, has issued only two. But Ms. Warren has already drawn criticism from centrists and conservatives who say her plans many calling for new regulationswould hurt business and the economy, stifle innovation and potentially harm the very workers they were intended to help. (New York Times) Warren and Sanders are vying to become the progressive alternative to Biden, a competition thats especially pivotal in the Midwest. The region is critical to Democratic hopes of regaining the White House in 2020, and Sanders campaign wrote in an April memo that hes by far the best positioned candidate to win in three upper Midwest states that handed Trump the White House. (AP)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60MX-S171-JC8Y-80PN-00000-00Biden victory will not turn clock back on global trade2020-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisFINANCEPg. 1Biden victory will not turn clock back on global tradeMartin Sandbu

If Joe Biden wins the US presidential election in November, the temptation will be to see Donald Trump's years in the White House as a temporary aberration from US engagement with the world and its willingness to uphold a rules-based liberal economic order.

Not only does Biden embody an older, more collaborative US outlook, he has even put climate change - a top concern for liberal multilateralists - at the centre of his campaign.

A victory for Trump's Democratic rival may well restore rules-based globalisation as the default for international economic interaction. But it will look very different from the globalisation of the 1990s. Even if the US recommits to a rules- based order, the conflict over what the rules should be will become much fiercer.

Both Trump's trade war and the immediate impulse from the pandemic have been about repatriating production. Post- Trump, the fight will shift from where production is located to how it is carried out. Welcome to the new trade policy: trade promotion, but in the service of extending the reach of the three blocs who set the rules - the US, EU and China.

Signs of this shift already abound. The update of the North American Free Trade Agreement made Mexico's preferential access to the automaker supply chain conditional on paying workers in its car industry higher wages.

The EU's trade deal with the Mercosur bloc will impose requirements ranging from animal welfare standards to respecting the Paris agreement on climate change. Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative aims to tie countries into Chinese trade and financial networks.

Smaller econ- omies are squeezed when big trading blocs insist on their standards. Emerging countries have little choice but to acquiesce to the demands of the world's biggest markets. Even sizeable national economies can be caught in the squeeze, as demonstrated by the UK's illusory hope to have close trade relations with both the EU and the US, while being completely free to set whatever standards it likes.

Aligning sectors

What is new is that countries are increasingly forced to align entire sectors with one of the big blocs. In the past, when trade was mostly in basic commodities and finished industrial goods, exporters could adjust production to each foreign market. But, for many reasons, rules increasingly cover the whole process of production.

Take the growing trade in services, which even physical goods, such as software-rich cars, now embody. That raises the stakes for the three big blocs to make sure it is their rules that are chosen. Demands for countries to make a choice will not go away with Trump.

Tensions will rise even in the area where America's return to the fold is most welcome. A Biden White House would recommit the US to the Paris agreement and may pursue an ambitious climate change policy at home. Biden promises carbon border taxes on imports from countries that are deemed to be "cheating on their climate commitments", a policy the EU also intends to introduce.

But making peace with Europe risks confrontation with China. It clears the field for a reunited west to form a "carbon club" demanding Beijing cracks down on its emissions or lose market access.

There are many possible outcomes of the looming regulatory battles. One is harmonisation: countries agree on similar (or similar enough) rules. This is the model of European economic integration, but is extremely unlikely on a global scale.

A second outcome is that countries outside the blocs are deeply absorbed into the sphere they are economically closest to. This creates dilemmas for economies close to more than one - think Latin America choosing between China and the US, or Africa between China and Europe.

A third is splintering. In some areas, the rule books of the three main trading blocs are irreconcilable and will probably remain so. This seems true of personal data processing, where Europeans prioritise consumers over digital producers, the US favours Big Tech, and China facilitates state surveillance.

Brussels effect

But a final, more optimistic, possibility is that countries converge on the most demanding standards. Under this "Brussels effect", countries sometimes adopt European-style rules because, once their companies satisfy them, they can typically also export to other markets.

The previous phase of globalisation was often criticised for triggering a race to the bottom. In the next phase, the struggle for regulatory dominance could paradoxically produce a race to the top. - Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2020

urn:contentItem:60GX-TDN1-DXH2-6123-00000-00Biden Wants To Be The Most Progressive President; Big Tech Grilled On Capitol Hill; Interview With Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL); Fauci Questioned Over Protests And COVID-19 Spread; Democrats Make A Mockery Of The Barr Hearing; Obama Pushes Mai-In Voting; Clinton-Epstein Connection; Maxwell Court Documents Unsealed; Mike Ditka Says Respect Our National Anthem Or Get Out; Remembering Herman Cain2020-08-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisWATTERS WORLD8:00 PM ESTMatt Gaetz, Donald Trump Jr., Mike DitkaNEWSDomestic080101cb.251Biden Wants To Be The Most Progressive President; Big Tech Grilled On Capitol Hill; Interview With Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL); Fauci Questioned Over Protests And COVID-19 Spread; Democrats Make A Mockery Of The Barr Hearing; Obama Pushes Mai-In Voting; Clinton-Epstein Connection; Maxwell Court Documents Unsealed; Mike Ditka Says Respect Our National Anthem Or Get Out; Remembering Herman CainJesse Watters, Dan Bongino, Mark Levin, Jackie Ibanez, Gregg Jarrett

MARK LEVIN, FOX NEWS HOST: Everything is on the table. Why? Because that is what the Democratic Party has become, a radical leftwing party. Think about it.

See you next time on LIFE, LIBERTY & LEVIN.

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: Welcome to WATTERS' WORLD, I'm Jesse Watters.

The Trump turnaround. That's the subject of tonight's Watters' Words.

You can feel the momentum shift in the presidential race. It showed up in the polls, too, in key battleground states. Take a look at the screen.

See, they show a consistent shift across the board to the President. Six point shift towards Trump in PA, four points to. Trump in Arizona, four point shift towards Trump in Florida, two points towards Trump in Michigan, one towards Trump in Wisconsin. Although a two point shift towards Biden in North Carolina, maybe that's why the President was there the other day.

Forget about the national polls. It's all about the battlegrounds anyway. Most pollsters are under sampling Republicans as high as 10 points. They do that just to depress turnout. Don't fall for it.

And just a little perspective, Hillary was beating Trump in every single battleground state going into the 2016 election. What happened? Hillary lost every single battleground state.

In addition, national polls showed Hillary crushing Trump. National polls showed John Kerry crushing Bush. National polls should Dukakis crushing Bush's dad, 41. And only two insurgent candidates knocked off an incumbent in the last 40 years. Rock Star Ronald Reagan and the politically gifted Bill Clinton with a little help from Ross Perot.

Biden, he doesn't have anywhere near that kind of talent and that's why he is hiding.

The President has been a lot more focused on the last two weeks. He has brought back the Coronavirus Briefings, addressing the nation six times from the Briefing Room. His tone is more serious, realistic and steady.

He's made major announcements about restocking the National PPE Stockpiles depleted under Obama-Biden. The vaccine trial phase is smashing all records. The therapeutics have been effective in the early stages and hospitalizations and mortality rates slashed in half.

And the President also announced the U.S. will soon become pharmaceutically independent, meaning we will be producing enough medical ingredients to keep our supply chain here in America.

He is punishing China for unleashing the virus on the world, while Joe Biden says nothing about the communist threat. The President beefed up his travel schedule, too, visiting Florida, Texas, North Carolina, Georgia and Maryland just in the last few weeks. Leaving the White House and visiting oil rigs, military facilities and medical plants.

Now Biden, he stays home in Delaware pretty much, maybe visits nearby Pennsylvania, but that's it. Don't buy the hype about Biden winning from his basement either.

He held a virtual speech the other day. Look at the bottom of the screen right here, put that up. Only 247 people were watching. No one cares what he has to say.

Schools are opening safely. The President allocating over $100 billion to safely do that. Biden, he wants schools closed. Businesses closed and churches closed before the election. That's just not going to cut it here in America.

The anarchists in Portland, they're being put down by Federal agents. Finally, the Oregon Governor stepped up to stop the violence. She is sending state and local police to help the Feds protect the Federal Courthouse and the Federal agents will remain in Portland to protect that courthouse until the streets are calm.

Bill Barr's taskforces had been activated in cities that are seeing spikes in homicides. They'll be working with local police departments to stop illegal gun trafficking, narcotics trafficking and gang violence.

Biden, he doesn't have a clue how to keep the streets safe. He could barely muster up a response to the anarchy in the first place.

This is a base election -- all about turnout. Trump's base is twice as fired up as Joe's base is. In fact, Joe doesn't really have a base. Have you ever seen a Biden bumper sticker anywhere? They don't exist.

Biden's base is basically borrowed Bernie Bros and Trump haters. There's no love for Joe Biden. In fact, the squad may not even vote for Joe. Biden is having trouble with blacks. He is having trouble with Hispanics. He is having trouble with young voters. That's why Biden's going so far left.

His is radical on trade, taxes, immigration and healthcare, and doesn't have a clue how to run a business or how to confront China. That's why Biden is desperate to rally the radical left and let slip this week that he himself is radical left. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESUMPTIVE DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: I think I have laid out the most detailed plans on the economy, and on issues relating to healthcare and the rest of any President in modern history.

I mean it's awful detail -- if I'm elected and this passes, I'm going to go down as the most progressive President in American history.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: So the President doesn't have to stretch too far to paint Biden as left because Biden just admitted it. But Biden doesn't know who he is. He'll just read whatever you put in front of them. He doesn't even know what year it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BIDEN: We had a relatively small population, and we called it at the time, Hispanic population, mostly Puerto Ricans, American citizens already. But you know, in the 2020 census, which is now two censuses ago, soon to be --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: Huh? Biden has always been a joke. He has run for President three times. He is a plagiarist. He is a hair sniffer. He's a national punchline, always has been.

Barack Obama didn't trust him to do anything. The two things he put Biden in charge of: the stimulus and Ukraine corruption. He fell flat on his face both.

So don't believe the lies you hear from the media or in social media about a Biden victory. This is going to be a very close election. But President Trump still has the edge.

Here with reaction, Fox News contributor, Dan Bongino, a former Secret Service agent and NYPD officer.

All right, Dan, what do you think about the analysis there at the top?

DAN BONGINO, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CONTRIBUTOR: I think you really made a great point, a pretty brilliant point. The only time and the last, you know, post-World War II really that an incumbent has lost in in our lifetimes has been the Bill Clinton, you know, Ross Perot, George H.W. election, and Ronald Reagan.

And your point that you followed up there where you said, listen, Bill Clinton was a gifted politician. I worked for him, you know, as a Secret Service and he had skills. You may not agree with his politics, but he had a way to make you feel like the most important person in the room.

Reagan was just the Dynamo. That speaks for itself.

Biden, you're right, is neither one of these and here's what's worse, if I may add on to your excellent story there. You like that, right?

WATTERS: Yes, I love it. Keep going.

BONGINO: We always throw the compliment to the show host.

WATTERS: Yes.

BONGINO: Here's the problem with Biden, not only is he terrible, he has obviously got issues, you know, listen, I'm not going to evaluate the guy with his psychological situation, but I mean, in fairness, he is going to be holding the nuclear codes and the guy doesn't know where he is.

I mean, he doesn't know what state he is in. He gets lost in the middle of an interview.

WATTERS: Right.

BONGINO: But not just is he bad, it's that who he attaches himself to via President Obama was terrible, too. Jesse, listen, nobody -- everybody gets what happened with the virus. That was the problem with the economy. Nobody, no sane person wants to go back to the Obama economy.

So he is bad and who he attaches himself to is even worse. He has got nowhere to go.

WATTERS: So do you think these are the four pillars of the reelection if the President confronts China, focuses on rebuilding the economy, keeps the streets safe, and basically tells Joe, you know, you can't even handle selling lemonade at a lemonade stand.

If he can do that, with the curveball thrown in because the vaccine is a curveball, Durham is a curveball, some sort of manufacturer October surprise from the fake news, that'll be a curveball. Is that how you see things shaping up in the next three months?

BONGINO: You know, I do. I just -- I'm torn on how much he should even pay attention to Biden. I know that sounds crazy. One side of me says, listen, chaos is never a message. Right? And Biden is the chaos candidate. There's no doubt about that.

Chaos. He doesn't know where he is. He doesn't even know he is running for President. He is clearly behind at a minimum, the redirecting funds from the police movement. I don't care what euphemism you want to use. He said it himself.

WATTERS: Yes, that sunk him.

BONGINO: He is clearly behind economic chaos with his tax hikes and stuff, but then the other side of me, Jesse says, the more you beat up on Biden, people almost feel bad for him. And Jesse, let's be candid. Does anybody really believe Biden is going to be President? The answer is no.

Either he loses the election or he wins, and nobody thinks he is the President anyway. It is going to be the Vice President and the Cabinet. So they've got to get that delicate balance where you don't make people feel bad for him, but you do point out the fact that this guy is absolutely the chaos candidate.

Your life will be an economic and street chaos if he is elected.

WATTERS: All right, Dan Bongino with the excellent analysis. Thank you very much.

BONGINO: Good to see.

WATTERS: Powerful CEOs grilled on Capitol Hill running the Big Tech deals. The head of Amazon, Facebook, Apple and Google hit for censorship and bias against conservatives.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MATT GAETZ (R-FL): It is possible that at Facebook, your employees do have the power to disadvantage conservative viewpoints.

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, Facebook: People make mistakes. People have some of their own goals some of the times.

GAETZ: There is either a little component or there is not a manual component, which is it?

SUNDAR PICHAI, GOOGLE, CEO: Creating those lists that process can involve a manual portion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: Joining me now, Florida Congressman, Matt Gaetz and author of the upcoming book, "Firebrand: Dispatches from the Frontlines of the MAGA Revolution," which is now available for preorder.

All right, so Congressman, you basically got these Big Tech executives to admit that they can have employees go rogue, censor conservatives, rewire and re-engineer sites to censor conservatives, and they don't have any idea what's going on under their own nose.

GAETZ: Big Tech used to tell us that it was just glitches in the algorithm that caused bias and mistreatment of conservatives. But now we see there are blacklists and deep inside the heart of every Silicon Valley woke- topian may beat the heart of an online tyrant.

And when you have those folks with that type of power, it does not give us the freedom, the democracy, the engagement that we deserve in a country as great as America.

WATTERS: Yes, and you guys have to threaten to bust up these monopolies if they don't play fair. You had -- I can't believe you're not on this committee because you're on every single committee, but Fauci was getting grilled by a bunch of your colleagues the other day. And here's Jim Jordan kind of giving it to Fauci.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Can the government limit the protesting?

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES: I don't think that's relevant to --

JORDAN: Well, you just said, if it increases the spread of the virus, I'm just asking, should we limit it?

FAUCI: Well, I'm not in a position to determine what the government can do in a forceful way.

JORDAN: No limit to protests, but, boy, you can't go to church on Sunday.

FAUCI: I don't know how many times I can answer that. I'm not going to opine on limiting anything. I'm just going to tell you --

JORDAN: You've opined on a lot of things, Dr. Fauci.

FAUCI: Yes, but I've never said --

JORDAN: This is something that directly impacts the spread of the virus and I'm asking your position on the protests.

FAUCI: Yes, I'm -- well, I'm not going to opine on limiting anything --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: All right, Congressman, a very smart guy, Dr. Fauci, but it seems like he's wearing thin with some of your colleagues. Is that true?

GAETZ: Yes. After watching that, I wondered whether or not churchgoers should just adopt the language of the protesters. Maybe we can have potluck protests or Sunday school sit-ins.

Maybe instead of giving our donations through tithes, we can just count that as bail money to release our eternal souls.

Jim Jordan pointed out that we don't get to choose the parts of the First Amendment that the government is going to allow and not allow, and though this is an uncommon virus, it should not deprive public health officials of basic commonsense.

WATTERS: Right. I mean, both protected under the First Amendment, but they're playing games with the rhetoric and the regulations.

All right, Barack Obama, I guess made some news, came out and said some pretty wild stuff at the funeral of the former Congressman the other day. This is what he said about nuking the filibuster. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: By ending some of the partisan gerrymandering so that all voters have the power to choose their politicians, not the other way around.

And if all this takes eliminating the filibuster, another Jim Crow relic, in order to secure the God-given rights of every American, then that's what we should do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: All right, so there everybody at the Lewis funeral gave him a big round of applause. So that's the game now. If Biden wins and they retake the Senate, they already have the House. They nuke that filibuster, man, they could add D.C. as a state. That could really tip the balance of power.

They could expand the Supreme Court, Congressman. They could go after guns. They could do anything they want and just jam a radical agenda down everyone's throat. Are people prepared for that?

GAETZ: Well, you know, when you look at Barack Obama, I guess it's surprising and confusing, that he is such a fan of Jim Crow relics, because it was Senator Obama in 2005, on President Bush's judicial nominations, and again in 2006, when Justice Alito was nominated, who said that the filibuster was necessary and important to debate in the Senate.

So, you know, maybe he was more willing to embrace Jim Crow relics as a senator than he is as a former President. But gosh, you know, John Lewis is someone who just should be celebrated outside of politics of -- you know, at his funeral.

I didn't really think that it was appropriate to be talking about the intricacies of redistricting and the filibuster while honoring a great American icon like John Lewis.

WATTERS: Yes, they lecture Republicans about decorum. All right, there he is, Congressman Matt Gaetz, best hair in Congress. I don't know --

GAETZ: You've got the best hair on Fox News, Jesse, so what a combo.

WATTERS: What a combo. I just don't have your hairdryer. I've got to save some money for that.

GAETZ: I'll send one to Emma.

WATTERS: Please do.

Damning documents unsealed in the Epstein-Maxwell case where we just confirmed about Bill Clinton on Epstein Island, and the long list of failures at the F.B.I. and the Department of Justice.

LEVIN: I've never seen a senior official of any administration ever treated like that. And I've been around a while. I was chief of staff to Attorney General Meese who was abused, but not like this.

LEVIN: First of all, I'm utterly confused. I thought people weren't allowed to have funerals. I thought there was a case brought to the Supreme Court where churches aren't allowed to have more than 10 people in one of these states, but casinos could have 50.

We need ID all over the country for a thousand different reasons. And so what? You have to actually vote.

Now, my problem is this. They're talking about it that the President even raised the possibility, well, maybe we have to put the vote off a little but he is trying to poke them in the eye and so forth.

WATTERS: That's right.

LEVIN: I would say this to Barack Obama. You're one of the great reasons in this country where there is a huge racial divide, and you could have been a great leader. You could have been a great leader of the American people of all races, but you couldn't put aside your community activism.

Mark Levin, watch his Sunday show, a huge hit and very provocative language on Twitter from Mr. Levin. Very Trump-esque.

Alan Dershowitz and former New Mexico Governor, Bill Richardson among several other prominent men who allegedly took part in the sexual abuse of underage girls.

Epstein telling her, you have done nothing wrong and I would urge you to start acting like it. Go outside, head high, not as an escaping convict. Go to parties. Deal with it.

TRUMP JR.: You don't -- you know, they don't have the same in-boxing problems.

WATTERS: That you, Donald Trump Jr., are more dangerous than the Ayatollah and the Communist Chinese. Everyone -- everyone is scared of Donald Trump Jr. and you're right, because here's the deal. It's about censorship.

TRUMP JR.: They will do whatever they can to push the voter to believe the radical left and to vote accordingly. That is their job in this. They've been doing it for a while. I mean, it's no secret. I've been on your show talking about, you know, social media censorship, what they're doing.

All right, so you have Joe Biden out there. He is running for President. He is walking for President, whatever you want to call it. He's gone far left. I don't know where his brain has gone. It might just be gone.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BIDEN: Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome at Kingswood Community Center. Actually, that's the one down I used to work -- that's a joke. You know where we are anyway. It's great to be here and back in a place where, you know --

TRUMP JR.: Jesse, what I want to know is, when does this -- when does this start being considered elder abuse? I mean, it's really not fair.

I mean, honestly, it wouldn't be truly sad if it wasn't so scary that this guy could be in charge of the nuclear football. You see it every day.

WATTERS: He fumbles.

TRUMP JR.: He doesn't remember where he is. He forgets who his wife is. He forgets what office he is running for. He gets in front of a crowd -- and don't forget Joe Biden is a 50-year swamp creature, right?

Chicago Bears legend Mike Ditka says if you can't respect our National Anthem, get the hell out of the country. The Hall of Famer joins me now.

All right, Coach, when you were with the Bears, if Singletary, if the Fridge, if anybody kneeled during the anthem, what would you do?

DITKA: Oh, they wouldn't play for us.

WATTERS: You'd bench them.

DITKA: It's that simple. Yes.

WATTERS: You just rip them right off the field? Or you just suspend them for the season? Or what would you do?

DITKA: You take them out. No, no. I would bench them. That's it. Until they found that it was honorable to respect the country.

This country has given them an opportunity to become millionaires. You understand, what I'm saying? You can't play American football in Peru. You can't play it in England.

American football can only be played in America and they make a lot of money doing it. Enjoy it. Respect it, but don't act like a clown.

WATTERS: You know, a lot of people agree with you, Coach. You know, they don't have players, and other countries do it.

WATTERS: Yes, other countries. They don't disrespect their anthems. They don't do it in in France and Germany and Great Britain. They don't do that. And those European countries have done a lot worse things than the United States. Why do you think in the United States this happens?

DITKA: I don't know. I really don't know. I don't understand what we've had -- I grew up in a community probably that was at least 50 percent black and 50 percent, a steel mill town, Aliquippa, Pennsylvania and we had no problem.

I played football my whole life and we had more black football players on our team we did than white, but it was never a problem. We played football. It wasn't about the color of a guy's skin. It was about the way he played the game, and what his contributions could be to society and to the school.

I mean, I don't get it. What's the big difference?

WATTERS: I don't get it either. I don't think a lot of the rest of the country gets it and if it happens in the NFL this season, I think a lot of people are going to go, click.

All right, Coach Ditka, thank you very much, and everybody go check out the X-League, women's tackle football. Mike Ditka is involved in that. Thank you.

Trump supporters are not defecting. They are not jumping ship.

New York-itis is where they believe that they are the center of the universe and that everybody agrees with them.

That's all for tonight. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. "Justice with Judge Jeanine is next."

And remember, I'm Watters and this is my world.

urn:contentItem:60M3-G411-DY7P-R001-00000-00Biden Would Reopen Trump-Cleared Mergers2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBiden Would Reopen Trump-Cleared Mergersby David Hatch

The draft 2020 Democratic Party Platform calls for a Biden administration to reopen select mergers cleared under President Donald Trump and impose new conditions to address any anticompetitive impacts.

The 80-page https://www.demconvention.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2020-07-21-DRAFT-Democratic-Party-Platform.pdf|document is set to be finalized during the mostly virtual Democratic National Convention from Aug. 17 to Aug. 20. It was adopted July 21.

Former Obama Vice President Joe Biden named Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., as his running mate on Tuesday, Aug. 11.

The tentative policy agenda, the wording and specifics of which could still change, suggests a Biden presidency would pivot toward greater skepticism about consolidation and any transactions that might increase it.

Pharmaceutical, healthcare, telecom, agriculture and retail mergers would be prioritized for reexamination by an incoming Democrat administration, the document says.

That could put some of the most iconic brands in the crosshairs of a Biden-era Federal Trade Commission or Department of Justice, including AT&T Inc. (T) Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. (BMY), Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) and DuPont (DD).

Beyond impacts on consumer prices, competition and innovation, enforcers are urged to assess whether mergers cleared by the Trump administration harmed workers and increased racial inequality.

The Democrats also hint that they want to broaden the "consumer welfare standard," the bedrock of antitrust for decades that emphasizes consumer consequences, mainly price effects, as the key metric to determining whether a transaction is anticompetitive.

Democrats will direct regulators to consider potential effects of future mergers on the labor market, on low-income and marginalized communities, and on racial equity, as well as on consumer prices and market competition, the platform says.

The Deal https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/14735497/index.dl|reported in 2018 that the Republican heads of the FTC and DOJ antitrust division insisted that the existing standard is flexible enough to accommodate evolving markets and technologies.

Notably, the document tamps down the rhetoric on breaking up companies accused of abusing their market power.

On the campaign trail, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., https://medium.com/@teamwarren/heres-how-we-can-break-up-big-tech-9ad9e0da324c |proposed that Facebook, Inc. (FB), Alphabet Inc. s (GOOGL) Google, and Amazon should be split apart to rein in Big Tech.

But the platform signals caution.

As a last resort, regulators should consider breaking up corporations if they find they are using their market power to engage in anticompetitive activities, the platform recommends.

DEAL SIZE

$ 50 Billion and Up

urn:contentItem:5J9R-VN61-DY0W-447Y-00000-00Big 3 Ask For $34 Billion; Driving Beyond Detroit; Banks Seek Young Assets; Fox 50 Gains Ground; Big 3's Survival Plans; Inbev Clydesdales Trot2008-12-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBig 3 Ask For $34 Billion; Driving Beyond Detroit; Banks Seek Young Assets; Fox 50 Gains Ground; Big 3's Survival Plans; Inbev Clydesdales TrotLanhamFULL TEXT

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning. Coming up this morning on "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST," the planes are out, the hybrids are in, and those turnaround plans delivered. But will Detroit automakers blueprints for survival convince Congress to give them a bailout?

And a Fox Business Exclusive, Anheuser-Busch President David Peacock with the latest on the Inbev buyout and what the future may hold for the company's marketing icon ,the Clydesdales.

And then we'll hit the catwalk for Victoria's Secret annual fashion show, in another Fox Business Exclusive, an interview with Victoria's Secret's CEO.

Today is Wednesday, December 3rd, 2008. "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST" starts right now.

Good morning and welcome to "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST." I'm Alexis Glick.

We have the very latest on the auto bailout coming up and Senator Arlen Specter will join us a little bit later.

Also the latest challenger, Gray & Christmas numbers and the ADP private sector numbers will all be coming out this morning.

But first a quick look on how the futures are stacking up here in the U.S.

This after a nice rally yesterday while most of the major markets were up anywhere from three to four percent, lifting up about I guess a third to half of the losses that we saw on Monday.

But this morning we have reversed trend. We are now looking lower, down 1.3 percent or down 115 points on the DOW we're staying at about 8,320. The S&P is down 13 or 1.7 percent. The NASDAQ is down 17 or down about one and a half percent as we speak.

All right, let's get things started with the three things you should know this morning.

After saying he was not going to touch the remaining TARP funds, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Paulson is according to the "Wall Street Journal" debating whether to ask Congress for the second half of those funds.

The Journal says he may ask for it as early as next week.

And one month after Election Day, incumbent Republican Senator Saxby Chambliss is claiming victory against Democrat Jim Martin in a runoff election in Georgia after neither received at least 50 percent of the votes as mandated by state law.

Meanwhile, Minnesota says they are into day nine of the recount between Republican incumbent Senator Norm Coleman and comic Al Franken.

And Super Bowl hero Plaxico Burress is done for the year and maybe for good with the New York Giants who fined and suspended him yesterday after he accidentally shot himself in the leg last weekend at a Manhattan nightclub. He now faces a minimum two-year jail term under New York law.

All right, those are the three things you should know about this morning.

Now for the three things you need to know about in the overseas markets, here's Mr. Ashley Webster in London.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FBN OVERSEAS MARKETS WRITER: Hey, good morning, Alexis and good morning, everybody.

Well, we saw some nice gains in Asia, but not so, so far in Europe. Let's take a look at the latest numbers. Here in London on the FTSE 100, down about half a percent at this hour. Although this is off of our lows. In Paris the CAC-40 off one and a half. And in Germany the DAX 30 index also off close to two percent now.

Talking of Germany, shares in a big German semiconductor company are short circuiting this morning; Infineon, reporting its seventh straight quarterly loss. The company says the fourth quarter loss came in at a whopping $970 million more than expected. The company blaming weakness in the sector, restructuring costs and write-downs associated with its stake in chipmaker Qimonda, Infineon's stock now down 25 percent.

Sacre bleu, Warren Buffett is facing a fight now with a French utility. Electricity de France is making a $4.5 billion bid for 50 percent of Constellation Energy's nuclear assets now Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway already made a $4.7 billion bid for this company for all of the company; it is a U.S. power company. Shareholders will vote on Buffett's offer later this month. But EBS says it undervalues Constellations true worth, it is a battle royale no doubt.

Let's go to Connell McShane for today's three market movers. Good morning, Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Ashley.

The Blackberry maker Research in Motion making a list this morning cutting its third quarter forecast. The company saying earnings per share are going to come in somewhere between 81 and 83 cents. The problem with that is that Wall Street is looking for 91 cents. So RIM saying a stronger dollar as well as the general economic slowdown have hurt its business and had hurt its stock plunging more than 67 percent so far this year.

Google is bracing for very difficult times. The Internet search engine giant is cutting back spending and cutting back on projects; a lot of the perks that go into being an employee at Google are apparently going by the wayside. So we'll keep an eye on Google stock down from the 700s into the 275 range on that stock here over the last year or so.

Now, we do have some breaking news this morning that we want to bring to you on mortgage applications. We don't always give you this number as it comes out but it is just being released now and what a gain in mortgage applications as mortgage rates come down.

In fact, according to the Mortgage Banker's Association, this is the biggest gain they have ever seen, in record. It is just in this morning. An increase has been reported in refinancing activity; that is a very, very big increase. Overall we're talking about re-fi's being up percentage terms at least by 200 percent here over the same -- over the last week and the overall market index increasing 112 percent according to the MBA which is just out with these numbers.

Again, it's their largest rise on record Alexis, the mortgage applications with the drop we've seen in mortgage rates apparently more people going out and refinancing their mortgages and getting new mortgages all together. So that's an interesting stat that's just in.

Those are the three market movers and it's back over to you in the studio.

GLICK: All right, I love that stat. I'm trying to refinance my mortgage too, Connell, just not getting the phone call back.

MCSHANE: Get in there.

GLICK: But we'll talk about that later.

All right, Detroit's big three automakers presented recovery plans to Congress late yesterday, and the pitch has become more dramatic as General Motors and Chrysler now say they are on the verge of a collapse by month's end unless they get the money from the government they need right now.

For more on what the plans say, Fox Business's Rich Edson joins us this morning from Washington, D.C. with more of the details. Good morning Rich.

RICH EDSON, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi good morning, Alexis. When these guys were up on Capitol Hill a couple of weeks ago and they were asking for $25 billion, it wasn't all that convincing that $25 billion was all that they needed especially when Congressmen were asking them to basically add up and individually separate how much they would need out of that $25 billion.

Two car companies went first and when the third went, they really couldn't answer to bring to that $25 billion number. Eventually they got there. And then they said ok we do need only 25 billion. But today that number has been just blown out of the water; $34 billion is potentially what these guys say they are going to need over the next year from the federal government.

The biggest coming from GM, $18 billion they say they are going to need at least $12 billion to operate next year, $4 billion immediately of that $12 billion, and if the economy gets worse, they say they are going to need an extra $6 billion. That goes to $18 billion for next year.

Ford is asking for $9 billion. Though it says it does not need it right away, it would like a $9 billion line of credit from the government.

And Chrysler is saying that it wants $7 billion in loans from the federal government.

So the proposals are in. They are on Capitol Hill. And one analyst said it's time to get to legislative work. Here's what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEAN WEST, GROUP ANALYST: The last round was a nice bit of political theater. The Democrats got that out of the way. They don't look like they are soft on automakers anymore. They played tough. They wouldn't have continued to keep the session open if they weren't planning on actually funding something.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: All right, here the concessions all three CEOs say they will take only a dollar in compensation if they get the loans. Chrysler is talking about an electric drive model in 2010. Ford says its 2015 fleet will be 36 percent more efficient than the models it offered in 2005. GM is giving corporate jets, they're giving them up. Ford is selling its jets and they are all driving to Washington, D.C. this time around; big difference from last time.

They're asking for billions of dollars, and they're also offering warrants in exchange for those billions. As far as the differences are concerned, Ford says it can turn a profit by 2011 or at least break even by that year. Chrysler is in merger talks. That really separates them. They are still looking for a partner.

And GM will focus its U.S. branding to Chevy, Buick, GMC and Cadillac. Pontiac is going to stay more of a niche brand. Rick Wagoner says GM is looking hard at all its other names and they can possibly contract them.

But Alexis as you know, when GM got rid of Oldsmobile a couple of years ago, it was a lengthy process, it was an expensive process. It cost them more than a million bucks, a billion bucks excuse me, back to you.

GLICK: Yes, I was going to say, it was a little bit more than that. All right, Rich Edson thank you so much, for bringing us up to date on all of that because wow it is complicated.

Well, as lawmakers debate that total of $34 billion that Rich Edson just talked about, automakers say they need the money to speed up production of new energy saving vehicles.

Now, based on yesterday's sales figures, no one is buying their current crop of cars. Get this, Chrysler sales were down 47 percent. GM was down 41. Ford down 31. Now, if GM survives it is betting big on the Volt, an electric car that has been rushed into production and will hit show rooms ideally within 18 months.

Here to discuss if the $40,000 Volt can save GM is Michael Duoba, he is the mechanical engineer at the Center for Transportation Research Energy Systems Division. And John Grisma is the chief insights officer for Young and Rubican Brands. He is also the author of "The Brand Bubble: The looming crisis in brand value and how to avoid it."

Welcome, gentlemen, thanks for being here.

MICHAEL DUOBA, CENTER FOR TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH: Thanks, Alexis.

GLICK: Michael, let me start with you. GM has been talking about this Volt. In fact the vice chairman sort of staked his career on it. He's been incredibly well known in the industry for the kind of cars he's developed. What do you make of whether or not GM could be successful with this car?

DUOBA: Well, I think that the Chevy Volt is a pretty exciting car. I think Bob Lutz is kind of the John F. Kennedy saying that he's going to go to the moon and end of the decade. And I think GM is kind of staking their brand on taking this car to the next level and perhaps dethroning the Prius as being the ultimate environmental car.

GLICK: John, there's some big differences between how people look at a car like the Toyota Prius and how they're trying to market this GM's Volt car here. Tell me what the differences are and why this is so important in their ability to sell this car.

JOHN GRISMA, CHIEF INSIGHTS OFFICER FOR YOUNG AND RUBICAN BRANDS: Absolutely. I think first and most importantly you have to look at GM is looking at this strategy clearly to improve its overall corporate image. And if you look back at some of the studies we've got actually seen there was a halo effect on the Toyota Prius meaning that there was actually moving across the board. You saw the SUVs and the trucks actually improving their perceptions of fuel efficiency just on the basis of having this one product in the line.

So clearly that's important from a perspective. But I think we have to slow down a little bit and really focus on what is the essence of this car? Will it really make an impact in the marketplace?

I think you've got to look at the fact that it is essentially they are talking 10,000 cars in what 2011. You're talking $30,000 at a price point a lot of questions it just loses with consumers.

GLICK: Yes and right now the price tag we're hearing is more like $40,000 but there's some vagary around it because it's still a long ways away.

But John, part of the issue here, you are a brand expert, and you've been watching what's been happening to the quality and the franchise behind the GM name. What has been happening and why is that contributing sort to the lack of, I guess, belief that this company can turn the story around?

GRISMA: You know, one of the things we wrote about in our book was the concept that consumers are actually acting more and more like shareholders, like investors. They are actually looking into the future for their expectations of brands.

And when we look at GM in the context of brand asset value which is our consumer brand database we have seen decline in trust, decline in differentiation, a decline in sort of perceived quality. This isn't necessarily fair because they are making some great products and the critics have actually -- the car critic really praised recent brands like the Cadillac, GTS, as well as the Saturn Aura.

So in that context I think what GM is trying to do is clearly get on board with green. I think all the big three automakers were behind a little bit in this in the 90s. They're trying to practice the sense of humility as well as sustainability. I mean I think if also if you step back and you look at GM, they pulled out of the Super Bowl this year, a very high- profile venue, $three million for a 30 second spot. They have ended their relationship with Tiger Woods which was a long time spokesperson. So I think they're trying to kind of be a little bit less flashy, a little bit more demure and try to get aligned with the administration's priorities.

GLICK: Michael, when you talk about the quality of this car or what it might do to turn GM's business around, they are sort of staking their future on it, who is going to buy this car?

DOUBA: That's a very good question. And I think that anyone can buy the car if you have a place to plug in. So there is a concern about the infrastructure involved you have to plug the car in every night as you would plug in your cell phone. So it is kind of a new paradigm of what we do with our car and how we use it.

But I think you know people who live in the suburbs who can drive enough miles to displace all the fuel that the vehicle promises to displace can buy the car.

GLICK: And are you concerned at all Michael about the price point? I mean I know we're looking out a couple of years from now, but on the other hand, you know, they are kind of staking their future on it, so it is kind of important.

DUOBA: Yes, I mean the price is -- it might be a little bit out of the reach of the average buyer, but it's -- they're not going to make money -- GM's is not going to make money on this product, so it is matter of just having enough, enough sales that they can show it's a strong product.

GLICK: John, what do you think?

GRISMA: I think that's the real key issue. I think you have to look at the infrastructure issues. You're talking about a $30,000 car. You're talking about perhaps urban environments because it's got a 40 miles range. How do you set up the infrastructure to basically plug in cars? How do you deal with that in New York? How do you deal with that in Boston?

Now, I think that these technologies will follow this car and it is an exciting thing but I think GM has to step back and think this isn't necessarily the one single silver bullet. They were successful in the past with the Corvette but let's look at this in the long-term plans for what they are going to do to roll out more sustainable vehicles.

GLICK: The one thing that you mentioned earlier is you said humility and sustainability. I presume that the combination of those two things is what they need to demonstrate to Congress later this week that they have both of those things.

You mentioned pulling back from the Super Bowl and a couple other moves that they've made but how do they bring about sustainability if they've now come to the well and said we need an additional $6 billion this after just testifying two weeks ago?

GRISMA: Yes, I mean first of all you've seen them out of their corporate jets and into their hybrids going to Capitol Hill. But I also think it's important to really look at how do they align with the administration's priorities? How do they align now with the Uber shareholders which is the taxpayers right? If GM is dealing with taxpayer money?

So I think in that context, what they have to do is prove their long-term sustainability, their ability to actually get in line with where Americans want to go, lessen their dependence on foreign oil and focus on really marketing this car in the context of where GM and Ford and Chrysler where are they're going in the future.

GLICK: It's interesting because we're going to talk to one of the top executives at Anheuser-Busch this morning and there used to be a concept here called made in America and we used to be excited about that and somehow we've got to turn this philosophy around because we're not very excited about it right now when it concerns the automakers.

All right, John and Michael, thank you guys so much. I appreciate it.

All right, coming up the newly formed Anheuser-Busch Inbev brought the largest European and American brewers together. After the break we're going to have an exclusive interview with the president of the Anheuser- Busch division to talk about the transition.

And then for all you Victoria's Secret lovers out there, Victoria's Secret angels are hitting the runway to revive sales this holiday season. We're going to have another exclusive interview with their CEO in just a little bit. You won't want to miss it. I promise.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
