And Q3 productivity was slightly better than anticipated, coming in at 1.3 percent.

This on the heels of a Challenger Gray & Christmas jobs number that came out earlier this morning that showed a job loss of 181,000 in the month of November. To break down all three of those numbers, Leo Tilman is the former chief strategist for Bear Stearns; Mark Lieberman is our FOX Business senior economist; and our FOX Business contributor Charles Payne is here.

All right, guys. Mark, you got an opportunity to look at the Q3 productivity number. I know unit labor costs is something you are concerned about. What did you find and how does it look?

MARK LIEBERMAN, FOX BUSINESS SR. ECONOMIST: Unit labor costs went up 3.1 percent in the final report...

GLICK: What does that mean?

LIEBERMAN: It means it is actually the cost of producing each specific item. It is an index that tracks that. It tells us something about where inflation is going and this is obviously tracking what we have seen in other inflation indicators.

Similarly, as we look at the overall productivity number, a strong productivity gain is probably more important in a good economy because it keeps prices down and it keeps a standard of living up.

What's happening now is, and it's tracking what we see in the rest of the economy, output is down, we see that from GDP, but employment and jobs are down further. So when you do simple arithmetic...

GLICK: Workers are becoming more productive.

LIEBERMAN: Exactly.

GLICK: Charles, what do you make of these numbers? Also the ADP number -- which let's keep in mind, the ADP number saw a loss of 250,000 jobs, there's usually not the best of correlations between the private sector number and the non-farm payrolls that we see from the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Friday. But we've been looking for a loss of 300,000.

I wonder whether or not those estimates are going to go higher since the private sector number was so depressing.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Absolutely. And to that point, ADP numbers always seem to be a lot rosier, if you will, than the Bureau of Labor statistics. So for them to come out with 250,000, you have got to be nervous.

I mean, if you weren't nervous already, to be quite frank, you are right now. As far as productivity, Alexis, I mean, this is something that was really more important in a different sort of economy where the Fed didn't know if it wanted to lower rates or raise rates and they needed cover. You know, I know Greenspan was able to use that productivity boom to keep rates low, much to everyone's chagrin...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: Yes, but what we really care about is jobs today.

PAYNE: At this point, yes. It doesn't seem like it matters.

GLICK: So, Leo, you have two pieces of data that came out this morning, both worse than anticipated, what do you now think the non-farm payrolls numbers is going to look like on Friday?

LEO TILMAN, FMR. CHIEF STRATEGIST, BEAR STEARNS: I think it is going to be weak. And all indications point to that. And to that point I think the inflation story is less important today. It is interesting that early in the year we were all concerned about systemic inflation pressures. Then we went into deflation worries. And now I think it's just not an issue for any foreseeable future.

It is conceivable that down the road the stimuli, the monetary policy are going to reignite inflation, but it is not in any foreseeable future.

GLICK: Mark?

LIEBERMAN: I think that's right. I mean, you know, deflation became more and more of a concern. And when you think about it, I mean, what can the Fed do if we were in an inflationary environment? Well, the Fed can raise interest rates. One of the ways you would combat deflation is to reduce interest rates. Well, there's a floor on how far you can go down on deflation.

GLICK: But if deflation becomes, as some suspect it might, a really big problem, let's just say for the sake of argument over the next six months, I know everybody is talking about inflation longer term being the bigger issue because we're -- the printing presses have not shut down since we arrived on television a year ago, but what if deflation becomes a real issue? How do we address it knowing that real interest rates are actually negative?

LIEBERMAN: A couple of things are going to work on this. Number one, as income improves, as the economy does recover, and this may shock some of the people who I work with regularly, it will recover. The...

GLICK: Oh, so that was the rose-colored glasses, the question, Mark...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: ... which we get like once every three months.

PAYNE: He has a rose-colored monocle somewhere.

LIEBERMAN: Exactly. No, the economy clearly will recover. It's going to take some time. And what's going to happen at the recovery, there will be pent up demand, and demand is the furor (ph) for deflation. You have to do whatever you can to pump up demand.

We have to put people back to work. We talk about that ad nauseam. Although it's obviously...

GLICK: Investments, all that kind of stuff.

LIEBERMAN: ... investments and things like that. And people -- you know, there's going to be -- if you deprive yourself of that big screen TV, at some point you are going to want to buy it, even though it's not made here.

TILMAN: On that note, bringing down long-term rates is going to play to that as well. So all the purchases of Treasury securities and agency securities by the Fed are an additional stimulus that should...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: ... mortgage applications explode. And I understand you say it is only applications, it is not necessarily full refinance activity. But, look, Charles and I have been talking about it, I'm like -- the minute I started seeing rates come down, I'm like, let's get on it. And I think a lot of people across this country are. So hopefully that's one good piece of...

(CROSSTALK)

LIEBERMAN: Let's think about that for a second, because what that is saying is that homeowners who are refi-ing -- it is not purchases, it is homeowners who are refi-ing, if they are doing that, why are they doing it? They desperately need cash.

GLICK: Yes. I'd like a little extra cash. Hey, it is a good thing.

(CROSSTALK)

PAYNE: Since the National Bureau of Economic Research gave this time stamp to the recession, we have got to give Mark props. Because Mark did call this.

GLICK: Yes, he did say fourth quarter last year.

LIEBERMAN: Thank you.

GLICK: You did call it, yes.

(APPLAUSE)

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: Yes, there he is. We love Mark Lieberman, even when he's depressed, we always try to cheer him up though.

LIEBERMAN: For depression you take a pill. Otherwise for recession...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: A pill. A cocktail. I was thinking these should be Bloody Mary conversations from now on. What do you think? I mean, we could propose that.

LIEBERMAN: Mimosas, whatever.

GLICK: Yes. See, look, there he is, mimosas. All right, guys, thank you very much. And I do want to mention by the way that Leo Tilman has a book, and I haven't even mentioned it, it's "Financial Darwinism." This is a very brilliant guy. So you want to pick that up. All right, guys.

Coming up, we're going to talk to Blockbuster video because they are making some huge changes. The CEO of the movie rental chain is going to be with us in a FOX Business exclusive when we return. They've got some very exciting things up their sleeves that I'm not sure you have heard about. We will talk about that coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: Blockbuster the leading brand for video rentals has seen its original business model attacked by technology, but now it's hitting the fast forward button to reinvent itself. The company is teaming up with Microsoft to develop new digital services that will let you watch movies on your phone. And it has entered into a partnership with Live Nation to sell concert tickets. This morning we welcome James Keyes, he's the chairman and CEO of Blockbuster.

Good to see you.

JAMES KEYES, CHMN. & CEO, BLOCKBUSTER: Great to be here, thanks.

GLICK: So you are doing a lot of inventive things because there's always this tug-of-war between Netflix and Blockbuster, each trying to move one step ahead of each other. Tell me about some of these -- this new technological road map, particularly as it relates to cell phones or mobile devices.

KEYES: Well, mobile devices, eventually portability is going to be king. We all like the convenience of being able to watch content when we want, where we want. And that really is the legacy of Blockbuster. Blockbuster was never really about video rentals. It was always about convenient access to media entertainment.

So the key is for us to transcend all of the various channels to keep up with technology and to provide our customers with the most convenient access wherever it is, even on your mobile phone.

GLICK: So I understand you are working on a deal here with Microsoft in terms of how to get the technology and the software so that we can get it on our mobile devices, and one of the things you are doing right now is testing it on kiosks and the ability for us perhaps to travel in an airport and upload it at some point in the future. Where is that going?

KEYES: Well, the key with the digital technology is that it's a wonderful thing. It allows so much flexibility with content, and yet, it seems that everyone is trying to get content on their big screen TV. Bandwidth in the United States is going to take some time to catch up to this demand because the file size for movies is actually very large.

So in the interim, in the next five years or 10 years, there are many other ways to deliver digital content. We are trying out some kiosks in stores, for example, so instead of taking an hour, hour-and-a-half to load a movie, you can load it in 30 seconds or 60 seconds right directly onto a portable device and have the convenience and flexibility of digital content in a portable fashion.

GLICK: You know, there are a lot of people who look at the video game industry, as I said to you yesterday, I spoke to an executive at Xbox, and I know they have a relationship with Netflix, but they look at that industry as a place which is experiencing unusual growth in a very difficult economy, and they are experiencing it year-over-year.

What kind of things are you trying to do perhaps to maybe address that audience, that demo which is a tremendous demo by doing partnerships like what Netflix and Xbox are doing together?

KEYES: We are -- again, it is very early, the idea of digital content directly to the home through game consoles or set-top boxes, very, very early in its development. Yes, we just released just a week ago a deal with a company called 2Wire, that's a large provider of these boxes and this technology to deliver content directly to the television, so now you can get Blockbuster on demand.

We have several thousand movies, new releases available from the ease of pulling up video-on-demand from your couch. And this is just another step. Again, very early.

GLICK: So who will sell those boxes? I mean, if 2Wire is a company that makes them, like, would I be able to get them on my set-top cable box? I mean, where will I see that come to me, the consumer?

KEYES: Today you can actually buy Blockbuster on demand online at blockbuster.com. We are selling it in a few stores just trying to test the consumer demand. That's really our objective right now. It is very early in the developmental stage.

But eventually you will find that this capability is baked not only into your cable box, but directly into your television set. In fact, we announced a deal with Intel not too long ago where their new chip for their Internet-ready television set in the next couple of years will include a widget that allows you to pull up the Blockbuster icon right there on your television set and have immediate access to all of your favorite movies.

GLICK: OK. So let's just take that example and let's just assume that for the sake of argument you live here in a place like New York City, you have Time Warner Cable. So I have Time Warner Cable and I have now just purchased this Internet television. Time Warner offers pay-per-view events, on demand events, how is it that I'm going to go to you as opposed to going to my cable operator who has been wired into my home?

KEYES: Well, today Blockbuster really owns that entertainment customer, particularly the customer for movies. And so our job is to make it a nice smooth transition for that customer to move over to these other services. And that's why we're leading now with Blockbuster on demand.

Eventually the cable companies will want to offer their customers various services. We will all have unique content. We will all have proprietary and exclusive content, and that will keep Blockbuster, the brand, relevant for the consumer.

GLICK: You know, one of the things I said yesterday to this executive at Xbox is I said, listen, you know, when we're on that console and they show the list of Netflix movies, they tend to be outdated, frankly. They're not the kind of movies, I'm sorry to say, that I want to see in today's world.

How do you make sure that you are delivering the newest, most credible content on any device right now so that it makes me want to do it? And if iPhone is doing something similar, why would I go with one of the devices that you have in a relationship with Microsoft as opposed to everybody carrying around that iPhone or that iPod?

KEYES: Well, first of all, you won't have that problem with Blockbuster. People have come to know and trust Blockbuster for the newest releases, the latest releases. Our Blockbuster on demand will have new releases. It is very different from the Netflix offering, as an example, which is a unique product, a very good product, but it is a subscription product.

And by nature, subscription content delivered digitally will be a little bit older content. It will be more in the pay TV window or two or three years older on average than the new releases that you can find available on Blockbuster.

So this is an opportunity for us. And as we go forward, our key competitive advantage will be to make it easy, convenient for the customer, and to have the best content available, the newest releases, exclusive content only available at Blockbuster.

GLICK: All right. James Keyes, sounds terrific. Come back, join us again, particularly as you put some of these plans in place. I want to see some of these devices and learn a little bit more about it.

KEYES: Well, thanks, great to be here.

GLICK: Great to have you.

All right, guys. We will be right back in just a moment with the "1 Thing You Should Know." Unfortunately, the one thing you should know right now is the market is pretty much at the low of the day. We are down 140 -- 156 points right now. The S&P down 2 percent, the Nasdaq down 2.25 percent. Some of this of course on the heels of those jobs numbers this morning. We will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All right. Now it is time for the "1 Thing You Should Know. We get started with Ashley Webster in London.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, you know what, Alexis? I was looking at all this miserable news that's coming about in the U.K. and the Eurozone, I thought, well, I will do this story. It's kind of interesting.

But there is quite a lot of snow around the U.K. and there's some blizzards forecast for tonight in the northern part of the country. So that means the odds of it snowing in London on Christmas Day now down to 11 to 4. It was 7 to 1.

You know, we bet on anything in the U.K. The odds are now down that a snow flake will fall on the London weather center on Christmas Day is now down to 11 to 4. I may take that bet.

GLICK: Wow, yes. Wouldn't it be great to have a white Christmas? We don't have enough white Christmases, at least here in New York. I'm sure for you in California it rarely ever happens. When you were growing up, did they do -- like I heard some families would bring in like the fake snow?

JENNA LEE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Oh, they do that, yes, absolutely. They will have like places that the kids can sled, but it will be sunny. So it never really felt like Christmas. It was always sunny.

GLICK: Yes, but now you are here.

LEE: Now I can freeze and feel...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: OK. So what's your "1 Thing"?

LEE: You know, we (INAUDIBLE) talk so much about mortgage applications and refinances being way up. And I think that after the program that was announced last week, that can't be a bad sign. And we have to take it in relative terms from the weeks before, but it can't be a bad thing.

GLICK: Yes, I like that. I actually think it is a good sign. I understand Lieberman is like, Alexis, it is only applications, but you know what? The fact that we can make homeownership more affordable or that we'll go out and refinance, personally I'm hoping to take advantage of it.

PAYNE: I think it is fantastic. My "1 Thing" though is, by the way, I think automakers, the CEOs should go on horseback to Capitol Hill.

GLICK: Maybe they should do the Clydesdales.

PAYNE: They should ride horses because, you know what, you bring back the thought of Paul Revere and how important it is for America. And also you suggest to America, you don't bail us out, everybody is going to be riding one of these.

GLICK: Yes, that's a great point. What about that "made in America." You know, we need to like be excited about "made in America" again. We need to work on them. Give them some tips.

All right, guys. We are going to go to commercial break. We are going to come back. We are going to have "The Opening Bell" coming up next. We are going to talk to a top executive in the power and energy world who can talk to us a little bit about all of this electricity grid, infrastructure building, some of the things that we have been talking about in terms of fiscal stimulus.

Stay with us. "The Opening Bell" is next. Thanks, guys.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:5KR6-6FB1-DY0W-4096-00000-00Big 3 Ask For $34 Billion; Driving Beyond Detroit; Banks Seek Young Assets; Fox 50 Gains Ground; Big 3's Survival Plans; Inbev Clydesdales Trot2008-12-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBig 3 Ask For $34 Billion; Driving Beyond Detroit; Banks Seek Young Assets; Fox 50 Gains Ground; Big 3's Survival Plans; Inbev Clydesdales TrotWalthamFULL TEXT

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning. Coming up this morning on "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST," the planes are out, the hybrids are in, and those turnaround plans delivered. But will Detroit automakers blueprints for survival convince Congress to give them a bailout?

And a Fox Business Exclusive, Anheuser-Busch President David Peacock with the latest on the Inbev buyout and what the future may hold for the company's marketing icon ,the Clydesdales.

And then we'll hit the catwalk for Victoria's Secret annual fashion show, in another Fox Business Exclusive, an interview with Victoria's Secret's CEO.

Today is Wednesday, December 3rd, 2008. "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST" starts right now.

Good morning and welcome to "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST." I'm Alexis Glick.

We have the very latest on the auto bailout coming up and Senator Arlen Specter will join us a little bit later.

Also the latest challenger, Gray & Christmas numbers and the ADP private sector numbers will all be coming out this morning.

But first a quick look on how the futures are stacking up here in the U.S.

This after a nice rally yesterday while most of the major markets were up anywhere from three to four percent, lifting up about I guess a third to half of the losses that we saw on Monday.

But this morning we have reversed trend. We are now looking lower, down 1.3 percent or down 115 points on the DOW we're staying at about 8,320. The S&P is down 13 or 1.7 percent. The NASDAQ is down 17 or down about one and a half percent as we speak.

All right, let's get things started with the three things you should know this morning.

After saying he was not going to touch the remaining TARP funds, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Paulson is according to the "Wall Street Journal" debating whether to ask Congress for the second half of those funds.

The Journal says he may ask for it as early as next week.

And one month after Election Day, incumbent Republican Senator Saxby Chambliss is claiming victory against Democrat Jim Martin in a runoff election in Georgia after neither received at least 50 percent of the votes as mandated by state law.

Meanwhile, Minnesota says they are into day nine of the recount between Republican incumbent Senator Norm Coleman and comic Al Franken.

And Super Bowl hero Plaxico Burress is done for the year and maybe for good with the New York Giants who fined and suspended him yesterday after he accidentally shot himself in the leg last weekend at a Manhattan nightclub. He now faces a minimum two-year jail term under New York law.

All right, those are the three things you should know about this morning.

Now for the three things you need to know about in the overseas markets, here's Mr. Ashley Webster in London.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FBN OVERSEAS MARKETS WRITER: Hey, good morning, Alexis and good morning, everybody.

Well, we saw some nice gains in Asia, but not so, so far in Europe. Let's take a look at the latest numbers. Here in London on the FTSE 100, down about half a percent at this hour. Although this is off of our lows. In Paris the CAC-40 off one and a half. And in Germany the DAX 30 index also off close to two percent now.

Talking of Germany, shares in a big German semiconductor company are short circuiting this morning; Infineon, reporting its seventh straight quarterly loss. The company says the fourth quarter loss came in at a whopping $970 million more than expected. The company blaming weakness in the sector, restructuring costs and write-downs associated with its stake in chipmaker Qimonda, Infineon's stock now down 25 percent.

Sacre bleu, Warren Buffett is facing a fight now with a French utility. Electricity de France is making a $4.5 billion bid for 50 percent of Constellation Energy's nuclear assets now Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway already made a $4.7 billion bid for this company for all of the company; it is a U.S. power company. Shareholders will vote on Buffett's offer later this month. But EBS says it undervalues Constellations true worth, it is a battle royale no doubt.

Let's go to Connell McShane for today's three market movers. Good morning, Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Ashley.

The Blackberry maker Research in Motion making a list this morning cutting its third quarter forecast. The company saying earnings per share are going to come in somewhere between 81 and 83 cents. The problem with that is that Wall Street is looking for 91 cents. So RIM saying a stronger dollar as well as the general economic slowdown have hurt its business and had hurt its stock plunging more than 67 percent so far this year.

Google is bracing for very difficult times. The Internet search engine giant is cutting back spending and cutting back on projects; a lot of the perks that go into being an employee at Google are apparently going by the wayside. So we'll keep an eye on Google stock down from the 700s into the 275 range on that stock here over the last year or so.

Now, we do have some breaking news this morning that we want to bring to you on mortgage applications. We don't always give you this number as it comes out but it is just being released now and what a gain in mortgage applications as mortgage rates come down.

In fact, according to the Mortgage Banker's Association, this is the biggest gain they have ever seen, in record. It is just in this morning. An increase has been reported in refinancing activity; that is a very, very big increase. Overall we're talking about re-fi's being up percentage terms at least by 200 percent here over the same -- over the last week and the overall market index increasing 112 percent according to the MBA which is just out with these numbers.

Again, it's their largest rise on record Alexis, the mortgage applications with the drop we've seen in mortgage rates apparently more people going out and refinancing their mortgages and getting new mortgages all together. So that's an interesting stat that's just in.

Those are the three market movers and it's back over to you in the studio.

GLICK: All right, I love that stat. I'm trying to refinance my mortgage too, Connell, just not getting the phone call back.

MCSHANE: Get in there.

GLICK: But we'll talk about that later.

All right, Detroit's big three automakers presented recovery plans to Congress late yesterday, and the pitch has become more dramatic as General Motors and Chrysler now say they are on the verge of a collapse by month's end unless they get the money from the government they need right now.

For more on what the plans say, Fox Business's Rich Edson joins us this morning from Washington, D.C. with more of the details. Good morning Rich.

RICH EDSON, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi good morning, Alexis. When these guys were up on Capitol Hill a couple of weeks ago and they were asking for $25 billion, it wasn't all that convincing that $25 billion was all that they needed especially when Congressmen were asking them to basically add up and individually separate how much they would need out of that $25 billion.

Two car companies went first and when the third went, they really couldn't answer to bring to that $25 billion number. Eventually they got there. And then they said ok we do need only 25 billion. But today that number has been just blown out of the water; $34 billion is potentially what these guys say they are going to need over the next year from the federal government.

The biggest coming from GM, $18 billion they say they are going to need at least $12 billion to operate next year, $4 billion immediately of that $12 billion, and if the economy gets worse, they say they are going to need an extra $6 billion. That goes to $18 billion for next year.

Ford is asking for $9 billion. Though it says it does not need it right away, it would like a $9 billion line of credit from the government.

And Chrysler is saying that it wants $7 billion in loans from the federal government.

So the proposals are in. They are on Capitol Hill. And one analyst said it's time to get to legislative work. Here's what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEAN WEST, GROUP ANALYST: The last round was a nice bit of political theater. The Democrats got that out of the way. They don't look like they are soft on automakers anymore. They played tough. They wouldn't have continued to keep the session open if they weren't planning on actually funding something.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: All right, here the concessions all three CEOs say they will take only a dollar in compensation if they get the loans. Chrysler is talking about an electric drive model in 2010. Ford says its 2015 fleet will be 36 percent more efficient than the models it offered in 2005. GM is giving corporate jets, they're giving them up. Ford is selling its jets and they are all driving to Washington, D.C. this time around; big difference from last time.

They're asking for billions of dollars, and they're also offering warrants in exchange for those billions. As far as the differences are concerned, Ford says it can turn a profit by 2011 or at least break even by that year. Chrysler is in merger talks. That really separates them. They are still looking for a partner.

SPECTER: Well, there is good reason to be skeptical. We know that the big three, they haven't performed in the past. They haven't kept up with the times on fuel efficiency and cars that will sell. But we're facing a situation here where the consequences of their going under could be very, very devastating for the entire economy.

So the issue is, will their plans provide a realistic opportunity for success? And in our free enterprise system, we let the market determine winners and losers. But where you have a situation where there could be a very serious impact on the entire economy, I think we ought to consider the specifics as to what they've proposed.

GLICK: Yes. I mean my concern, senator, is, look, believe me, I'm worried about the job losses, I'm worried about the industry and the implications it could have for the greater economy. What bothers me about the story is it has not been clearly demonstrated to me what the sustainability is of the industry. And perhaps what we need to consider is, maybe it shouldn't be the big three. I mean maybe it should be the big seven or a combination, you know. I just haven't heard enough of a justification as to how the industry is going to change. We're built for 16 million cars. We're selling 10 million cars. And I imagine that number's not going to get much better over the next couple of years.

SPECTER: Well, you haven't heard enough justification. And, frankly, neither have I. But I'm prepared to look. That's my pedigree. My job as a senator is to take a look at the specifics as to what they have proposed. I want to see where their efficiencies are. I want to see the economists and the experts in the field make an evaluation which is objective. And then I want to make the determination as to whether there's a realistic chance that they can succeed. Because if we can avoid having them go under and having a lot of people lose their jobs and having the ripple effect go through suppliers and automobile dealers across the economy, that's something what we want to do. But we're not going to do it blindly. Only if they make a solid case.

GLICK: Great point. A solid case.

Now, let me ask you, there are two members who are going to be sitting on the panel. I know you had Peter Morici from the University of Maryland sitting on the panel last time. This time you're going to have comptroller Mr. Gene Didarro (ph), who's a Moody's chief economist. Tell me why you're adding these two names to the panel and what you hope to get out of them in addition to talking to the executives.

SPECTER: Well, the economists have been added to the panel to get some independent evaluation as to what the consequences would be. Look here, when you talk about what's going to happen in the future on the economy, it is very, very hard to judge. And we want to have the best experts we can find to give us some insights. And then there's examination and cross- examination.

You must watch C-Span occasionally, as well as your own network, and you see the way the senators probe and get more information. And we'll be doing that. It's our judgment. It's not their judgment. We're elected to make these judgments. And that's why I convened a meeting yesterday in Philadelphia, why my staff and I have been pouring over the details of the semicolons (ph) so that when we go back to Washington on Monday, we're in a position to make an informed judgment.

GLICK: You know, you were speaking of Philadelphia, senator. Tell me, how do the people in Pennsylvania feel about the bailout of the auto industry?

SPECTER: Well, people in Pennsylvania haven't spoken about the bailout of the auto industry. But let me tell you how they felt about the $700 billion which we legislated all last October. They didn't like it.

I spent the month of October doing town meetings, which is my practice, to touch all of Pennsylvania's 67 counties. The temperature was 212. They wanted to know why the regulators hadn't done their job. They wanted to know what was going to be done with the $700 billion. And I told them that it was a very bitter decision that I faced and that the others faced because of what we were informed would be the consequences.

So the issue now to help the big three is something that I'm prepared to do only if they really make, as I said before, the solid case. I know that the public opinion is against the bailouts, but sometimes, in my position, you have to make decisions which may not be the most popular if that really is my judgment or our collective judgment about what is in the public interest.

GLICK: You know, senator, I am so glad that you brought up the TARP program because there are reports that Treasury Secretary Paulson may go as early as next week to members of Congress to ask for the other $350 billion. If he stands in front of the Senate, what will you tell him if he asks for the money?

SPECTER: Well, the first thing I will ask him is what he has done with the first $350 billion. We have a problem which was created because of the mortgage situation, defaults on mortgages, and the Treasury Department has done precious little on that subject.

Then we took a look at the credit freeze, and there were a lot of highly sophisticated fandangos that they were undertaking to try to put money in the banks and nothing has happened there. Before we're going to consider giving him $350 billion more, he is going to have to have some really good explanations as to what he has done with the first $350 billion.

And I've had a chance to meet with Treasury Secretary Paulson, and very bluntly, I haven't been impressed with what he has had to say.

GLICK: Finally, before I let you go, in Philadelphia yesterday, in addition to the meetings that you said you had about the auto manufacturers and the plans they laid out, President-elect Obama met with many current governors and former governors about this proposed stimulus plan.

We are now hearing to the tune of $500 billion, maybe more, how do you feel about it, and do you believe that infrastructure, rebuilding, job creation are essential parts of a fiscal stimulus plan if in fact we have the money to pay for it?

SPECTER: There's no doubt that our highways and our bridges are crumbling. What I'm going to be looking for are parts of a stimulus plan which are pro-growth. For example, the stimulus package we passed last summer, I had a proposal which had been pending for a long time to authorize expensing or deductibility of 50 percent in the first year of capital advances.

For example, if a steel company built a big hearth, they had it depreciated 20 years, 5 percent a year, my legislation, which is put into the plan, is able to take 50 percent in the first year. And that's the kind of a pro-growth proposal which sticks to the regs, which is more than giving several hundred dollars to people to spend, which doesn't have any lasting effect.

It may feel good for a short period of time. So when we talk about highways and bridges and items which will enable us to be pro-growth in the future, those are the proposals which will draw my support.

GLICK: All right. Well, Senator Specter, great pleasure speaking with you this morning. Thank you so much for taking the time to talk with us.

SPECTER: Thank you. I have enjoyed it.

GLICK: All right. Let's go upstairs to Connell McShane, because, Connell, I know we saw those third-quarter productivity numbers just came out. And a little bit more analysis on those ADP numbers as well.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes, we see the productivity at the bottom of your screen has actually been revised higher in the third quarter which is a surprise. The expectation was it would be revised lower. So 1.3 percent at an annual rate in the third quarter compared to the prior quarter. That is an upward revision compared to the first number. And it was expected to be downward.

So that is a bit of a surprise to the market. The futures have actually come off their lows, for what it is worth, they're down 142, and the Dow futures have been about 20 points more than that there a moment ago.

So that's the economic data this morning that has just been released. There are your futures. We are going to give you, as we go to break here, two quick stocks to watch in the day ahead, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. Merrill Lynch has just come out and significantly cut its fourth- quarter earnings estimates or lack thereof for both Goldman and Morgan.

Instead of a profit, they are expecting losses of both of these firms. And they've -- the downward revision could affect both of those stocks. Keep an eye on them today. Our panel is going to weigh in on all of the economic numbers, and a FOX Business exclusive, the CEO of Blockbuster coming up, explaining how they are competing in a crowded market. So don't go away. "Money for Breakfast" continues here in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All right. As Connell just mentioned, the productivity numbers, the revision to the third quarter just came out. In addition we saw the second announcement of jobs reports this morning coming out of ADP on private sectors, a decline of 250,000. That did exceed estimates. And Q3 productivity was slightly better than anticipated, coming in at 1.3 percent.

This on the heels of a Challenger Gray & Christmas jobs number that came out earlier this morning that showed a job loss of 181,000 in the month of November. To break down all three of those numbers, Leo Tilman is the former chief strategist for Bear Stearns; Mark Lieberman is our FOX Business senior economist; and our FOX Business contributor Charles Payne is here.

All right, guys. Mark, you got an opportunity to look at the Q3 productivity number. I know unit labor costs is something you are concerned about. What did you find and how does it look?

MARK LIEBERMAN, FOX BUSINESS SR. ECONOMIST: Unit labor costs went up 3.1 percent in the final report...

GLICK: What does that mean?

LIEBERMAN: It means it is actually the cost of producing each specific item. It is an index that tracks that. It tells us something about where inflation is going and this is obviously tracking what we have seen in other inflation indicators.

Similarly, as we look at the overall productivity number, a strong productivity gain is probably more important in a good economy because it keeps prices down and it keeps a standard of living up.

What's happening now is, and it's tracking what we see in the rest of the economy, output is down, we see that from GDP, but employment and jobs are down further. So when you do simple arithmetic...

GLICK: Workers are becoming more productive.

LIEBERMAN: Exactly.

GLICK: Charles, what do you make of these numbers? Also the ADP number -- which let's keep in mind, the ADP number saw a loss of 250,000 jobs, there's usually not the best of correlations between the private sector number and the non-farm payrolls that we see from the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Friday. But we've been looking for a loss of 300,000.

I wonder whether or not those estimates are going to go higher since the private sector number was so depressing.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Absolutely. And to that point, ADP numbers always seem to be a lot rosier, if you will, than the Bureau of Labor statistics. So for them to come out with 250,000, you have got to be nervous.

I mean, if you weren't nervous already, to be quite frank, you are right now. As far as productivity, Alexis, I mean, this is something that was really more important in a different sort of economy where the Fed didn't know if it wanted to lower rates or raise rates and they needed cover. You know, I know Greenspan was able to use that productivity boom to keep rates low, much to everyone's chagrin...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: Yes, but what we really care about is jobs today.

PAYNE: At this point, yes. It doesn't seem like it matters.

GLICK: So, Leo, you have two pieces of data that came out this morning, both worse than anticipated, what do you now think the non-farm payrolls numbers is going to look like on Friday?

LEO TILMAN, FMR. CHIEF STRATEGIST, BEAR STEARNS: I think it is going to be weak. And all indications point to that. And to that point I think the inflation story is less important today. It is interesting that early in the year we were all concerned about systemic inflation pressures. Then we went into deflation worries. And now I think it's just not an issue for any foreseeable future.

It is conceivable that down the road the stimuli, the monetary policy are going to reignite inflation, but it is not in any foreseeable future.

GLICK: Mark?

LIEBERMAN: I think that's right. I mean, you know, deflation became more and more of a concern. And when you think about it, I mean, what can the Fed do if we were in an inflationary environment? Well, the Fed can raise interest rates. One of the ways you would combat deflation is to reduce interest rates. Well, there's a floor on how far you can go down on deflation.

GLICK: But if deflation becomes, as some suspect it might, a really big problem, let's just say for the sake of argument over the next six months, I know everybody is talking about inflation longer term being the bigger issue because we're -- the printing presses have not shut down since we arrived on television a year ago, but what if deflation becomes a real issue? How do we address it knowing that real interest rates are actually negative?

LIEBERMAN: A couple of things are going to work on this. Number one, as income improves, as the economy does recover, and this may shock some of the people who I work with regularly, it will recover. The...

GLICK: Oh, so that was the rose-colored glasses, the question, Mark...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: ... which we get like once every three months.

PAYNE: He has a rose-colored monocle somewhere.

LIEBERMAN: Exactly. No, the economy clearly will recover. It's going to take some time. And what's going to happen at the recovery, there will be pent up demand, and demand is the furor (ph) for deflation. You have to do whatever you can to pump up demand.

We have to put people back to work. We talk about that ad nauseam. Although it's obviously...

GLICK: Investments, all that kind of stuff.

LIEBERMAN: ... investments and things like that. And people -- you know, there's going to be -- if you deprive yourself of that big screen TV, at some point you are going to want to buy it, even though it's not made here.

TILMAN: On that note, bringing down long-term rates is going to play to that as well. So all the purchases of Treasury securities and agency securities by the Fed are an additional stimulus that should...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: ... mortgage applications explode. And I understand you say it is only applications, it is not necessarily full refinance activity. But, look, Charles and I have been talking about it, I'm like -- the minute I started seeing rates come down, I'm like, let's get on it. And I think a lot of people across this country are. So hopefully that's one good piece of...

(CROSSTALK)

LIEBERMAN: Let's think about that for a second, because what that is saying is that homeowners who are refi-ing -- it is not purchases, it is homeowners who are refi-ing, if they are doing that, why are they doing it? They desperately need cash.

GLICK: Yes. I'd like a little extra cash. Hey, it is a good thing.

(CROSSTALK)

PAYNE: Since the National Bureau of Economic Research gave this time stamp to the recession, we have got to give Mark props. Because Mark did call this.

GLICK: Yes, he did say fourth quarter last year.

LIEBERMAN: Thank you.

GLICK: You did call it, yes.

(APPLAUSE)

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: Yes, there he is. We love Mark Lieberman, even when he's depressed, we always try to cheer him up though.

LIEBERMAN: For depression you take a pill. Otherwise for recession...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: A pill. A cocktail. I was thinking these should be Bloody Mary conversations from now on. What do you think? I mean, we could propose that.

LIEBERMAN: Mimosas, whatever.

GLICK: Yes. See, look, there he is, mimosas. All right, guys, thank you very much. And I do want to mention by the way that Leo Tilman has a book, and I haven't even mentioned it, it's "Financial Darwinism." This is a very brilliant guy. So you want to pick that up. All right, guys.

Coming up, we're going to talk to Blockbuster video because they are making some huge changes. The CEO of the movie rental chain is going to be with us in a FOX Business exclusive when we return. They've got some very exciting things up their sleeves that I'm not sure you have heard about. We will talk about that coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: Blockbuster the leading brand for video rentals has seen its original business model attacked by technology, but now it's hitting the fast forward button to reinvent itself. The company is teaming up with Microsoft to develop new digital services that will let you watch movies on your phone. And it has entered into a partnership with Live Nation to sell concert tickets. This morning we welcome James Keyes, he's the chairman and CEO of Blockbuster.

Good to see you.

JAMES KEYES, CHMN. & CEO, BLOCKBUSTER: Great to be here, thanks.

GLICK: So you are doing a lot of inventive things because there's always this tug-of-war between Netflix and Blockbuster, each trying to move one step ahead of each other. Tell me about some of these -- this new technological road map, particularly as it relates to cell phones or mobile devices.

KEYES: Well, mobile devices, eventually portability is going to be king. We all like the convenience of being able to watch content when we want, where we want. And that really is the legacy of Blockbuster. Blockbuster was never really about video rentals. It was always about convenient access to media entertainment.

So the key is for us to transcend all of the various channels to keep up with technology and to provide our customers with the most convenient access wherever it is, even on your mobile phone.

GLICK: So I understand you are working on a deal here with Microsoft in terms of how to get the technology and the software so that we can get it on our mobile devices, and one of the things you are doing right now is testing it on kiosks and the ability for us perhaps to travel in an airport and upload it at some point in the future. Where is that going?

KEYES: Well, the key with the digital technology is that it's a wonderful thing. It allows so much flexibility with content, and yet, it seems that everyone is trying to get content on their big screen TV. Bandwidth in the United States is going to take some time to catch up to this demand because the file size for movies is actually very large.

So in the interim, in the next five years or 10 years, there are many other ways to deliver digital content. We are trying out some kiosks in stores, for example, so instead of taking an hour, hour-and-a-half to load a movie, you can load it in 30 seconds or 60 seconds right directly onto a portable device and have the convenience and flexibility of digital content in a portable fashion.

GLICK: You know, there are a lot of people who look at the video game industry, as I said to you yesterday, I spoke to an executive at Xbox, and I know they have a relationship with Netflix, but they look at that industry as a place which is experiencing unusual growth in a very difficult economy, and they are experiencing it year-over-year.

What kind of things are you trying to do perhaps to maybe address that audience, that demo which is a tremendous demo by doing partnerships like what Netflix and Xbox are doing together?

KEYES: We are -- again, it is very early, the idea of digital content directly to the home through game consoles or set-top boxes, very, very early in its development. Yes, we just released just a week ago a deal with a company called 2Wire, that's a large provider of these boxes and this technology to deliver content directly to the television, so now you can get Blockbuster on demand.

We have several thousand movies, new releases available from the ease of pulling up video-on-demand from your couch. And this is just another step. Again, very early.

GLICK: So who will sell those boxes? I mean, if 2Wire is a company that makes them, like, would I be able to get them on my set-top cable box? I mean, where will I see that come to me, the consumer?

KEYES: Today you can actually buy Blockbuster on demand online at blockbuster.com. We are selling it in a few stores just trying to test the consumer demand. That's really our objective right now. It is very early in the developmental stage.

But eventually you will find that this capability is baked not only into your cable box, but directly into your television set. In fact, we announced a deal with Intel not too long ago where their new chip for their Internet-ready television set in the next couple of years will include a widget that allows you to pull up the Blockbuster icon right there on your television set and have immediate access to all of your favorite movies.

GLICK: OK. So let's just take that example and let's just assume that for the sake of argument you live here in a place like New York City, you have Time Warner Cable. So I have Time Warner Cable and I have now just purchased this Internet television. Time Warner offers pay-per-view events, on demand events, how is it that I'm going to go to you as opposed to going to my cable operator who has been wired into my home?

KEYES: Well, today Blockbuster really owns that entertainment customer, particularly the customer for movies. And so our job is to make it a nice smooth transition for that customer to move over to these other services. And that's why we're leading now with Blockbuster on demand.

Eventually the cable companies will want to offer their customers various services. We will all have unique content. We will all have proprietary and exclusive content, and that will keep Blockbuster, the brand, relevant for the consumer.

GLICK: You know, one of the things I said yesterday to this executive at Xbox is I said, listen, you know, when we're on that console and they show the list of Netflix movies, they tend to be outdated, frankly. They're not the kind of movies, I'm sorry to say, that I want to see in today's world.

How do you make sure that you are delivering the newest, most credible content on any device right now so that it makes me want to do it? And if iPhone is doing something similar, why would I go with one of the devices that you have in a relationship with Microsoft as opposed to everybody carrying around that iPhone or that iPod?

KEYES: Well, first of all, you won't have that problem with Blockbuster. People have come to know and trust Blockbuster for the newest releases, the latest releases. Our Blockbuster on demand will have new releases. It is very different from the Netflix offering, as an example, which is a unique product, a very good product, but it is a subscription product.

And by nature, subscription content delivered digitally will be a little bit older content. It will be more in the pay TV window or two or three years older on average than the new releases that you can find available on Blockbuster.

So this is an opportunity for us. And as we go forward, our key competitive advantage will be to make it easy, convenient for the customer, and to have the best content available, the newest releases, exclusive content only available at Blockbuster.

GLICK: All right. James Keyes, sounds terrific. Come back, join us again, particularly as you put some of these plans in place. I want to see some of these devices and learn a little bit more about it.

KEYES: Well, thanks, great to be here.

GLICK: Great to have you.

All right, guys. We will be right back in just a moment with the "1 Thing You Should Know." Unfortunately, the one thing you should know right now is the market is pretty much at the low of the day. We are down 140 -- 156 points right now. The S&P down 2 percent, the Nasdaq down 2.25 percent. Some of this of course on the heels of those jobs numbers this morning. We will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All right. Now it is time for the "1 Thing You Should Know. We get started with Ashley Webster in London.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, you know what, Alexis? I was looking at all this miserable news that's coming about in the U.K. and the Eurozone, I thought, well, I will do this story. It's kind of interesting.

But there is quite a lot of snow around the U.K. and there's some blizzards forecast for tonight in the northern part of the country. So that means the odds of it snowing in London on Christmas Day now down to 11 to 4. It was 7 to 1.

You know, we bet on anything in the U.K. The odds are now down that a snow flake will fall on the London weather center on Christmas Day is now down to 11 to 4. I may take that bet.

GLICK: Wow, yes. Wouldn't it be great to have a white Christmas? We don't have enough white Christmases, at least here in New York. I'm sure for you in California it rarely ever happens. When you were growing up, did they do -- like I heard some families would bring in like the fake snow?

JENNA LEE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Oh, they do that, yes, absolutely. They will have like places that the kids can sled, but it will be sunny. So it never really felt like Christmas. It was always sunny.

GLICK: Yes, but now you are here.

LEE: Now I can freeze and feel...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: OK. So what's your "1 Thing"?

LEE: You know, we (INAUDIBLE) talk so much about mortgage applications and refinances being way up. And I think that after the program that was announced last week, that can't be a bad sign. And we have to take it in relative terms from the weeks before, but it can't be a bad thing.

GLICK: Yes, I like that. I actually think it is a good sign. I understand Lieberman is like, Alexis, it is only applications, but you know what? The fact that we can make homeownership more affordable or that we'll go out and refinance, personally I'm hoping to take advantage of it.

PAYNE: I think it is fantastic. My "1 Thing" though is, by the way, I think automakers, the CEOs should go on horseback to Capitol Hill.

GLICK: Maybe they should do the Clydesdales.

PAYNE: They should ride horses because, you know what, you bring back the thought of Paul Revere and how important it is for America. And also you suggest to America, you don't bail us out, everybody is going to be riding one of these.

GLICK: Yes, that's a great point. What about that "made in America." You know, we need to like be excited about "made in America" again. We need to work on them. Give them some tips.

All right, guys. We are going to go to commercial break. We are going to come back. We are going to have "The Opening Bell" coming up next. We are going to talk to a top executive in the power and energy world who can talk to us a little bit about all of this electricity grid, infrastructure building, some of the things that we have been talking about in terms of fiscal stimulus.

Stay with us. "The Opening Bell" is next. Thanks, guys.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:7W6C-99W0-YBK5-D2W3-00000-00Big 3 Ask For $34 Billion; Driving Beyond Detroit; Banks Seek Young Assets; Fox 50 Gains Ground; Big 3's Survival Plans; Inbev Clydesdales Trot2008-12-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBig 3 Ask For $34 Billion; Driving Beyond Detroit; Banks Seek Young Assets; Fox 50 Gains Ground; Big 3's Survival Plans; Inbev Clydesdales Trot

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning. Coming up this morning on "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST," the planes are out, the hybrids are in, and those turnaround plans delivered. But will Detroit automakers blueprints for survival convince Congress to give them a bailout?

And a Fox Business Exclusive, Anheuser-Busch President David Peacock with the latest on the Inbev buyout and what the future may hold for the company's marketing icon ,the Clydesdales.

And then we'll hit the catwalk for Victoria's Secret annual fashion show, in another Fox Business Exclusive, an interview with Victoria's Secret's CEO.

Today is Wednesday, December 3rd, 2008. "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST" starts right now.

Good morning and welcome to "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST." I'm Alexis Glick.

We have the very latest on the auto bailout coming up and Senator Arlen Specter will join us a little bit later.

Also the latest challenger, Gray & Christmas numbers and the ADP private sector numbers will all be coming out this morning.

But first a quick look on how the futures are stacking up here in the U.S.

This after a nice rally yesterday while most of the major markets were up anywhere from three to four percent, lifting up about I guess a third to half of the losses that we saw on Monday.

But this morning we have reversed trend. We are now looking lower, down 1.3 percent or down 115 points on the DOW we're staying at about 8,320. The S&P is down 13 or 1.7 percent. The NASDAQ is down 17 or down about one and a half percent as we speak.

All right, let's get things started with the three things you should know this morning.

GLICK: Maybe they should do the Clydesdales.

PAYNE: They should ride horses because, you know what, you bring back the thought of Paul Revere and how important it is for America. And also you suggest to America, you don't bail us out, everybody is going to be riding one of these.

GLICK: Yes, that's a great point. What about that "made in America." You know, we need to like be excited about "made in America" again. We need to work on them. Give them some tips.

All right, guys. We are going to go to commercial break. We are going to come back. We are going to have "The Opening Bell" coming up next. We are going to talk to a top executive in the power and energy world who can talk to us a little bit about all of this electricity grid, infrastructure building, some of the things that we have been talking about in terms of fiscal stimulus.

Stay with us. "The Opening Bell" is next. Thanks, guys.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END
