Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:7W77-4H01-2PFY-H0VJ-00000-00Big 3 Ask For $34 Billion; Driving Beyond Detroit; Banks Seek Young Assets; Fox 50 Gains Ground; Big 3's Survival Plans; Inbev Clydesdales Trot Away2008-12-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisMONEY FOR BREAKFAST7:00 AM ESTLeo Tilman, Michael Nutter, Sharen Turney, Michael Duoba, John Grisma, David Peacock, Trevor Hamilton, Thaddeus McCotter, Bill Hartnett, Arlen Specter, Arlen Specter, Leo Tilman, James KeyesNEWSFinancial120301cb.220Big 3 Ask For $34 Billion; Driving Beyond Detroit; Banks Seek Young Assets; Fox 50 Gains Ground; Big 3's Survival Plans; Inbev Clydesdales Trot AwayAlexis Glick, Charles Payne, Ashley Webster, Connell McShane, Mark Lieberman, Rich Edson

Detroit's big three automakers presented recovery plans to Congress late yesterday, and the pitch has become more dramatic as General Motors and Chrysler now say they are on the verge of a collapse by month's end unless they get the money from the government they need right now.

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning. Coming up this morning on "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST," the planes are out, the hybrids are in, and those turnaround plans delivered. But will Detroit automakers blueprints for survival convince Congress to give them a bailout?

And a Fox Business Exclusive, Anheuser-Busch President David Peacock with the latest on the Inbev buyout and what the future may hold for the company's marketing icon ,the Clydesdales.

And then we'll hit the catwalk for Victoria's Secret annual fashion show, in another Fox Business Exclusive, an interview with Victoria's Secret's CEO.

Today is Wednesday, December 3rd, 2008. "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST" starts right now.

Good morning and welcome to "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST." I'm Alexis Glick.

We have the very latest on the auto bailout coming up and Senator Arlen Specter will join us a little bit later.

Also the latest challenger, Gray & Christmas numbers and the ADP private sector numbers will all be coming out this morning.

But first a quick look on how the futures are stacking up here in the U.S.

This after a nice rally yesterday while most of the major markets were up anywhere from three to four percent, lifting up about I guess a third to half of the losses that we saw on Monday.

But this morning we have reversed trend. We are now looking lower, down 1.3 percent or down 115 points on the DOW we're staying at about 8,320. The S&P is down 13 or 1.7 percent. The NASDAQ is down 17 or down about one and a half percent as we speak.

All right, let's get things started with the three things you should know this morning.

After saying he was not going to touch the remaining TARP funds, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Paulson is according to the "Wall Street Journal" debating whether to ask Congress for the second half of those funds.

The Journal says he may ask for it as early as next week.

And one month after Election Day, incumbent Republican Senator Saxby Chambliss is claiming victory against Democrat Jim Martin in a runoff election in Georgia after neither received at least 50 percent of the votes as mandated by state law.

Meanwhile, Minnesota says they are into day nine of the recount between Republican incumbent Senator Norm Coleman and comic Al Franken.

And Super Bowl hero Plaxico Burress is done for the year and maybe for good with the New York Giants who fined and suspended him yesterday after he accidentally shot himself in the leg last weekend at a Manhattan nightclub. He now faces a minimum two-year jail term under New York law.

All right, those are the three things you should know about this morning.

Now for the three things you need to know about in the overseas markets, here's Mr. Ashley Webster in London.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FBN OVERSEAS MARKETS WRITER: Hey, good morning, Alexis and good morning, everybody.

Well, we saw some nice gains in Asia, but not so, so far in Europe. Let's take a look at the latest numbers. Here in London on the FTSE 100, down about half a percent at this hour. Although this is off of our lows. In Paris the CAC-40 off one and a half. And in Germany the DAX 30 index also off close to two percent now.

Talking of Germany, shares in a big German semiconductor company are short circuiting this morning; Infineon, reporting its seventh straight quarterly loss. The company says the fourth quarter loss came in at a whopping $970 million more than expected. The company blaming weakness in the sector, restructuring costs and write-downs associated with its stake in chipmaker Qimonda, Infineon's stock now down 25 percent.

Sacre bleu, Warren Buffett is facing a fight now with a French utility. Electricity de France is making a $4.5 billion bid for 50 percent of Constellation Energy's nuclear assets now Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway already made a $4.7 billion bid for this company for all of the company; it is a U.S. power company. Shareholders will vote on Buffett's offer later this month. But EBS says it undervalues Constellations true worth, it is a battle royale no doubt.

Let's go to Connell McShane for today's three market movers. Good morning, Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Ashley.

The Blackberry maker Research in Motion making a list this morning cutting its third quarter forecast. The company saying earnings per share are going to come in somewhere between 81 and 83 cents. The problem with that is that Wall Street is looking for 91 cents. So RIM saying a stronger dollar as well as the general economic slowdown have hurt its business and had hurt its stock plunging more than 67 percent so far this year.

Google is bracing for very difficult times. The Internet search engine giant is cutting back spending and cutting back on projects; a lot of the perks that go into being an employee at Google are apparently going by the wayside. So we'll keep an eye on Google stock down from the 700s into the 275 range on that stock here over the last year or so.

Now, we do have some breaking news this morning that we want to bring to you on mortgage applications. We don't always give you this number as it comes out but it is just being released now and what a gain in mortgage applications as mortgage rates come down.

In fact, according to the Mortgage Banker's Association, this is the biggest gain they have ever seen, in record. It is just in this morning. An increase has been reported in refinancing activity; that is a very, very big increase. Overall we're talking about re-fi's being up percentage terms at least by 200 percent here over the same -- over the last week and the overall market index increasing 112 percent according to the MBA which is just out with these numbers.

Again, it's their largest rise on record Alexis, the mortgage applications with the drop we've seen in mortgage rates apparently more people going out and refinancing their mortgages and getting new mortgages all together. So that's an interesting stat that's just in.

Those are the three market movers and it's back over to you in the studio.

GLICK: All right, I love that stat. I'm trying to refinance my mortgage too, Connell, just not getting the phone call back.

MCSHANE: Get in there.

GLICK: But we'll talk about that later.

All right, Detroit's big three automakers presented recovery plans to Congress late yesterday, and the pitch has become more dramatic as General Motors and Chrysler now say they are on the verge of a collapse by month's end unless they get the money from the government they need right now.

For more on what the plans say, Fox Business's Rich Edson joins us this morning from Washington, D.C. with more of the details. Good morning Rich.

RICH EDSON, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi good morning, Alexis. When these guys were up on Capitol Hill a couple of weeks ago and they were asking for $25 billion, it wasn't all that convincing that $25 billion was all that they needed especially when Congressmen were asking them to basically add up and individually separate how much they would need out of that $25 billion.

Two car companies went first and when the third went, they really couldn't answer to bring to that $25 billion number. Eventually they got there. And then they said ok we do need only 25 billion. But today that number has been just blown out of the water; $34 billion is potentially what these guys say they are going to need over the next year from the federal government.

The biggest coming from GM, $18 billion they say they are going to need at least $12 billion to operate next year, $4 billion immediately of that $12 billion, and if the economy gets worse, they say they are going to need an extra $6 billion. That goes to $18 billion for next year.

Ford is asking for $9 billion. Though it says it does not need it right away, it would like a $9 billion line of credit from the government.

And Chrysler is saying that it wants $7 billion in loans from the federal government.

So the proposals are in. They are on Capitol Hill. And one analyst said it's time to get to legislative work. Here's what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEAN WEST, GROUP ANALYST: The last round was a nice bit of political theater. The Democrats got that out of the way. They don't look like they are soft on automakers anymore. They played tough. They wouldn't have continued to keep the session open if they weren't planning on actually funding something.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: All right, here the concessions all three CEOs say they will take only a dollar in compensation if they get the loans. Chrysler is talking about an electric drive model in 2010. Ford says its 2015 fleet will be 36 percent more efficient than the models it offered in 2005. GM is giving corporate jets, they're giving them up. Ford is selling its jets and they are all driving to Washington, D.C. this time around; big difference from last time.

They're asking for billions of dollars, and they're also offering warrants in exchange for those billions. As far as the differences are concerned, Ford says it can turn a profit by 2011 or at least break even by that year. Chrysler is in merger talks. That really separates them. They are still looking for a partner.

And GM will focus its U.S. branding to Chevy, Buick, GMC and Cadillac. Pontiac is going to stay more of a niche brand. Rick Wagoner says GM is looking hard at all its other names and they can possibly contract them.

But Alexis as you know, when GM got rid of Oldsmobile a couple of years ago, it was a lengthy process, it was an expensive process. It cost them more than a million bucks, a billion bucks excuse me, back to you.

GLICK: Yes, I was going to say, it was a little bit more than that. All right, Rich Edson thank you so much, for bringing us up to date on all of that because wow it is complicated.

Well, as lawmakers debate that total of $34 billion that Rich Edson just talked about, automakers say they need the money to speed up production of new energy saving vehicles.

Now, based on yesterday's sales figures, no one is buying their current crop of cars. Get this, Chrysler sales were down 47 percent. GM was down 41. Ford down 31. Now, if GM survives it is betting big on the Volt, an electric car that has been rushed into production and will hit show rooms ideally within 18 months.

Here to discuss if the $40,000 Volt can save GM is Michael Duoba, he is the mechanical engineer at the Center for Transportation Research Energy Systems Division. And John Grisma is the chief insights officer for Young and Rubican Brands. He is also the author of "The Brand Bubble: The looming crisis in brand value and how to avoid it."

Welcome, gentlemen, thanks for being here.

MICHAEL DUOBA, CENTER FOR TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH: Thanks, Alexis.

GLICK: Michael, let me start with you. GM has been talking about this Volt. In fact the vice chairman sort of staked his career on it. He's been incredibly well known in the industry for the kind of cars he's developed. What do you make of whether or not GM could be successful with this car?

DUOBA: Well, I think that the Chevy Volt is a pretty exciting car. I think Bob Lutz is kind of the John F. Kennedy saying that he's going to go to the moon and end of the decade. And I think GM is kind of staking their brand on taking this car to the next level and perhaps dethroning the Prius as being the ultimate environmental car.

GLICK: John, there's some big differences between how people look at a car like the Toyota Prius and how they're trying to market this GM's Volt car here. Tell me what the differences are and why this is so important in their ability to sell this car.

JOHN GRISMA, CHIEF INSIGHTS OFFICER FOR YOUNG AND RUBICAN BRANDS: Absolutely. I think first and most importantly you have to look at GM is looking at this strategy clearly to improve its overall corporate image. And if you look back at some of the studies we've got actually seen there was a halo effect on the Toyota Prius meaning that there was actually moving across the board. You saw the SUVs and the trucks actually improving their perceptions of fuel efficiency just on the basis of having this one product in the line.

So clearly that's important from a perspective. But I think we have to slow down a little bit and really focus on what is the essence of this car? Will it really make an impact in the marketplace?

I think you've got to look at the fact that it is essentially they are talking 10,000 cars in what 2011. You're talking $30,000 at a price point a lot of questions it just loses with consumers.

GLICK: Yes and right now the price tag we're hearing is more like $40,000 but there's some vagary around it because it's still a long ways away.

But John, part of the issue here, you are a brand expert, and you've been watching what's been happening to the quality and the franchise behind the GM name. What has been happening and why is that contributing sort to the lack of, I guess, belief that this company can turn the story around?

GRISMA: You know, one of the things we wrote about in our book was the concept that consumers are actually acting more and more like shareholders, like investors. They are actually looking into the future for their expectations of brands.

And when we look at GM in the context of brand asset value which is our consumer brand database we have seen decline in trust, decline in differentiation, a decline in sort of perceived quality. This isn't necessarily fair because they are making some great products and the critics have actually -- the car critic really praised recent brands like the Cadillac, GTS, as well as the Saturn Aura.

So in that context I think what GM is trying to do is clearly get on board with green. I think all the big three automakers were behind a little bit in this in the 90s. They're trying to practice the sense of humility as well as sustainability. I mean I think if also if you step back and you look at GM, they pulled out of the Super Bowl this year, a very high- profile venue, $three million for a 30 second spot. They have ended their relationship with Tiger Woods which was a long time spokesperson. So I think they're trying to kind of be a little bit less flashy, a little bit more demure and try to get aligned with the administration's priorities.

GLICK: Michael, when you talk about the quality of this car or what it might do to turn GM's business around, they are sort of staking their future on it, who is going to buy this car?

DOUBA: That's a very good question. And I think that anyone can buy the car if you have a place to plug in. So there is a concern about the infrastructure involved you have to plug the car in every night as you would plug in your cell phone. So it is kind of a new paradigm of what we do with our car and how we use it.

But I think you know people who live in the suburbs who can drive enough miles to displace all the fuel that the vehicle promises to displace can buy the car.

GLICK: And are you concerned at all Michael about the price point? I mean I know we're looking out a couple of years from now, but on the other hand, you know, they are kind of staking their future on it, so it is kind of important.

DUOBA: Yes, I mean the price is -- it might be a little bit out of the reach of the average buyer, but it's -- they're not going to make money -- GM's is not going to make money on this product, so it is matter of just having enough, enough sales that they can show it's a strong product.

GLICK: John, what do you think?

GRISMA: I think that's the real key issue. I think you have to look at the infrastructure issues. You're talking about a $30,000 car. You're talking about perhaps urban environments because it's got a 40 miles range. How do you set up the infrastructure to basically plug in cars? How do you deal with that in New York? How do you deal with that in Boston?

Now, I think that these technologies will follow this car and it is an exciting thing but I think GM has to step back and think this isn't necessarily the one single silver bullet. They were successful in the past with the Corvette but let's look at this in the long-term plans for what they are going to do to roll out more sustainable vehicles.

GLICK: The one thing that you mentioned earlier is you said humility and sustainability. I presume that the combination of those two things is what they need to demonstrate to Congress later this week that they have both of those things.

You mentioned pulling back from the Super Bowl and a couple other moves that they've made but how do they bring about sustainability if they've now come to the well and said we need an additional $6 billion this after just testifying two weeks ago?

GRISMA: Yes, I mean first of all you've seen them out of their corporate jets and into their hybrids going to Capitol Hill. But I also think it's important to really look at how do they align with the administration's priorities? How do they align now with the Uber shareholders which is the taxpayers right? If GM is dealing with taxpayer money?

So I think in that context, what they have to do is prove their long-term sustainability, their ability to actually get in line with where Americans want to go, lessen their dependence on foreign oil and focus on really marketing this car in the context of where GM and Ford and Chrysler where are they're going in the future.

GLICK: It's interesting because we're going to talk to one of the top executives at Anheuser-Busch this morning and there used to be a concept here called made in America and we used to be excited about that and somehow we've got to turn this philosophy around because we're not very excited about it right now when it concerns the automakers.

All right, John and Michael, thank you guys so much. I appreciate it.

All right, coming up the newly formed Anheuser-Busch Inbev brought the largest European and American brewers together. After the break we're going to have an exclusive interview with the president of the Anheuser- Busch division to talk about the transition.

And then for all you Victoria's Secret lovers out there, Victoria's Secret angels are hitting the runway to revive sales this holiday season. We're going to have another exclusive interview with their CEO in just a little bit. You won't want to miss it. I promise.

GLICK: Newly formed Anheuser-Busch Inbev brought the largest European and American brewers together. Here to talk about the transition and the future of the famous Anheuser-Busch Clydesdale Horses, Anheuser-Busch President, David Peacock joins us now in a Fox Business Exclusive.

Good morning, great to see you.

DAVID PEACOCK, ANHEUSER-BUSCH PRESIDENT: Good to see you again Alexis.

GLICK: It is the first time that I'm talking to you live in person.

PEACOCK: That's right.

GLICK: Since the deal, walk me through, how has the transition been?

PEACOCK: It's been good. You know I tell you, we've been very impressed with the people from Inbev. And I think there's a lot of commonality on how we approach the business and just how we work. And I've got to say it's been a very collaborative effort.

GLICK: And I said to you when you walked in, I imagine that this has required a lot of traveling, a lot of getting to know each other and also a lot of calming people's fears because the transition, a change of this magnitude is pretty big for one of the largest independent private companies -- I mean public but owned by a family.

PEACOCK: Right.

GLICK: What has that been like addressing their concerns?

PEACOCK: I think you just have to be honest with people and be up front and just make sure they understand that the best interests of the organization are always top of mind. And that we are committed to treating everybody with great respect. And the organization, our performance has been great so I give them the big thumbs up on the effort that they have shown during all these uncertainty.

GLICK: Anheuser-Busch obviously is an iconic brand and a lot of people were concerned about the concept that an iconic brand going to a European company. How will the brand change or will we not see a lot of changes at least here in the United States?

PEACOCK: I think the things that work and the things that matter won't change. You know the heirs of our company will never change, the brand Budweiser is such a part of our company. And saw it when you came to see us, we don't have Anheuser-Busch on the top of our building, we have Budweiser. And that's what people buy and that's what people believe in. And that's what not going to change.

And the Clydesdales, the book you're holding, the Clydesdales aren't going to change. They are going to continue to graze in the pastures in mid- Missouri where their new farm is where we moved them a couple weeks ago. And they are going to be continued to be housed on the campus.

GLICK: We just showed a copy of this, and I have it in my hand it's called "The Great American Tradition." As a matter of fact, when I went down to St. Louis to visit you guys, I was there for the 75th anniversary of the Clydesdales.

PEACOCK: Right.

GLICK: And what's the meaning behind this? Tell people about this. This is part of the tradition of the company.

PEACOCK: The story was back in when prohibition was repealed 1933, August Busch Jr. wanted to show his father some respect and commemorate the moment. And they offered an eight horse hitch to deliver the first beer to the governor Al Smith, I think governor or mayor of New York and then FDR in Washington, D.C.

And they've just been a part of our heritage ever since then. And they represent strength, power, quality, beauty, all the great things that we think are synonymous with America and are synonymous with our brand Budweiser.

GLICK: One of the things that's also synonymous with your brand is huge advertising in the Super Bowl. And you are going ahead with some huge spots. Tell me a little bit about that, and why you've continued along with the investment because as you and I both know Inbev is known for cost- cutting.

PEACOCK: Yes, but it is a knock they don't deserve. I mean, if you look at their third quarter, they actually had an increase in marketing and selling up about 12 percent. So they will invest behind brands. We're going to have actually nine commercials in the Super Bowl this year, and about half of them will be dedicated to the Clydesdales.

And we've got some really nice spots on the horizon and one I think especially that just wrapped up last week that I think could be the winner hopefully.

GLICK: Oh, I like that.

Now, one of the things you guys have done is you've always invested a lot in sports, sports across the globe.

PEACOCK: Right.

GLICK: And had some huge partnerships with some of the biggest sports in the industry. Will you continue to have those partnerships? Will you, you know, readdress them? You know, where does that stand?

PEACOCK: Sports is a big part of our DNA. Last night we had an event where we invited a lot of the New York media and sports community in for a happy hour and told all those folks from ESPN and the different teams, we're still there. We are still a big part of what you do, and you are still a big part of reaching our consumers in the proper way.

GLICK: Let's talk a little bit about financials because the stock has been very turbulent, and it's been a difficult economy. One of the things I said to you in the very beginning that I didn't realize about the deal and I was pretty much in the know about this I didn't necessarily understand that there was a six-month bridge loan that Inbev used which was part of financing this deal.

PEACOCK: Right.

GLICK: They have now announced this they are going to go -- that they are going to go out there through a rights offering and raise funds in the marketplace. It really hurt the stock. First day it was announced, the stock was down 13 percent. Why are you doing this and what do you want shareholders to know?

PEACOCK: I think most important is the intrinsic value of the deal is still there. It is a tough market, but combining these two great companies and the growth opportunities and the expansion of the brand Budweiser, which is a big part of this globally still have merit. And I think at the end of the day, from what we have seen, if you've got a combination that makes sense, and there's opportunity for growth, you're going to see the financials fall into place.

So we're not too worried about what we have seen out in the marketplace. It's like anything else, when you have a good idea and two companies should come together, then I think at the end of the day the financial community and the markets will respond positively.

GLICK: Even though it is dilutive to shareholders right now because this rights offerings is going to be in existence now for a two-week period, over the long haul you think you will make up for it with growth and opportunities?

PEACOCK: Yes, the synergies we talked about are still there. We still have visibility to them. All the reasons why it made sense for these companies to come together are still there.

GLICK: you and I have talked in the past about beverage sales here in the United States. And the numbers have been very small increases, low single digit percentage gains, but that there are tremendous opportunities still in emerging economies. How much of those opportunities have changed because we are now in a much more difficult global environment, or will you still look to get more penetration?

PEACOCK: Oh, definitely. I think brand Budweiser has a lot of opportunity in the emerging markets. The beer industry so far in the U.S. has been very good. It probably will come in just under one percent growth which for us is good, and it is very resilient in this kind of time.

Recessions are short-term. This is a long-term deal. We are going to be in business a long time. We have been in business a long time. And I think that's the long-term view we are going to continue to take.

GLICK: One last question, China. China has said you guys have a big stake in a Chinese brewer as does Inbev. They have capped the stake. They have said no more acquisitions of any other brewers in China, no percentage stakes. What does that mean to your business model, are you concerned about that?

PEACOCK: No, I think we have got a very good model in China, and we have really created the premium segment with Budweiser years ago. And recently just this year we rolled out to over 100 markets where we hadn't sold before.

What's interesting about China is you have constant geographic expansion opportunities because it's just so vast. And it is amazing to me still when you can see a city in China that may be 20th in size and there's still six million people, and you may not have even really penetrated that market. So we have a lot of growth opportunities there and in combining the two companies that we've got now with some of the brands like Harbin and some of the brands that Inbev has.

And that really is the legacy of Blockbuster. Blockbuster was never really about video rentals. It was always about convenient access to media entertainment.

So the key is for us to transcend all of the various channels to keep up with technology and to provide our customers with the most convenient access wherever it is, even on your mobile phone.

GLICK: So I understand you are working on a deal here with Microsoft in terms of how to get the technology and the software so that we can get it on our mobile devices, and one of the things you are doing right now is testing it on kiosks and the ability for us perhaps to travel in an airport and upload it at some point in the future. Where is that going?

KEYES: Well, the key with the digital technology is that it's a wonderful thing. It allows so much flexibility with content, and yet, it seems that everyone is trying to get content on their big screen TV. Bandwidth in the United States is going to take some time to catch up to this demand because the file size for movies is actually very large.

So in the interim, in the next five years or 10 years, there are many other ways to deliver digital content. We are trying out some kiosks in stores, for example, so instead of taking an hour, hour-and-a-half to load a movie, you can load it in 30 seconds or 60 seconds right directly onto a portable device and have the convenience and flexibility of digital content in a portable fashion.

GLICK: You know, there are a lot of people who look at the video game industry, as I said to you yesterday, I spoke to an executive at Xbox, and I know they have a relationship with Netflix, but they look at that industry as a place which is experiencing unusual growth in a very difficult economy, and they are experiencing it year-over-year.

What kind of things are you trying to do perhaps to maybe address that audience, that demo which is a tremendous demo by doing partnerships like what Netflix and Xbox are doing together?

KEYES: We are -- again, it is very early, the idea of digital content directly to the home through game consoles or set-top boxes, very, very early in its development. Yes, we just released just a week ago a deal with a company called 2Wire, that's a large provider of these boxes and this technology to deliver content directly to the television, so now you can get Blockbuster on demand.

We have several thousand movies, new releases available from the ease of pulling up video-on-demand from your couch. And this is just another step. Again, very early.

GLICK: So who will sell those boxes? I mean, if 2Wire is a company that makes them, like, would I be able to get them on my set-top cable box? I mean, where will I see that come to me, the consumer?

KEYES: Today you can actually buy Blockbuster on demand online at blockbuster.com. We are selling it in a few stores just trying to test the consumer demand. That's really our objective right now. It is very early in the developmental stage.

But eventually you will find that this capability is baked not only into your cable box, but directly into your television set. In fact, we announced a deal with Intel not too long ago where their new chip for their Internet-ready television set in the next couple of years will include a widget that allows you to pull up the Blockbuster icon right there on your television set and have immediate access to all of your favorite movies.

GLICK: OK. So let's just take that example and let's just assume that for the sake of argument you live here in a place like New York City, you have Time Warner Cable. So I have Time Warner Cable and I have now just purchased this Internet television. Time Warner offers pay-per-view events, on demand events, how is it that I'm going to go to you as opposed to going to my cable operator who has been wired into my home?

KEYES: Well, today Blockbuster really owns that entertainment customer, particularly the customer for movies. And so our job is to make it a nice smooth transition for that customer to move over to these other services. And that's why we're leading now with Blockbuster on demand.

Eventually the cable companies will want to offer their customers various services. We will all have unique content. We will all have proprietary and exclusive content, and that will keep Blockbuster, the brand, relevant for the consumer.

GLICK: You know, one of the things I said yesterday to this executive at Xbox is I said, listen, you know, when we're on that console and they show the list of Netflix movies, they tend to be outdated, frankly. They're not the kind of movies, I'm sorry to say, that I want to see in today's world.

How do you make sure that you are delivering the newest, most credible content on any device right now so that it makes me want to do it? And if iPhone is doing something similar, why would I go with one of the devices that you have in a relationship with Microsoft as opposed to everybody carrying around that iPhone or that iPod?

KEYES: Well, first of all, you won't have that problem with Blockbuster. People have come to know and trust Blockbuster for the newest releases, the latest releases. Our Blockbuster on demand will have new releases. It is very different from the Netflix offering, as an example, which is a unique product, a very good product, but it is a subscription product.

And by nature, subscription content delivered digitally will be a little bit older content. It will be more in the pay TV window or two or three years older on average than the new releases that you can find available on Blockbuster.

So this is an opportunity for us. And as we go forward, our key competitive advantage will be to make it easy, convenient for the customer, and to have the best content available, the newest releases, exclusive content only available at Blockbuster.

GLICK: All right. James Keyes, sounds terrific. Come back, join us again, particularly as you put some of these plans in place. I want to see some of these devices and learn a little bit more about it.

KEYES: Well, thanks, great to be here.

GLICK: Great to have you.

All right, guys. We will be right back in just a moment with the "1 Thing You Should Know." Unfortunately, the one thing you should know right now is the market is pretty much at the low of the day. We are down 140 -- 156 points right now. The S&P down 2 percent, the Nasdaq down 2.25 percent. Some of this of course on the heels of those jobs numbers this morning. We will be right back.

GLICK: All right. Now it is time for the "1 Thing You Should Know. We get started with Ashley Webster in London.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, you know what, Alexis? I was looking at all this miserable news that's coming about in the U.K. and the Eurozone, I thought, well, I will do this story. It's kind of interesting.

But there is quite a lot of snow around the U.K. and there's some blizzards forecast for tonight in the northern part of the country. So that means the odds of it snowing in London on Christmas Day now down to 11 to 4. It was 7 to 1.

You know, we bet on anything in the U.K. The odds are now down that a snow flake will fall on the London weather center on Christmas Day is now down to 11 to 4. I may take that bet.

GLICK: Wow, yes. Wouldn't it be great to have a white Christmas? We don't have enough white Christmases, at least here in New York. I'm sure for you in California it rarely ever happens. When you were growing up, did they do -- like I heard some families would bring in like the fake snow?

JENNA LEE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Oh, they do that, yes, absolutely. They will have like places that the kids can sled, but it will be sunny. So it never really felt like Christmas. It was always sunny.

GLICK: Yes, but now you are here.

LEE: Now I can freeze and feel...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: OK. So what's your "1 Thing"?

LEE: You know, we (INAUDIBLE) talk so much about mortgage applications and refinances being way up. And I think that after the program that was announced last week, that can't be a bad sign. And we have to take it in relative terms from the weeks before, but it can't be a bad thing.

GLICK: Yes, I like that. I actually think it is a good sign. I understand Lieberman is like, Alexis, it is only applications, but you know what? The fact that we can make homeownership more affordable or that we'll go out and refinance, personally I'm hoping to take advantage of it.

PAYNE: I think it is fantastic. My "1 Thing" though is, by the way, I think automakers, the CEOs should go on horseback to Capitol Hill.

GLICK: Maybe they should do the Clydesdales.

PAYNE: They should ride horses because, you know what, you bring back the thought of Paul Revere and how important it is for America. And also you suggest to America, you don't bail us out, everybody is going to be riding one of these.

GLICK: Yes, that's a great point. What about that "made in America." You know, we need to like be excited about "made in America" again. We need to work on them. Give them some tips.

All right, guys. We are going to go to commercial break. We are going to come back. We are going to have "The Opening Bell" coming up next. We are going to talk to a top executive in the power and energy world who can talk to us a little bit about all of this electricity grid, infrastructure building, some of the things that we have been talking about in terms of fiscal stimulus.

Stay with us. "The Opening Bell" is next. Thanks, guys.

urn:contentItem:5VNF-RFX1-F0J6-J1SR-00000-00Big advertisers rein in online spending2019-03-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisMARKETING & MEDIAPg. 35Big advertisers rein in online spendingPaul McIntyre

Australia's $8.8 billion digital advertising market could be entering a two-speed economy with blue-chip advertisers notably more tempered in their online spending versus small and medium-sized companies.

The online advertising sector grew 11.6 per cent to $8.8 billion in calendar 2018, accounting for a record 54 per cent of the total Australian advertising sector, the latest Online Advertising Expenditure report from the IAB and PwC shows.

But ad spend data from Standard Media Index (SMI), which tracks $7.2 billion in annual advertising investment from media agencies, tells a different story. Media agencies control most of the media budgets for large brand owners.

According to SMI, blue-chip advertisers increased their online spending through media agencies at half the growth rate (5.8 per cent) of the 11.6 per cent increase in the IAB-PwC report. Large advertisers spent $2.07 billion in online channels in 2018 but their 5.8 per cent increase last year is a near halving of their online spending through media agencies in 2017 (up 10.1 per cent).

SMI says blue-chip advertisers are allocating 28.5 per cent of their total advertising budgets to online channels, compared with online's 54 per cent marketshare in the IAB-PwC figures.

SMI managing director Jane Ratcliffe said the vast difference in figures was due to the IAB-PwC figures capturing spending across the SME sector. "Clearly national marketers have very different objectives to their small business counterparts," Ms Ratcliffe said. "Agencies continue to allocate the bulk of their client ad spend to television (41.3 per cent) with digital representing 28.5 per cent of all national marketer media spend."

Still, many local online publishers large and small, are not witnessing the 11.6 per cent online advertising growth rate outlined in the IAB-PwC report for 2018.

They argue the growth is going primarily to the advertising duopoly of Facebook and Google, which the World Advertising Research Centre (WARC) forecast last month would snatch 61.4 per cent of the $287.4 billion global online ad market in 2019 between them.

WARC forecasts the worldwide online advertising sector will decline 7.2 per cent in 2019, excluding Google and Facebook, but the two online giants will collectively grow 22 per cent globally this year to account for $176 billion in advertising revenues.

"If you dig deeper into the IAB numbers, you'll see all the upside is in Google and Facebook," said Bohemia Group managing director, Brett Dawson. "That's just the lay of the land now. We've got two big players with all the data, they're really easy to buy and they're bloody cheap. Others simply don't stand a chance in the current environment. Regulation might help but I don't see that happening in the near term."

Mr Dawson said more mergers and acquisitions in the Australian media sector could also help local media companies and smaller publishers compete with Google and Facebook's dominance. "We've seen News Corp and Seven get together to have a run at data and Nine's takeover of Fairfax," he said. "It doesn't get you around [lower] pricing or ease of transacting though."

IAB CEO Gai Le Roy said there were bright spots for local media in online video and editorial-style "native content" but acknowledged many local and international media groups - digital "pureplay" publishers included - had not experienced the headline 11.6 per cent online advertising growth in the IAB's report.

"It is tough for many in the market and we hear that regularly," she said. "We're trying to find new ways for diversity and sustainability in our market. It is very important a range of players survive for the future of media and the industry."

Ms Le Roy said the online advertising industry's double-digit growth was "definitely favouring players" that could "easily service a wide range of advertisers". She said the online ad market was also favouring those with "strong video offerings."

Ms Le Roy pointed to the TV industry's fast-growing broadcast video on demand (BVOD) category as an example of a growth hot spot although some TV executives said BVOD was at about half the $250 million category it should be. Overall, online video advertising grew 26.2 per cent last year to $1.4 billion, according to the IAB and PwC.

However, short-form video advertising, once predicted to be a boom for local publishers, had proven a false hope as Facebook and Google gained marketshare in the fast-growing category.

"Short-form video is completely commoditised," said one publisher who did not want to be named. "It's been gouged by Facebook and YouTube as a complete substitute. The market is overlooking the effectiveness of video advertising in professionally created content environments for price and questionable metrics. Facebook secondary crediting for a video view is zero seconds but people are still throwing money on social."

The IAB's Australian board is a challenging one for industry policy development and measurement standards. Facebook and Google both sit on the IAB board along with local publishers such as Nine, News Corp, REA, Seven West Media and Verizon Media.

Ms Le Roy said a two-speed online advertising economy, in which human-free, self-service advertising platforms offered by the big tech players had proven hugely popular with SMEs, was challenging for Australian media companies. She said the market was seeing some counter offensives from large media groups like News Corp and Nine.

"Definitely small businesses without agencies are going to self-service platforms, which is a challenge and an opportunity for media companies," she said. "We're seeing developments like Nine's Galaxy service come into play where smaller advertisers can access [advertising] inventory."

For CMO Brief's weekly newsletter edition on global and local conversations, perspectives and trends for the chief marketing officer, sign up at your.afr.com/cmo-brief/

Key pointsThe online advertising sector grew 11.6 per cent to $8.8 billion in calendar 2018.

Online spending growth rate for blue-chip advertisers nearly halved in that period.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SV2-7651-JBG7-410F-00000-00Big Baby and the triumph of corporate America2018-07-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexis NEWS ZONE CPg. 17Big Baby and the triumph of corporate America

Perspective

By Kevin Horrigan

There's Big Steel. There's Big Pharma. There's Big Tech and Big Coal and Big Banks and Big Oil. Now comes the latest major lobbying organization to throw its weight around and demonstrate the astounding hold that corporate conservatives have on all three branches of the U.S. government.

Say hello to Big Baby.

The New York Times reported that during this year's World Health Assembly in May, the U.S. delegation tried to undermine a resolution encouraging women around the world to breastfeed their babies. The assembly is the annual meeting of delegates from 194 nations to the United Nations-affiliated World Health Organization.

For decades, health experts have agreed that mother's milk is better for infants than commercial baby formulas. The resolution urged member countries to regulate the misleading marketing claims of formula manufacturers. The resolution was in no way controversial until the U.S. delegation, representing the interests of Big Baby, started stirring up trouble.

Ecuador, which was scheduled to introduce the resolution, was threatened with trade retaliation and the possible withdrawal of U.S. military aid. Other nations, fearing similar threats, backed down. Eventually the Russians, of all people, agreed to introduce the resolution, and it passed mostly unchanged.

If there's any nation the Trump administration won't mess with, it's Russia.

"We're not trying to be a hero here," a Russian delegate told the Times, "but we feel that it is wrong when a big country tries to push around some very small countries, especially on an issue that is really important for the rest of the world."

This is the sort of thing that U.S. officials used to be able to say. Today they do the bidding of corporate interests. More than three-fourths of the U.S. baby food market is controlled by three companies: Nestle USA (Gerber), Abbott Inc. (Similac) and Mead Johnson (Enfamil). All three are part of Big Baby's $47 billion a year global market, which is expected to grow 50 percent in the next three years no matter what the World Health Assembly says.

With Donald Trump in the White House, Republicans in control of Congress and a corporate majority on the Supreme Court, business has done spectacularly. But trying to persuade mothers in the Third World to mix up baby formula -- despite having no reliable supply of clean water to mix it with -- is truly perverse.

It's the apotheosis for a movement that lay dormant during the years of the New Deal and the Great Society but began to emerge in the 1970s. Movement conservatives appropriated the word "freedom" as a substitute for untrammeled greed. It was truly brilliant how they did it.

They decided that the Gilded Age had it right, and that a nation's greatness should not be measured, as Gandhi said, by how it treats its weakest members, but by how much wealth its strongest members could amass. In support of this, they interpreted the U.S. Constitution's insistence on the primacy of property rights as fixed and unchanging.

The key moment came in 1976 when the Supreme Court decided that money, a measure of property, was a protected form of free speech when spent on political contributions. The loudest voices in the public square now belong to those with the most money.

Ronald Reagan became the movement's charismatic figurehead. Social issues like guns, gays and abortion (secondary concerns to most corporate conservatives) were used to divide the old Roosevelt coalition. Dog-whistle racist appeals fomented a backlash to the civil rights movement. Conservative intellectuals -- to the extent that sophistic arguments on behalf of the privileged constitute intellectualism -- were planted in universities and courtrooms. Unions, with a big assist from certain corrupt union leaders, became a bad thing -- even though collective wealth is the only counterbalance to individual wealth.

The stock market boomed. Executive compensation exploded. Blue-collar wages flatlined. A man named Leonard Leo built an obscure organization of conservative lawyers called the Federalist Society into a powerful force for the protection of corporate interests and wedge social issues. He is chiefly responsible for picking the conservative majority on the Supreme Court -- including Brett Kavanaugh, the man Trump nominated as Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy's replacement.

"Leonard Leo was a visionary," Tom Carter, who worked as a public relations man for Leo, told The Daily Beast. "He figured out 20 years ago that conservatives had lost the culture war. Abortion, gay rights, contraception -- conservatives didn't have a chance if public opinion prevailed. So they needed to stack the courts."

Yes! Public opinion be damned. Just load up the courts with Federalist Society members and wait for the fun to begin. Steal a Supreme Court nomination. Ignore Trump's abuses as long as he supports the plutocratic agenda.

It's like taking candy from a baby. Or worse, mother's milk.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5STN-2961-DXVP-V2JM-00000-00‘Big baby’ and triumph of corporate America2018-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisCOLUMNISTS‘Big baby’ and triumph of corporate AmericaKEVIN HORRIGAN

There's "big steel." There's "big pharma." There's "big tech" and "big coal" and "big banks" and "big oil." Now comes the latest major lobbying organization to throw its weight around and demonstrate the astounding hold that corporate conservatives have on all three branches of the U.S. government.

Say hello to "big baby."

The New York Times reported that during this year's World Health Assembly in May, the U.S. delegation tried to undermine a resolution encouraging women around the world to breastfeed their babies. The assembly is the annual meeting of delegates from 194 nations to the United Nations-affiliated World Health Organization.

For decades, health experts have agreed that mother's milk is better for infants than commercial baby formulas. The resolution urged member countries to regulate the misleading marketing claims of formula manufacturers. The resolution was in no way controversial until the U.S. delegation, representing the interests of "big baby," started stirring up trouble.

Ecuador, which was scheduled to introduce the resolution, was threatened with trade retaliation and the possible withdrawal of U.S. military aid. Other nations, fearing similar threats, backed down. Eventually, the Russians, of all people, agreed to introduce the resolution and it passed mostly unchanged.

If there's any nation the Trump administration won't mess with, it's Russia.

"We're not trying to be a hero here," a Russian delegate told the Times, "but we feel that it is wrong when a big country tries to push around some very small countries, especially on an issue that is really important for the rest of the world."

This is the sort of thing U.S. officials used to be able to say. Today they do the bidding of corporate interests. More than three-fourths of the U.S. baby food market is controlled by just three companies: Nestle USA (Gerber), Abbott Inc. (Similac) and Mead Johnson (Enfamil). All three are part of big baby's $47 billion a year global market, which is expected to grow 50 percent in the next three years no matter what the World Health Assembly says.

With Donald Trump in the White House, Republicans in control of Congress and a corporate majority on the Supreme Court, business has done spectacularly. But trying to persuade mothers in the third world to mix up baby formula — despite having no reliable supply of clean water to mix it with — is truly perverse.

It's the apotheosis for a movement that lay dormant during the years of the New Deal and the Great Society but began to emerge in the 1970s. Movement conservatives appropriated the word "freedom" as a substitute for untrammeled greed. It was truly brilliant how they did it.

They decided the Gilded Age had it right, and a nation's greatness should not be measured, as Gandhi said, by how it treats its weakest members, but by how much wealth its strongest members could amass. In support of this, they interpreted the Constitution's insistence on the primacy of property rights as fixed and unchanging.

The key moment came in 1976 when the Supreme Court decided that money, a measure of property, was a protected form of free speech when spent on political contributions. The loudest voices in the public square now belong to those with the most money.

Ronald Reagan became the movement's charismatic figurehead. Social issues like guns, gays and abortion (secondary concerns to most corporate conservatives) were used to divide the old Roosevelt coalition. Dog-whistle racist appeals fomented a backlash to the civil rights movement. Conservative intellectuals — to the extent that sophistic arguments on behalf of the privileged constitute intellectualism — were planted in universities and courtrooms. Unions, with a big assist from certain corrupt union leaders, became a bad thing — even though collective wealth is the only counterbalance to individual wealth.

The stock market boomed. Executive compensation exploded. Blue-collar wages flatlined. A man named Leonard Leo built an obscure organization of conservative lawyers called the Federalist Society into a powerful force for the protection of corporate interests and wedge social issues. He is chiefly responsible for picking the conservative majority on the Supreme Court — including Brett Kavanaugh, the man Trump nominated as Justice Anthony Kennedy's replacement.

"Leonard Leo was a visionary," Tom Carter, who worked as a public relations man for Leo, told The Daily Beast. "He figured out 20 years ago that conservatives had lost the culture war. Abortion, gay rights, contraception — conservatives didn't have a chance if public opinion prevailed. So they needed to stack the courts."

Yes! Public opinion be damned. Just load up the courts with Federalist Society members and wait for the fun to begin. Steal a Supreme Court nomination. Ignore Trump's abuses as long as he supports the plutocratic agenda.

It's like taking candy from a baby. Or worse, mother's milk.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RKX-7801-JBVM-Y4B5-00000-00Big bad tech;Algy Hall looks at criticism of tech titans and rising monopolistic power from George Soros, Brookings Institute and Jonathan Ruffer2018-02-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19Big bad techAlgy Hall looks at criticism of tech titans and rising monopolistic power from George Soros, Brookings Institute and Jonathan Ruffer

When George Soros took to the podium at Davos last month, he delivered a stinging broadside to the tech titans. "Davos is a good place to announce that their days are numbered," railed the octogenarian, multi-billionaire investor. "Regulation and taxation will be their undoing and EU Competition Commissioner Vestager will be their nemesis."

Mr Soros is one of a growing number of notables calling for tech giants to be brought to heel. There are some deeply dystopian concerns occupying Mr Soros and other like-minded critics, including the prospect that "IT monopolies" could facilitate "totalitarian control the likes of which not even Aldous Huxley or George Orwell could have imagined". But from an investment perspective, perhaps the most tangible part of Mr Soros's Davos tirade was his argument that big technology companies are bad for competition and consumers, and "undermine the efficiency of the market economy".

Because "Facebook and Google effectively control over half of all internet advertising revenue", content providers have to use their platforms and "accept whatever terms they are offered" helping these big tech firms generate "exceptional profitability". In Mr Soros' view they are "near-monopoly distributors" and should be regulated as though they were public utilities with the objective of "preserving competition, innovation, and fair and open universal access".

What's more, the tech titans' control of data and their ability to use it to manipulate users for "their own commercial purposes" allows them to "use discriminatory pricing to keep for themselves more of the benefits that otherwise they would have to share with consumers".

The mounting concern about tech giants that exploit "network effects", such as the so-called FANGs - Facebook (US:FB), Amazon (US:AMZN), Netflix (US:NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (US:GOOGL) - comes at a time when a broader rethink about the role of anti-trust law appears to be under way. A recent Brookings Institute paper provides some stark numbers to illustrate the growing concentration in many industries, including IT. Indeed, the share of US GDP accounted for by Fortune 500 companies has increased from 58 per cent to 73 per cent since 1980, and whereas the top 60 companies accounted for less than a fifth of GDP in 1954, now the top 20 alone account for over a fifth.

The problem with this, according to the Brookings paper, is that increased concentration may have benefited corporate profits at the expense of wages, consumer welfare and business investment. Indeed, the paper points out that "labour and capital share have been declining simultaneously between 1984 and 2014, offset by rising profits in the non-financial corporate sector".

While the enforcement of antitrust laws experienced a shift away from broader consumer welfare and political considerations from the 1970s, the Brookings paper sees a brewing populist backlash and "recent developments on Capitol Hill [that] suggest a serious re-evaluation of the purposes and powers of antitrust law and enforcement has begun".

A key reason this debate is relevant to investors is that the rise in monopolistic corporate power may be an important factor behind elevated levels of profitability in the US and other developed markets. That means changes in antitrust laws could have a real, albeit slow and grinding, impact on equity market returns. Arguably of more immediate significance, though, is the fact the FANGs now appear clearly in many influential people's sights. Given their popularity as investments and their weighting in key US and global indices, that's significant. The issue is succinctly summed up by Jonathan Ruffer in the latest investment view from his eponymous firm.

"Two thousand years ago, stability was threatened by marauders who could overpower the local authority of a distant power. Today, those marauders take a different form: they are the corporate 'disruptors' - the Amazons, Facebooks, Twitters, Ubers which have discountenanced governments, who are unable to stop them conversing across borders, changing the way business is done, how conversations are constructed, all the while avoiding tax. In many investment climates, they would trade at low ratings - the judgement being the speed at which they could grow while conditions remain favourable, counterbalanced by the danger of their business model being de-railed by nonmarket forces. Today's market looks only at the element which is benign for the disruptors - but there will be a fight back. We are already seeing one against Uber where the authorities are increasingly imaginative in their resistance to their business model. They remain dangerous investments - remember Minister Fouquet, who overreached himself on seventeenth century France's milch cows, and who hosted a dinner for Louis XIV, and 7,000 others. Too lavish, thought the king, and Fouquet spent the next 19 years in prison, no doubt on a modest price/earnings ratio."

WHERE TO FIND THE PIECES MENTIONED ¦ George Soros Davos speech transcript, 25 January 2018: https://www.georgesoros.com/2018/01/25/remarks-delivered-atthe-world-economic-forum/¦ A policy at peace with itself: Antitrust remedies for our concentrated, uncompetitive economy, William A Galston and Clara Hendrickson, 5 January 2018:   https://www.brookings.edu/research/a-policy-at-peace-with-itselfantitrust-remedies-for-our-concentrated-uncompetitive-economy/¦ Ruffer investment review, Jonathan Ruffer, January 2018:   https://www.ruffer.co.uk/about/investment-review

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XGD-PGJ1-F03R-N1BJ-00000-00Big Banks AND Big Tech (not versus)2019-11-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBig Banks AND Big Tech (not versus)Chris M Skinner

Nov 11, 2019( The Finanser by Chris Skinner: http://thefinanser.com/ Delivered by Newstex) I've said for a while that the Big Tech giants will not become banks. Amazon and Alibaba will do a lot of bank-like activities, but they will never move into full-service banking, as in offering deposit accounts. Why won't they?

Because that's full banking activity which has all of the audit and compliance overhead that Big tech giants don't want. The average technology firm in America has five times less regulation than the average American bank, and that's a key point. Another key point is that most of the Big Tech giants have a major chunk of market focused upon banks as customers. A huge chunk of Amazon and Alibaba's cloud-based services are used by banks, and a massive amount of Google and Facebook advertising comes from financial firms. Why would you bite the hand that feeds you? But then there's another nuance that I've been thinking about and haven't seen played out until now. If I were a bank, why wouldn't I partner with the Big Tech giants and help them offer banking? If I were a bank and did that, then such a partnership would sidestep the competition and put them on the back foot. After all, if Amazon partnered with my bank to offer banking then they wouldn't need my competition. I would have the upper hand and my competition would be left for dust. Well, finally, that's happened. If you didn't see it last week, JPMorgan announced[1] that they had forged partnerships with Amazon and Airbnb to help them offer bank services. It's basically an ewallet that technology companies can give to their customers to use as virtual bank accounts. The JPMorgan product gives 'tech companies the ability to provide millions of customers virtual bank accounts and to offer perks such as car loans or discounts on home rentals to those who keep money stashed there. The more customers use their virtual accounts to pay for services, the less the companies would have to spend on payment-processing fees to third parties such as JPMorgan.' Fantastic. However, that's not the end of the game as JPMorgan has not yet gained all the partners they hope. It's targeting the biggest e-commerce and gig economy companies such as Amazon, Uber, Airbnb and eBay, but it has not yet signed them all up and, even if they did, there may be wiggle room to see these companies choose alternative providers over time. So, is this how it all plays out? Does this mean that the battle for the future of banking will be between Big Banks vying for the best partnerships with Big Tech? In short, yes. That's exactly what I see happening. Big banks need to have the biggest platforms as partners. The platforms don't want to be big banks. They need to stick to their knitting. But Big Tech needs to offer payments, loans, credit, savings and financial services and the best way for them to do that is to find a big bank partner whose products they can white label. That is happening folks. JPMorgan's ewallet announcement is exactly this. Therefore, expect lots of moves amongst the big bank crowd to forge partnerships with the Big Tech giants over the next decade. That's where the battleground for the consumer lies and exactly where banks will focus.Postnote: this is kind of a follow-up to last week's Big Banks versus Big Tech[2] post Posted on: November 11, 2019 [ 1]: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-11-06/jpmorgan-has-a-plan-to-help-amazon-airbnb-look-more-like-banks [ 2]:   https://thefinanser.com/2019/11/big-banks-versus-big-tech-its-all-about-the-money.html/

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKV-6YV1-DXH2-62SR-00000-00Big Banks in Focus; Border Crisis; Interview with Senator James Lankford (R) Oklahoma; Jon Stewart Blasts Senator Paul Rand and Sen. Mike Lee Over 9/11 Victims Fund Delay; Drug Deaths Decline; Instagram Expands Hidden 'Like' Test; Oscar Mayer Offers Fans Stay in Wienermobile; Netflix Sees Underwhelming Growth as Competitors Prep New Services; Facebook Appears Before House Committee Regarding Cryptocurrency "Libra"2019-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Tom Bevan, Tim Griffin, Tom Brown, James LankfordNEWSFinancial071802cb.231Big Banks in Focus; Border Crisis; Interview with Senator James Lankford (R) Oklahoma; Jon Stewart Blasts Senator Paul Rand and Sen. Mike Lee Over 9/11 Victims Fund Delay; Drug Deaths Decline; Instagram Expands Hidden 'Like' Test; Oscar Mayer Offers Fans Stay in Wienermobile; Netflix Sees Underwhelming Growth as Competitors Prep New Services; Facebook Appears Before House Committee Regarding Cryptocurrency "Libra"Maria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Jackie DeAngelis, Lauren Simonetti

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, July 18th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Earnings are in focus once again. Morgan Stanley is due out in any moment right now. The estimate calls for a profit of $1.14 a share on revenue of $9.99 billion. The stock is up going into the numbers, up about 1 percent. We will bring you those numbers and full analysis coming up.

Microsoft, one name to watch this morning after the bell. This as the technology giant warns of hundreds of attempted election related hacks from other countries.

We're also watching Netflix, the streaming giant takes a big hit after reporting a loss of U.S. subscribers and slow growth overseas. The stock down better than 11 percent this morning.

While we're speaking future are lower -- take a look at futures this morning, indicating a decline of the start of trading of about 17 points on the Dow, down almost a point on the S&P, and down 10 points on the Nasdaq. Stocks were down yesterday, of course, as earnings season exposed some weakness in growth outlooks for some companies.

Industrial and energy stocks the biggest drags. There's some worry that the economy and profits will slow down second half of the year. The DowIndustrials were down 116 points yesterday, the Nasdaq was lower by 37.

Global markets this morning look like this. European indices are mixed. FT 100 down 21, CAC 40 is up 13, and the DAX index in Germany lower by 48.

In Asia overnight, trade fears continuing to drive markets down. Worst performer was Japan. Nikkei average down about 2 percent. Exports fell for the seventh month in a row in Japan, driven by a sharp decline in shipments of chip making tools and automobile parts to China.

Border crisis -- 2,000 additional troops headed to the southern border. We have the very latest this morning.

Budget Battle, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is warning a deal to raise the debt ceiling is needed by tomorrow. Deadline is looming. We're looking at where we could be headed from here as the clock is ticking this morning.

Plus, lay away for teen, find out the retailer that is going after cash- strapped teens and millennials with a buy now, pay later approach.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Networks' Jackie DeAngelis, Real Clear Politics co-founder and president Tom Bevin; and PWC partner Mitch Roschelle. Great to see everybody this morning.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good MORNING. Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: We're waiting on Morgan Stanley earnings. Your take on what the banking sector has looked like so far? It's been a mixed story, I guess. But what's your take in terms of what you're seeing? Bank of America yesterday.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: I think very strong from an economic perspective because the consumers have been driving the earnings of all the banks that have been reporting. And the consumer is anywhere from two- thirds to 75 percent of the economic expansion that we're seeing in the U.S.

So I think that bodes well for the economy. May not bode well for the banks because some of the pieces of their business are falling because the yield curve is not exactly cooperative for the banking industry. But I think it's good for the economy.

BARTIROMO: And then what happens when the fed cuts rates in two weeks. We're going to talk with Tom Brown really -- a student of the banks for many, many years coming up this morning.

And joining us this morning, my exclusive interview coming up with Kentucky Senator and Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell. Home Depot co-founder and NYU Ken Langone Health board of trustees member Ken Langone is here on healthcare in America. And the Senator from Oklahoma James Lankford.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big program coming up here.

Joining us right now is Second Curve Capital CEO Tom Brown. And Tom -- it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks for being here.

TOM BROWN, CEO, SECOND CURVE CAPITAL: Nice to see you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: How would you characterize the banks so far in this quarter?

BROWN: I think it's a pretty good characterization. So very strong results. If you think about you're talking about 15 to 18 percent returns on equity.

Bank of America yesterday, 17 percent earnings per share growth. So I think the industry and the big banks in particular are doing very well.

BARTIROMO: You called B of A a long time ago. You've been liking that stock, I know that. It's a big week for all the banks obviously we had JP Morgan Chase, you mentioned Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Citigroup -- all helping to lift the sector after beating the estimates on the top and the bottom line.

What about the second half? We've got the Federal Reserve going to cut rates in two weeks. What does that do to all of this?

BROWN: Earnings go down. Not down on an absolute basis but certainly the flatter yield curve and lower interest rates on an absolute basis are going to be tougher for net interest margins and for them to grow their earnings per share.

ROSCHELLE: If you're running one of those banks and you know that the yield curve is flat, if not slightly inverted, and rates are going to come down potentially, how do you adjust the business model a little bit for the rest of the year to try to pick up revenue or earnings in other parts of the business?

BROWN: You do what bank of New York did yesterday and what Brian Moynihan said yesterday which is we're going to be tighter on expenses. But there really are no options.

Now, a negative inverted yield curve is not normal. So it will too change and that's what I think they have to do is just wait it out until we get back to a more normal environment.

DEANGELIS: Tom -- you look at some of the big banks, the stock prices year-to-date: Citigroup 36 percent increase, Goldman Sachs 27 percent, B of A 18 percent -- I'm just wondering if you feel like these stocks are a little overdone here even though we're seeing strong earnings.

BROWN: Heck no.

BARTIROMO: Bring it on. You want more.

They had the worst December that they've ever experienced. So you know, the book ends are very important. So we're coming off of a period where the stocks peaked in about May of last year relative to the market on an absolute basis. So we're just beginning to recover.

On average, you're paying 17 times earnings for a company in the S&P 500. And for a large bank, you're paying 8 to 11 times earnings. So still looks to me like --

BARTIROMO: Why? Why are they trading at such a discount to the rest of the market then?

BROWN: I think -- there's so much concern about an inverted yield curve and a recession. So a recession brings higher losses. And that's the biggest swing factor for bank earnings is a higher loan loss provision. Just don't see that. No signs on my radar screen.

MITCHELLE: Right. No one talks about it in any of the earnings releases. In fact, delinquencies and some of the banks were better than expected.

BROWN: Right, right.

BARTIROMO: Are you saying you don't expect a recession?

BROWN: No. I think the only thing that shows you or would scare you about a possible recession is the inverted yield curve. But besides that, I mean again, you mentioned the strength of the consumer, it's incredible with employment being as strong as it is and incomes being -- going up and the balance sheets are better than we've ever seen. So it's a strong environment for the consumer.

BARTIROMO: When you look at a company like Morgan Stanley which we're waiting on coming out with earnings any second here, wealth management has been real important. They've done a great job in terms of gathering assets. Is that where the growth in the business is, wealth management? How do you characterize this move?

I mean UBS was really the first to really bone up on wealth management and gain assets.

BROWN: Yes. If you think about it, Maria -- 10 years ago and how much Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley have changed, it's really incredible. Goldman Sachs spending a $1.3 billion to become a retail bank. And Morgan Stanley really converting the company into more of an asset manager than an investment bank. It's really been remarkable.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And he's done a great job with that, certainly when you compare to where the CEO was in the throes of the recession, the worst financial crisis we've seen.

So do you expect a good number from Morgan? What are you expecting in terms of the most important issues to look at once the number hits the tape.

BROWN: I think what most people will be focused on is that revenue number that you mentioned, just under $10 billion. I think it would be nice to see it over $10 billion. But there's a lot of just -- the short-term swing factors are going to take that one way or the other.

BARTIROMO: So any stocks that you want to own right here? I know you like Bank of -- you still like B of A.

BROWN: Still like b of a. Still like Citi. There's an incredible number, there's eight large banks where the combination of their trailing 12-month dividend yield, plus the amount that they're reducing their capital stock is over 9 percent and they're trading at less than one and-a-half times tangible book value. So it's an industry that is generating a lot of excess capital. They're using it to return to shareholders and the valuations of the companies overall are low and particularly relative to the market.

MITCHELLE: Tom, we were talking about the big banks but how about the regional banks. They sort of get lost in the headlines during earnings season. Is there anything in the regional banks that's really interesting to you?

BROWN: Sure. I love what I would call niche regional banks. We had one last night that reported their earnings called -- a company called Tri- State Capital. And what they do is they have no branches. They're just a business lender on one side and they make personal loans on the other side. A company that's growing 15 to 25 percent a year on the bottom line.

So there are, you know, still 5,200 banks in this country and what I love about being an analyst for 30 years is that there's always a great story out there. You can always find a good, well-managed company that's doing something different.

BARTIROMO: And there could be a deal in a lot of those regionals, right? I mean, you know, these companies are not facing the cap that the largest are in terms of acquiring more deposits.

BROWN: Well, you were talking about that yesterday.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I was, with Anton Schutz. And Anton thinks that we're going to see a lot of deals in the small and regional banks. Do you think that?

BROWN: You can always say yes because there's always 200 deals a year.

BARTIROMO: There you go.

BROWN: I'm going to go yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Tom -- well, we hope you'll stick around. Morgan Stanley numbers are coming out. We want to get your reaction when they do. Tom -- thank you.

Tom Brown joining us there.

Coming up -- Securing the border, 2,100 troops headed to the U.S./Mexico border. Senate Homeland Security Committee member Senator James Lankford will weigh in coming up.

Then buy now, pay later -- American Eagle rolls out a lay-away plantar plan targeting its top shoppers, including millennials and young people. Details right after this. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

A deadly fire at a Japanese animation studio. Cheryl Casone with the details this morning -- Cheryl.

CASONE: At least 13 people are confirmed dead, Maria. Ten others presumed dead in the suspected case of arson. About 35 others were injured. Some of them critically. Police in japan say the man that -- the suspect that started the fire is being treated at one of the hospitals there. But there's no word yet on a motive for this attack, they feel like.

2020 election day more than a year away but Microsoft says it has already detected nearly 750 attempts to infiltrate U.S. political parties' campaigns and think tanks. Microsoft won't name the targets but they say all of them are protected by the company's service that identifies cyber threats.

There's Microsoft, a little lower in the premarket of course. That's a company that's on earnings watch for us this week.

American Eagle is helping cash-strapped consumers. The outfitter planning to offer a buy now, pay later service. Shoppers are going to be able to make a purchase, pay for it in installments. Analysts say buy now, pay later encourages shoppers to spend more money, appealing to those younger shoppers who have less of that disposable income.

Back in the day, they called it lay-away -- Maria.

The loophole in our system is if you cross the border with a child, you get into the country. So that encourages adults that want to get into the country to get their hands on a child and to be able to bring them across so they can get in the country.

That's not anything different.

That's the same thing that happened all over the world that when you're seeking asylum, you go to the next country that will accept you. That will make an enormous difference on this. If we get to the end of the fiscal year, we shouldn't hold federal workers hostage basically in this process. They don't know what their job prospect is. The American people shouldn't be able to feel it. Congress should.

At the same time, we have what's called a continuing resolution that keeps budget spending the exact same as last year but Congress can't leave. Weekends, weekdays, we're in session, no one can travel until the budget negotiations are done.

We're facing very different threats now as we have a rising China, we have a rising Iran. So we need to make sure that we are prepared to be defensive in that to say don't attack us, don't come at us because we're fully ready to defend ourselves and our country.

A stronger defense in those areas that people know that we can respond deters people from actually engaging in war in the first place. So if we show our selves weak and not ready for the battle, that encourages people to bring the battle to us.
