HIGGINS: Well, one of the things here that we see is clearly going into the presidential elections, Trump has signaled that the social media companies are going to be in the crosshairs and this is just Facebook waving a flag and inviting more opportunities for criticism and kind of picking at them. And it wasn't just Facebook on the Hill this week, as you know. Really big tech in general is under the microscope, whether it's Amazon or it's Google, Facebook.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HIGGINS: These companies are raising a lot of concerns among Democrats and Republicans for various different reasons, but uniting them in this idea of has big tech become too big.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. Well, there's a lot of scrutiny there. Tim, good to see you, thanks so much.

HIGGINS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Tim Higgins from the Journal.

Still ahead my exclusive interview with Senate Majority leader Mitch McConnell, that's next on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, July 18th.

Our top story this morning at 08:00 a.m., President Trump sounding off, he was in full campaign mode during a rally in North Carolina last night discussing the economy, the progressive Democrat squad 2020 and everything in between.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The leading voices of the Democrat Party are left wing extremists who reject everything our nation stands for.

Omar has a history of launching vicious anti-Semitic screeds.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Get her out -- get her out.

And Tlaib who used the f word to describe the presidency and your president, that's not nice, even for me.

Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60D4-XM21-DXP9-92J3-00000-00Big banks look to the cloud to accelerate digital shift2020-07-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBig banks look to the cloud to accelerate digital shiftPatrick Jenkins

As their booming share prices testify, technology companies have been brimming over with new business during the coronavirus pandemic.For ba... As their booming share prices testify, technology companies have been brimming over with new business during the coronavirus pandemic . For banks, there has been a special tech awakening: to the merits of cloud computing. After years...

As their booming share prices testify, technology companies have been brimming over with new business during the coronavirus pandemic.For ba...

As their booming share prices testify, technology companies have been brimming over with new business during the coronavirus pandemic.

For banks, there has been a special tech awakening: to the merits of cloud computing. After years of foot-dragging, many have been abandoning their cautious approach to cloud-based services and signing up with gusto to outsource their storage of data and other activities that demand high-intensity computing power.

In the past few days alone, Amazon Web Services struck a big new deal with HSBC while Google announced partnerships with Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank.

Why now? Some of the reasons are obvious. As banks come under pressure from the financial costs of lockdown — a decline in economic activity, an explosion of loan losses — they are seizing any opportunity to cut costs. Cloud services tend to be priced in ways that mean you pay for what you use, rather than committing to billions of dollars of investment upfront.

But the enthusiasm for cloud computing is not just about scrimping. Banks have been among the most enthusiastic adopters of cloud-based software and video conferencing services to facilitate working from home. Just as the pandemic hit, Microsoft completed the rollout of its Teams video service to 100,000 staff across Santander’s global banking operations, building on a cloud contract struck with the Spanish bank last year.

The pandemic is also accelerating the trend towards digital banking. Dutch group ING said this month it would close a quarter of its branches. Cloud providers are increasingly casting themselves as “digitisation partners” for the banks.

Pre-pandemic, the banking sector was more reluctant than most to move to the cloud. A Bank of England report on digital finance last year — authored by Huw van Steenis, an adviser to former governor Mark Carney — estimated that only a quarter of the activities of the largest global banks were cloud-based. 

That tally is far lower than in other sectors, though McKinsey has forecast that between 40 and 90 per cent of banks’ workloads globally could move to the cloud in a decade. Bankers believe coronavirus will accelerate that shift dramatically. An executive at one big cloud provider says: “So far it’s been high-compute intensity areas, such as risk management modelling, that have moved on to the cloud. Personally sensitive data and trading data have not moved. But we’re starting to see that change.”

Banks’ historic reluctance stems in part from their nervousness about security and privacy. But it also reflects longstanding regulatory concerns about the robustness of cloud-based services and concentration risk in the sector.

Thirty of the world’s biggest banks, deemed systemically important, are subject to regulatory capital surcharges in the name of safety. If 90 per cent of bank data moves to the cloud, how much more risky is it that three or four largely unregulated companies dominate that space? 

Over the past couple of years, though, the mood has gradually brightened. Tech giants have engaged with regulators. Their pitch to win bank business has been helped by a broader trend in cloud computing towards so-called “container technology”. This allows companies to use multiple cloud providers as back-up, switching between them in case of problems. Banks and their supervisors have also been persuaded that cloud systems, backed by vast well-financed tech companies with the most sophisticated cyber security, should be especially secure.

A step change in attitudes was evidenced by that 2019 Bank of England report. It concluded that the BoE “should embrace cloud technologies, which have matured to the point they can meet the high expectations of regulators and financial services”.

If it all sounds too good to be true, it may be. Capital One, the US bank and credit card operator, still declares in a case study advertised by Amazon Web Services: “The most important benefit of working with AWS is that we don't have to worry about building and operating the infrastructure.” But that insouciance backfired last year when it suffered a vast cloud breach exposing the personal details of more than 100m credit card customers and applicants and access to 80,000 bank accounts. An ex-AWS employee was blamed, accused of using the bank’s own web application and a firewall misconfiguration to access its data in the cloud. Legal wrangling ensued.

A different kind of privacy threat emerged in Hong Kong last week, with the big cloud companies fighting off regulatory attempts to gain access to the underlying customer data of bank clients. It remains to be seen whether hostile regulators have more or less leverage over big tech than over big banks. But given that the dominant global cloud companies are all American, mounting geopolitical tensions between the US and China, and other parts of the world, will not be helpful.

This article has been revised since original publication to clarify the alleged cause of Capital One’s data breach.

Extracts.SummaryText: ... A look at the big week ahead. Check it out. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: This week on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, tomorrow we are live in San Francisco with the biggest banker in the nation. Jamie Dimon is here. Wednesday, big tech bracing for big regulations, but stocks continue to soar. We are watching your wallet. Thursday, increasing Iranian saber rattling, bringing the U.S. to the brink of war. Senator James Lankford on the path forward. And, Friday, it is time to "Ask Maria." ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XYX-0BN1-JB20-G02N-00000-00Big Banks on Tap; Rep. Chuck Fleischmann (R-TN) is Interviewed about the Middle East Turmoil; Outrage in Iran; Bail Reform Blowback; U.S. to Stop Civilian Drone Program Over Security Threat; Labor Department Announces Changes to Joint Employment Rules; R. Riveter Employs Military Spouses Nationwide; NASA Intern Finds New Planet on His Third Day on Job2020-01-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTKen Leon, Lee Carter, Mitch Roschelle, Eugene Scalia, Cameron Cruz, Lisa Bradley, Chuck FleischmannNEWSFinancial011302cb.231Big Banks on Tap; Rep. Chuck Fleischmann (R-TN) is Interviewed about the Middle East Turmoil; Outrage in Iran; Bail Reform Blowback; U.S. to Stop Civilian Drone Program Over Security Threat; Labor Department Announces Changes to Joint Employment Rules; R. Riveter Employs Military Spouses Nationwide; NASA Intern Finds New Planet on His Third Day on JobDagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Rick Leventhal, Andrew Napolitano

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, January 13th.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

Protests erupting in Iran, now turning violent. Reports now say Iranian police are shooting ammunition and tear gas into crowds on the street. Iran denying the claims. A live report from the Middle East ahead.

We kick off a busy week on Wall Street. Investors waiting for the start of earnings season and the signing of the phase one trade deal with China. Futures are looking to the plus side to start the week higher. A 63 point gain on the Dow futures. This after stocks closed to the downside on Friday. The Dow did cross 29,000 before reversing course.

For the week, all three major market gauges were higher. The Nasdaq the standout, look at that, gaining 1.75 percent.

In Europe, markets are hovering near the flat line. We have a slight gain on the FTSE 100 in England. A little bit of red in France and Germany. And the U.K. unexpectedly shrinking the U.K. economy ahead of the key general election.

In Asia overnight, markets mostly higher. The Nikkei in Japan closed for a holiday.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi expected to deliver the articles of impeachment finally. What to expect from the Senate hearing, the Senate trial, what it means for the Democrats who will have to come off the campaign trail.

And skipping dating websites and apps. One billionaire wants to use a trip to the moon to find his perfect match. That story later in the hour.

And here to break it all down with me this morning, pollster and Maslansky and Partners and president, author of "Persuasion," Lee Carter, CFRA director of equity research, Ken Leon, and PWC Partner Mitch Roschelle.

It's been a hot hour. We've got two more. Buckle up.

And let's talk about, really quickly, we were looking at the futures here. Earnings season, Mitch, what are you guys watching?

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Well, we start with the banks tomorrow. And I think it's actually going to be surprising to the upside for the banks. They did see in the fourth quarter the yield curve steepen a little bit, which is important. A lot of M&A activity, a lot of trading volume because the market was so hot. So I think the banks probably had a good fourth quarter.

KEN LEON, DIRECTOR OF EQUITY RESEARCH, CFRA: Yes, the banks are a barometer for the U.S. economy. And it is really about the key driver, the U.S. economy. Banks also are benefiting as well. Finally interest rates are not going down. That's going to help earnings.

But it's also about the sentiment. What do these CEOs from JP Morgan, from Citigroup and Wells Fargo have to say about the outlook for 2020? We think it's going to be good, especially coming off last week with the strong jobs report.

MCDOWELL: And speaking of that, Maria Bartiromo is going to be interviewing Jamie Dimon of -- JP Morgan's CEO at the JP Morgan Healthcare Conference. It's the healthcare conference. So you'll get some insight into how healthcare and particularly pharmaceutical companies are doing.

But corporate profits are still expected to drop for the second quarter in a row. It will be the annual earnings growth will come down to the smallest in three years. But investors are still betting on what? Because you still had the S&P hitting a new all-time high on Thursday.

LEON: So I -- my take on this, you know, the Fed, at worse, is on the sidelines, but also we're seeing that it's an expansion with a low inflation. We don't have -- inflation -- if we have inflation below 2 percent, it's the expansion of the multiples. The valuations. Banks are cheap relative to the market, to the S&P 500. That's getting the attention of investors. The biggest part of the financial sector is the banks.

ROSCHELLE: Right, although the banks did do better last year than the S&P 500.

LEON: Just the fourth quarter -- and the fourth quarter was the momentum that started.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

So I -- I actually think that guidance coming from this entire earnings season is going to be the most important thing, to listen to the words of CEOs about the future, about their plans for investment and, most important, their plans for hiring because I think that the continuation of creating jobs is going to be important for 2020 going into an election cycle.

CARTER: I agree.

LEON: And and -- and also especially when you look at the quality the -- you know, of -- of the jobs numbers. And also, the middle class is growing and we're seeing an increase of households that are off subsidies from the government because of a the strong economy. That's benefiting really the consumer markets overall. This is going to be a terrific --

MCDOWELL: And I've said this, that the wage gains for the bottom earners are growing faster than even for the middle tier of Americans and even the richest Americans. And wages have risen at a 6.1 percent annual clip for workers over 25 without high school degrees. Three -- that's -- that is much, much faster than those with a college degree. It's really incredible what's happening in this country in terms of the inequality gap shrinking.

But I want to move on to our top story this hour, erupting -- protests erupting in Iran, now turning violent. Hundreds taking to the streets of Tehran over the weekend following the country's announcement it had accidentally shot down a Ukrainian aircraft last week killing all 176 people on board.

President Trump weighing in yesterday on the protests, saying this, to the leaders of Iran, do not kill your protesters. Thousands have already been killed or imprisoned by you and the world is watching. More importantly, the USA is watching. Turn your Internet back on and let reporters roam free. Stop the killing of your great Iranian people.

This as a rocket attack targeting northern Baghdad Air Base wounded four Iraqi service men. The U.S. blaming the attack on Iran-supported militias but no group has claimed responsibility.

Joining us now, Tennessee Congressman, House Appropriations Committee member, Chuck Fleischmann.

Congressman, good to see you.

REP. CHUCK FLEISCHMANN (R-TN): Good morning.

MCDOWELL: What should the U.S. do now and in the days and weeks to come?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, I think, first of all, the president and the United States are doing exactly what we need to do, monitor the situation very closely, make sure that we communicate effectively.

There's an olive branch right now out there to the Iranian people who, for decades, have lived under a radical, oppressive theocracy, which has been detrimental to Iran, detrimental to the region, detrimental to the world. And freedom always wins. And I think the people of Iran ultimately will want to be free again under a new type of government. So messaging, encouragement, and a monitoring of a very dangerous situation.

ROSCHELLE: Congressman, good morning. Mitch Roschelle.

Joining me now, Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano.

Maria Bartiromo has been warning people about this.

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And it's not just New York.

NAPOLITANO: So I have probably done thousands of bails. Typically when you're assigned bail, you sit on the bench and the police will bring in hundreds of people. You've got about five or six minutes per person. And you're basically trying to decide -- they're innocent until proven guilty. What is their criminal record? Who have they harmed? What is the evidence against them? What is the likelihood of conviction? What is the likelihood they're going to come back if -- if you -- if you give them a reasonable bail? These are all the things you have to decide on the spur of the moment.

In New York, if the crime is not one of violence, you may not give them bail, meaning, they walk out of your courtroom without anything to induce them to return.

So this bank robbery, you say to yourself, well how could a bank robber possibly be bailed out? The guy robbed four banks in one day. He didn't use a gun. And he didn't threaten violence. He used a note. And because he handed the tellers a note, it's considered a non-violent crime and, therefore, he's entitled to be set free irrespective of his -- of his record.

MCDOWELL: The governor, Governor Cuomo, is so gutless, he didn't have -- he didn't even mention this in his State of the State Address.

NAPOLITANO: Well, they're -- the -- the law is horrific.

Now, New Jersey has a bail law. There is a presumption that the person being arrested should be freed, but the judge can override the presumption on the basis of, was there violence, is there a criminal record, is the person likely to return if I don't give them bail? In New York, there is no presumption and the judges have no opportunity to override the bail.

Now, in the case of this guy who punched people in the nose, that's not because of the bail law, that's because of poor judgment on the part of the judge. You do not let a homeless person who is attacking people and has been arrested for the attack and caused injury, knocked two teeth out of this woman's mouth, you do not let that person free without bail.

MCDOWELL: Here's my prediction. You are going to see -- and we saw that police officers were directed by the Manhattan District Attorney Cy Vance - -

NAPOLITANO: Yes. Yes.

NAPOLITANO: Right.

Let's move on to jobs, in focus. The Labor Department announcing a deregulation taking on the Obama era joint employer rule.

Joint employment occurs when workers have two employers like a franchise and then the overarching company or a company using contractors.

The Obama administration had moved to dramatically expand joint employment which some estimate cost over $5 billion a year for businesses.

My next guest is out with a new op-ed in the Wall Street Journal this morning with acting White House chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney, making labor rules rational again, writing this.

By removing uncertainty for these businesses and their workers, this rule also benefits the economy more broadly. Every dollar lost by business to vague or unnecessary regulation is a dollar less for creating jobs, increasing wages, funding retirement plans or lowering prices. Smart deregulation is good for the American worker, business, families and the economy.

The co-author of that right here, U.S. Secretary of Labor, son of former U.S. Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, Eugene Scalia.

Mr. Secretary, good to see you.

EUGENE SCALIA, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF LABOR: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: I took -- I stepped on your words but tell the viewers why this rule change? Explain it and why this rule change would benefit potentially everybody in this country?

SCALIA: Yes, it's an important rule. And as you said, the joint employment is the idea that a worker can actually have two different companies that are responsible for paying minimum wage, paying overtime, keeping the records.

And that -- you know, that sometimes happens, if somebody's working at a particular worksite and the company there is closely supervising what that worker does.

But then there's another company that hired that person that determines the pay, and that oversees them too, then you have two employees that they both have to make sure everything's done right, but that's costly.

And what the Obama administration did was tried to really push out how many different circumstances. Two different companies were on the hook for all those employment responsibilities and it has to do with wage hour obligations, that's what we focus on. But during Obama administration, they were looking at union rights and that circumstance too and that can be costly.

MCDOWELL: Why did you need to do this now because there was already a National Labor Relations board action that's similar to this?

Also, that the Labor Department very early on in the Trump administration issued guidance on the joint employer rules. Why do you need to do this now?

SCALIA: Well, couple reasons. First, we administer different statutes than the National Labor Relations board which has to do with overseeing union organizing rights.

Second, we really felt we needed to bring some clarity and rationality to this area in the wake of the confusion that had risen during the last administration.

You know, the Obama administration had put out what it called a bulletin which suggested that if a company is just responsible for overseeing payroll for somebody, just processing payroll, that could be an employer too. Or if a worker does work on the premises of a company, then that company with the premises, they're the employer, just based on that.

And that's very broad and costly. So we wanted to bring clarity and roll that back so it's more sensible and less burdensome on employees.

MCDOWELL: An employer, a franchise, operator, how soon would they see the benefits of this? How soon would the broad economy see the benefits of this change?

SCALIA: Soon. March 6th is when we expect this to go into effect. It will be the law, people can -- people can rely on it.

You mentioned franchisers. You know, what this says is that you're a franchiser or -- and you want your franchisees to -- for example, have a sexual harassment policy or had other, you know, sound, fair practices, that doesn't make you an employer.

Well, if you're a contractor and you want your suppliers to be responsible stewards, just imposing that in the agreement, that doesn't make you an employer. So those companies are going to be more comfortable urging best practices by their suppliers which is going to help workers.

MCDOWELL: Let's talk about workers. On Friday, the Labor Department released its December jobs numbers and showing 145,000 jobs were created in the month of December with a 3-1/2 percent unemployment rate, that's the lowest certainly in my lifetime, in 50 years.

The jobs report also showed that women overtook men in holding the majority of U.S. jobs for the first time in a decade. Women held 50.04 percent of all U.S. jobs.

We women represent more than 77 percent of jobs in education and health services, but we're almost up to 14 percent of mining and logging jobs in this country.

What can you do as the Secretary of Labor to continue this trend and making sure women are better represented in some fields outside of maybe education and healthcare?

SCALIA: You know, part of what we can do is rules like this. You know, we've got this just extraordinary economy right now, as you say. The best we've seen in 50 years are by some measures more.

And one of the fabulous things about it is that the beneficiaries -- you know, we're seeing the lowest unemployment rate ever for African Americans, for Hispanic Americans, for adult women. So these are great outcomes, continued deregulation is one important part of that.

You know, in terms of women's participation, helping simply by enforcing the discrimination laws but also through programs like apprenticeships which can help train women to enter into professions that historically maybe they didn't, either because they didn't think it's something they could do, or they were excluded. That's been a focus of ours.

MCDOWELL: In income inequality, that gap is shrinking, that gap is narrowing because lower earners in this country, say wages for the bottom 10 percent. The Wall Street Journal editorial page wrote about this over the weekend, are rising faster than middle income Americans and faster than the highest earners in this country. So those wages are growing so much faster and even particularly for people who don't have even high school diplomas.

SCALIA: Exactly. It was a really good editorial over the weekend, you know, laying it all out. And just -- you know, one data point is during the Obama administration, the faster wage gains were among the top 10 percent of earners. We've flipped that now. The fastest wage gains are among the bottom 10 percent.

And when you look at a number of different measures of how the economy is doing, it's some people who had less opportunity historically who are some of the really big beneficiaries right now.

MCDOWELL: Great to see you.

SCALIA: Pleasure to be here.

MCDOWELL: Secretary of Labor Department, Eugene Scalia, please come back.

SCALIA: Love to.

Other winners include Joaquin Phoenix for Best Actor for "Joker" and Renee Zellweger, Best Actress for "Judy". Well, how the Golden Globes lined up? And "The Irishman" taking home the award for Best Ensemble Cast.

Oscar nominations coming out at bottom of the next hour. Mitch, I hated "The Irishman" but I've said that like a hundred time.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Yes, I mean, we're not quite sure how you feel about that one. But I did love "Once Upon A Time In Hollywood". I love most Quentin Tarantino film. But the great thing about that movie is it has the Charles Manson story buried in it.

I don't want to spoil it if you haven't seen it. But that's sort of the story within the story. The beginning's a little slow but it's a great movie.

MCDOWELL: I think this is how it's going to line up though for the Oscar nominations. I would love to see Adam Driver for "Marriage Story". He will get nominated for an Academy Award. I would love to see him win because it is that incredible.

So this guy wants to take you out of this world. A Japanese billionaire is promising the date of a lifetime, searching for a girlfriend to join him on an unforgettable voyage around the moon. His quest the subject of a new documentary program and the latest stunt by the attention grabbing entrepreneur.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: I just -- I love this story. I mean, it is like "The Bachelor" meets something, I don't even know what he's trying to accomplish here. But I guess he's trying to get fame. He's trying to get a girlfriend. Good luck with that because he sounds like he can't get a girlfriend.

MCDOWELL: Is that where we are? If you're already a multimillionaire or a billionaire but that's not enough that you need fame?

CARTER: Yes, I think that's --

MCDOWELL: You need attention. You need the hot -- the hot glow of the spotlight?

CARTER: Look, I mean, we grew up where there wasn't "The Bachelor", there wasn't reality television show. I think for now, for most people they see the opportunity, they can get out there and they can be anything.

But it doesn't matter unless people hear it, unless people see it, unless they're famous somehow, unless it's on Instagram, unless they get likes.

And so, this is of course is the next out of world version of it. And I don't think it's a good thing but that's where we're living.

MCDOWELL: I think you're also speaking to what's going on with Prince Harry and a Meghan Markle, about them wanting to get away from the royal family and then they want more attention or a different kind of attention. Like the kind that the Kardashian family gets.

CARTER: Attention they can control.

ROSCHELLE: Then they should move to L.A.

MCDOWELL: Yes but you also have to deal with paparazzi and the press in a way that you're not protected by the confines of the royal family.

KEN LEON, DIRECTOR OF EQUITY RESEARCH, CFRA: Grow your brand, it's all about brand.

MCDOWELL: Oh, gosh. Lee, brand. What brand do they have? I don't know.

And speaking of out of this world, a teenager interning at NASA discovered an unknown planet, his third day on the job. It has two stars, it is 1300 light years from Earth. Wolf Cukier, I mispronounced that, found the planet, looking through NASA's orbiting Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite. Ken?

LEON: This is an amazing story. This is a junior in high school who's able to discover something NASA couldn't. He's either a genius, but the ability to find something bigger than the sun to stars, enormously bigger with the powerful telescopes that NASA has. This is a nice story.

MCDOWELL: This is why I miss the space pro -- I miss the space program, when we were not sending astronauts into space and we're hitching rides with Russia to the International Space Station. I just think that it is so -- I encourage people, I've said this before, to watch "Apollo 11", the -- it's a documentary about the moon launch and moon landing.

ROSCHELLE: Is it Netflix?

MCDOWELL: It's -- no, I had to pay for it. I had to rent it. But it's never before seen footage from NASA and it's just inspirational, even to this day. And I think that's kind of what's been missing a little bit.

CARTER: It's a lot.

LEON: It's heroism. You know, heroism -- you know, like "Apollo 13", even when it doesn't work, Jim Lovell who --

CARTER: Well, it also gave us all a point to gather together.

ROSCHELLE: Correct.

CARTER: And support something together and watch and wonder together and we don't have that anymore.

LEON: Together and it's aspirational.

ROSCHELLE: And the Olympics don't do what the -- what the space program used to do which was to get every American to be patriotic for that moment around that event.

MCDOWELL: See, I looked up. I watched the "Apollo 11" documentary and I looked up the names of the flight directors during that mission and let me say who they are. Clifford Charlesworth, Gerald Griffin, Gene Kranz and Glynn Lunney. And I read their -- like I read Cliff Charlesworth obituary from the New York Times and they didn't do him service. So I digress because I'm a nerd.

Still ahead, Oscar's favorite movies, the Academy Award nominations out in about half an hour. We'll have them right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VFR-5F41-F0JP-W3V4-00000-00Big bank stall brings focus back to struggles of regionals2019-02-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 21Big bank stall brings focus back to struggles of regionalsRICHARD GLUYAS, FOUR PILLARS

The best part about Westpac's soft trading update yesterday was the helpful distraction provided barely half an hour later by Bank of Queensland's thumping profit downgrade.

Suddenly, the plight of the regional banks that was highlighted in Bendigo and Adelaide Bank's poor interim result a week ago again became front of mind for -investors.

The main offending item for BoQ, which has a February 28 half year, was lower non-interest income, with the net interest margin also expected to be eroded from 1.97 per cent a year ago to a range of 1.93-1.95 per cent due to funding cost pressures and price competition for new loans.

Cash earnings for the half are now expected to be $165 million-$170m, down from $182m.

BoQ stock slumped alarmingly by more than 6.3 per cent, in line with share-price swings of 5 per cent-plus for earnings transgressions.

Westpac, meanwhile, served up its first quarterly trading update since the practice was abandoned by then-chief executive Gail Kelly in 2013.

The assumption yesterday was that the market has now been "cleansed" in preparation for a sizeable bond issue in the US.

Westpac's cash earnings for the December quarter came in at $2.04 billion - higher than the $1.91bn quarterly average for the second half of 2018, or $2.05bn before remediation charges.

While the bank said its margin, excluding treasury and markets, was higher in the December quarter due to loan repricing, the downside for the market was the absence of remediation costs.

Westpac said additional charges were likely to be incurred in the second quarter.

The back-ending of the charges means a much bigger figure is now expected in the half-year result, with Credit Suisse analyst Jarrod Martin forecasting a $250m, post-tax remediation expense in the 2019 financial year.

A big chunk of that is expected to relate to fees-for-no-service charged by 1660 planners in Westpac's aligned dealer groups, included as a contingent liability in the 2018 accounts.

According to the note, the bank kept part of the ongoing advice fees paid to the dealer groups by clients since 2008, and was in the early stages of getting its head around the services that were provided, or not provided, as the case may be. It was therefore not possible to estimate potential remediation costs, and no provision had been raised.

Apart from ANZ, exposure to aligned dealer groups is the big unknown in the fees-for-no-service debacle, with Westpac chief financial officer Peter King commenting in November last year that there was "no industry approach as to how you deal with that at the moment".

"That's probably the one that we need to bottom out next year," King said. New and old in fintech After an ANZ board trip to Silicon Valley in 2013, Phil Chronican said the opaque nature of the threat from financial technology made it fundamentally different to previous waves of competition and disruption.

Chronican, who was then CEO Australia for ANZ and is now acting CEO at National Australia Bank, said fintech was not a clear and present danger, but the threat could unfold quickly in ways that "we can't yet predict".

Six years later, the risk to incumbent institutions is taking shape, with the vanguard overwhelmingly occupied by established technology companies, or "big tech".

So there we were, convinced for many years that it was the emerging, niche players in peer-to-peer lending, crowd-funding and cross-border payments that were sowing the seeds for the sector's creative destruction.

The fintech model that has evolved - with some clear exceptions in payments and credit - is a co-operative relationship between the new and the old.

This has been driven by some cold market realities, including an inability to tap low-cost funding or build the customer base that would make them a serious competitive threat to incumbents.

The truce works both ways - fintechs can operate viably without scale and unburdened by regulation, depending on their business models, while traditional players can modernise clunky processes through innovation.

That's not to say the threat has receded - far from it.

Just as Chronican warned, it's unfolded in a way that wasn't predicted, with big tech's footprint already large in financial services (see table) and its impact potentially much greater than fintech.

Companies such as Amazon, Google and Facebook, or the Chinese behemoths Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu, have a huge competitive advantage in enormous customer bases and strong brand recognition and trust.

A Financial Stability Board report also noted they can use advanced analytics and big data generated through other services such as social media.

"Combined with strong financial positions and access to low-cost capital, big-tech firms could achieve scale very quickly in fin-ancial services," the report said.

"This would be particularly true where network effects are present, such as in payments and settlements and lending." The FSB's concern is clear.

While greater competition and diversity in lending, payments, insurance, trading and other areas of financial services could create a more efficient and resilient financial system, more intense competition could also erode the profitability of incumbents.

This could have spillover effects on the stability of the system by leading to greater risk-taking in order to preserve profit margins.gluyasr@theaustralian.com.auTwitter: @Gluyasr

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XDX-WYW1-F03R-N2PP-00000-00Big Banks versus Big Tech it's all about the money2019-11-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBig Banks versus Big Tech it's all about the moneyChris M Skinner

Nov 04, 2019( The Finanser by Chris Skinner: http://thefinanser.com/ Delivered by Newstex) I've blogged for a while now about the different approaches to Big Tech in China and America. In China, Big Tech is pretty much working hand-in-hand with government to solve society's issues and police them. People in the West may not like it or understand it, but Big Brotherly Love works in China for the majority.

It's just the marginalised few, like the ethnic Uighurs and other Muslims that it doesn't work for. That's something that needs to change but, generally, China's Big Tech policy is one where government and enterprise are joined at the hip. The USA is very different. In America, Big Tech does what Big Tech wants as long as the Big Tech lobbyists can cover the cost[1]. The land of the free and home of the brave is also the maison of the millionaires. If you have money, anything can be achieved in America. Or so it seems just look at the NRA if you wonder what this means. Anyways, there's now a funding fight taking place between Big Tech and Big Banks in America, which should be fun to watch. We all know how worried banks are about Amazon, Google and Facebook moving into their space and, according to Politico[2],Facebook's launch of Libra currency has just tipped the scales. Lawmakers 'were caught off guard by Facebook's plans, and thesocial media giant has been recruiting lobbyists[3]with deep experience in financial services to help bolster its case. 'Concerns over Libra spurred the Independent Community Bankers of America, which represents smaller lenders, to join forces with Waters, a California Democrat, in calling for a moratorium on the project. Waters' House Financial Services Committee staff promoted the group's position in a briefing memo circulated to members before an Oct. 23 hearing with Zuckerberg. ''It's Big Tech trying to get into banking and the possibility of disintermediation of the whole banking system itself,' said Chris Cole, executive vice president at the community bankers group. 'It's not just small banks undermining Facebook's invention. The project initially had the support of Visa, MasterCard and other big payments industry players, but they backed out of joining the Switzerland-based association that will manage Libra as regulatory and political scrutiny reached a fever pitch. In the wake of the departures, JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon knocked Libra as 'a neat idea that will never happen.'' Yep, regulators and policymakers don't like Libra as it's a threat to national governance as represented by national banks who work closely with government, in the same way as Big Tech does in China. Neat. But, however much lobbying banks make of Washington's corridors, Facebook has a lot of capital to spend on winning the arguments and isn't finished yet. At Money 2020 last week David Marcus, the man who leads the Facebook currency initiative, took to the stage and highlighted that, when looking at history, 'the most meaningful innovations that have changed the lives of millions across the world in a profound way have always been met with damning headlines.' Using examples such as electricity, the Internet, mobile phones and smartphones, he believes that the Libra network has the potential to 'change the direction of the world' in the same way as these innovations. 'These headlines are a preamble to more hard times ahead and we must govern the network into a place where it will meet regulatory standards, then we will see the network come to life. People deserve much better than they have,' he asserts. Reporting on Finextra[4] provides more detail: Marcus disagrees with the fundamental notion that stablecoins pose a threat to national monetary policy. He explores how there would be a threat if Libra prevented the government from having a national monetary policy, which today is done with interest rates. In addition to this, he says that stablecoins would be a threat if the process involved money creation. 'With Libra, there is no money creation; we have a full one to one back reserve, there is no money creation whatsoever,' Marcus reiterates. Marcus says that in hindsight, he wishes Libra had spoken more about 'what we were actually building, which are new payments rails on the internet, the way it should be.' Libra is a payment network and it not a consumer facing product that people will use every day. 'We also designed Libra in such a way so that any wallet can participate as long as KYC and AML requirements are met. It was designed to be competitive, but we still need to earn people's trust over time to use Calibra.' Marcus clarifies that there is a 'data separation between Facebook and Libra' and data will not be used for ad targeting but will bring distribution. 'Moving money around the world with WhatsApp and Messenger is what will bring real value on a day to day basis.' Neat. Whatever happens, Libra has woken up the markets to new ideas and new opportunities and maybe even a digital dollar[5],which would be no bad thing. Let's see what happens in this space. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T03-4PM1-F021-63J0-00000-00Big banks vs big tech: Gary Cohn's comments about Facebook spark debate about lesser of two evils2018-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Big banks vs big tech: Gary Cohn's comments about Facebook spark debate about lesser of two evilsBy Chris Graham

Gary Cohn, the former Goldman Sachs President, reportedly believes banks were more responsible in 2008 before the financial crisis than social media companies are today. 

Facebook has served as a lightning rod for anger and mistrust towards social media firms ever since the revelations that 87 million users might have had their data shared with Cambridge Analytica .

Banks, meanwhile, are still struggling to regain public trust after helping instigate the financial crisis 10 years ago. Risky assets like subprime mortgages led to large losses and many crisis-stricken banks, including the Royal Bank of Scotland, had to be bailed out by governments.

Speaking at a benefit event at the weekend in New York for the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, the former economic adviser to Donald Trump referred to the other controversy plaguing Facebook: the spread of misinformation and fake news.

"It's very interesting how the world turns," Mr Cohn was quoted by Bloomberg as saying. "In '08 Facebook was one of those companies that was a big platform to criticise banks, they were very out front of criticising banks for not being responsible citizens. I think banks were more responsible citizens in '08 than some of the social media companies are today. And it affects everyone in the world. The banks have never had that much pull."

'Tone deaf, laughable'

Tech and finance experts winced at the comparison. 

Fergus Ryan, an analyst working with International Cyber Policy Centre, described his comments as "tone deaf, laughable and, of course, very convenient for him".

"As recently as December 2017, Cohn told the media that neither Wall Street nor the tech companies deserve the criticism they're taking right now.... But now it seems he's happy to let the big tech companies be the whipping boy.

"Neither the banks nor social media platforms deserve to be let off the hook for their actions. Comparing how irresponsible the banks were in the lead up to the global financial crisis with how irresponsible social media platforms are now is a bit like comparing an oil spill with a dumpster fire - albeit a very, very, big dumpster fire."

RBS timeline - back from the brink

Richard Holden, a leading economist at UNSW Business School, said "it was a bit rich" from Mr Cohn, but he played down the impact that Facebook has had compared to the big banks, which "nearly caused the great depression". 

"If I was being asked for  a horse race of whose bad behaviour has had the worse effect, I'd come down on the side of the banks and mortgage brokers." 

'The public hate the banks'

Mr Ryan said Facebook's "naivety" was partly to blame for their failings.

"Facebook executives were too rosy-eyed about the role of their platform as a source of good in the world. They were not clear-eyed about how malign actors could use it for bad ends," he said.

Professor Holden agreed that Facebook was more naive than the banks, who "knew they were selling stuff that was, if not worthless, were worth vastly less than what they were selling them for".

He said companies such as Facebook should learn from the anger caused by the banks, who have yet to regain the public's trust in the decade following the crisis. "Getting out in front of it is really important," he said. 

"The public just hate the banks, the public are willing to tolerate all kinds of punitive behaviour ... Facebook doesn't want to go there." 

Ten years on: the key players in the financial crisis - where are they now?

Some lawmakers in the US have suggested regulating social media, adding they hope the companies will become more transparent and proactive in countering foreign meddling.

For its part, Facebook appears to be making efforts in that area. Last week, it announced it had uncovered a covert campaign to use its platform to exacerbate US political divisions ahead of the mid term elections in November. 

Facebook said  the unknown actors behind the latest campaign "went to much greater lengths to obscure their true identities" than Russia-linked groups had in the run-up to the 2016 presidential election.

A lack of trust

But it is the issue of privacy that has particularly angered ordinary users, with the Cambridge Analytica scandal prompting a "delete Facebook" campaign .  

In March, a Reuters' survey found that most people in the US used Facebook throughout the day more than they used Twitter, Instagram, Pinterest, Tumblr, Snapchat, or Google+. But although people were more likely to be on Facebook, 51 percent either said they didn't trust the platform at all or didn't trust it very much.

Banks have also failed to regain the trust of US customers. In 2009, a Gallup poll found 49% of respondents had "some" confidence in the institutions, while 26% had "very little" confidence. Fast forward nine years, and those numbers have barely changed. 

'I'm really sorry': Zuckerberg's history of apologising

Unsurprisingly the news on Monday that Facebook was reportedly in talks to deepen links with banks and financial institutions to improve their customer service raised eyebrows. 

"I could not believe that. As if that would make them more trustworthy....", said David Kinley, who holds the Chair in Human Rights Law at the University of Sydney.

Professor Kinley, author of "Necessary Evil: How to Fix Finance by Saving Human Rights", said there were some big similarities between the two industries.

"Banks and financiers are now huge IT employers .... They also do mess with our privacy.

"There is no doubt that the details that are held by banks are used in a way that will benefit them and indeed their clients to whom they choose to share the details, and of course that's the same as the social media platforms."

Banks 'have been screwing with out privacy'

However, there is one big difference. 

"[The banks] have the temptation, and have yielded to the temptation, of screwing with our details, with our privacy. The banks have not only screwed with our details but they've financially benefited from that at our expense.

"They've been using what details they have on us to enrich themselves whereas I think the social media have done less to thieve financially from us. What they have done is broken the trust by selling them on."

How to take back your privacy on Facebook

Janna Thompson, Professor of Philosophy at La Trobe University, has written extensively on corporate ethics.

And when it comes to choosing between the lesser of two evils, she has slightly more sympathy for the social media firms, whom she likens to "Frankenstein and his monster".

"[The banks] were engaged in an unbridled quest for profit and did not care if they did it by engaging in dodgy behaviour. They should have known that things would end badly for a lot of innocent people.

"In 2008 when Facebook was criticising the banks I don't think Zuckerberg and others knew, or could have known, how some people would later use this platform.

"The relationship between them and their creation is rather like the relationship between Frankenstein and his monster. I don't think they really know how to control it. I am not saying that they are blameless. Just that the banks are more blameworthy for the GFC (great financial crisis) than they are for what happened (on social media) during the US election, etc."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:59N4-14F1-JB6S-F2KF-00000-00Big Board to test systems ahead of Twitter IPO2013-10-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBig Board to test systems ahead of Twitter IPOJim Kim

It would be easy to overstate the importance of NYSE's big victory in the Twitter sweepstakes. It was big news when the social media giant decided to list on the Big Board, shunning the Nasdaq, the traditional home of big tech stocks. Of course, the NYSE has been pursuing technology companies for years with notable successes, even in social media. LinkedIn chose the NYSE not too long ago.

Still, anytime a tech company with as much brand awareness as Twitter bucks the Nasdaq, it's a big moment, one that the Big Board can ill afford to botch. If it can pull off a successful IPO, it truly will have stuck one to its great rival.

Taking no chances, the Big Board has announced it will allow brokerage firms to test their systems ahead of the deal date. Trading systems testing with a mock opening auction of Twitter's stock has been scheduled for Saturday, Oct. 26. The deal will actually be priced sometime in November.

According to media reports, such systems testing over a weekend is not unusual. What is unusual is a test around a specific deal.

The point of course is to avoid the technical problems that plagued the debut of Facebook, a botched deal that ultimately landed Nasdaq OMX in regulatory hot water. It agreed to pay $10 million to settle enforcement actions in the wake of the deal.

The Twitter deal is less likely to pose technical issues, as it is a much smaller deal. That said, it pays to be careful.

For more:
- see this The Verge item

urn:contentItem:5W3W-RGM1-JCF2-8038-00000-00Big brother in big tech;Tech companies have made user privacy and security a focus with heightened consumer awareness and scrutiny from the authorities2019-05-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisLIFEBig brother in big techTech companies have made user privacy and security a focus with heightened consumer awareness and scrutiny from the authoritiesChong Koh Ping

The hottest trend in tech is not tech. It is privacy.

In the past two weeks, the chief executives of Google and Facebook - two tech companies that frequently track our digital habits - have made protecting user data the central theme in their conference speeches.

But experts believe there is more that tech firms can do. Similarly, consumers want an easier way to monitor if the tech firms are actually walking the talk.

At Google's annual gathering of software developers in the United States last week, its chief executive Sundar Pichai said: "We strongly believe that privacy and security are for everyone, not just a few."

At the event, called Google I/O, the company said its new mobile operating system Android Q and existing products such as YouTube and Google Maps will have new privacy features so users can be in control of their data. The bulk of such data will also remain in the users' devices rather than being collected and stored in the cloud at the firm's end.

At Facebook's annual F8 developer conference two weeks ago in the US, company chief executive Mark Zuckerberg declared that "the future is private".

He vowed to do more, including extending popular messaging app WhatsApp's end-to-end encryption to other Facebook-owned private messaging platforms Messenger and Instagram Direct.

This spotlight on privacy and security comes as big tech firms suffer public backlash over how they handle users' personal information.

In January, Google was fined (EURO)50 million (S$76.7 million) in France for breaching European Union online privacy rules. The French regulator said Google lacked transparency and clarity in how it informs users about its handling of personal data and failed to properly obtain their consent for personalised ads.

Facebook went under intense fire after it reported, early last year, sharing the private information of as many as 87 million users with political consultancy firm Cambridge Analytica. The third-party firm had used users' personal data to design advertising and content to influence their votes during the 2016 United States presidential election.

Experts say tighter regulatory scrutiny and heightened consumer awareness are two key drivers in protecting user privacy among big tech firms.

For instance, the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which came into force in May last year, is the biggest shake-up of data privacy laws in more than two decades. It allows users to better control their personal data and gives regulators the power to impose fines of up to 4 per cent of global revenue for violations.

The impact of the GDPR extends beyond Europe, said Ms Charmian Aw, a lawyer who specialises in information technology, privacy and data security at Reed Smith in alliance with Resource Law.

She noted that countries in the region, such as India and Thailand, are looking to adopt in their laws features that are similar to those in the GDPR. Singapore, too, has considered the GDPR to see what can be ported over to its existing law, she said.

In addition, consumers are getting more aware of issues related to data sharing and cybersecurity with the proliferation of digitalisation and all things tech, including topics such as artificial intelligence and blockchain.

"Media coverage on privacy topics is also becoming more and more prevalent," she added.

But critics have pointed out that some of the changes pledged by the tech firms are not enough to address the central issue of privacy related to data sharing.

NUS computer science professors Liang Zhenkai, Xiao Xiaokui and Reza Shokri said what is needed is a fundamental change in how user data is collected, shared and used.

"To better safeguard user privacy, it is important that user data should be carefully sanitised before leaving their devices," they said in an e-mail response.

So far, only Google and Apple have applied an advanced privacy preservation mechanism, and only some of their data collection processes.

"Not all data collected by all vendors are protected by such a mechanism," they added.

Mr Claus Mortensen, principal analyst of Ecosystm, a technology research and advisory firm, pointed out that Facebook had talked only about the encryption of its private messaging services - Messenger and Instagram Direct. It had skirted the central issue of data sharing.

"Facebook's chequered history with regard to privacy has been its liberal use and sharing of user data... on the main Facebook platform.

"It is this data that was shared with Cambridge Analytica, with leading handset manufacturers and a number of other Internet companies without the users' knowledge or explicit consent," he said.

He did not think Facebook would walk the talk and put new privacy safeguards into effect until it comes up with a clear business strategy to wean itself off data sharing as the main revenue-generating tool.

But he said that Google, on the other hand, has taken some real steps that would help protect user privacy, including stopping the scanning of Gmail users' e-mails for ad targeting and rolling out an auto-delete feature that erases Web and app activity after three or 18 months.

Ms Aw said such actions lean towards a privacy by design approach, which is to embed user privacy in product or service features. This is what tech firms need to do on top of the usual consent clauses that they present to users.

"Ultimately, the burden lies on these tech firms to demonstrate that they are accountable and compliant with the law," she added.

Consumers tell The Straits Times they welcome such moves by tech giants to protect their data, but it is hard for them to know if these firms are actually walking the talk.

"They tell you they are implementing new rules, but there is no oversight. How do you know what actually flows out of your computer'" said Mr Dennis Chu, 38, a business development manager at an engineering firm.

Dr Kua Shin Yii, 41, a doctor in private practice, thinks these new privacy measures are a step in the right direction, but much of her data could have been collected anyway prior to these new pledges.

"I feel Google and Facebook are feeding me information based on what I surf. And we don't know how much data has been collected already," she said.

Indeed, Mr Mortensen thinks this hints at the motivation behind these two tech giants' current initiatives.

"Google probably hasn't stopped scanning Gmail users' messages because they really want to provide them with greater levels of privacy - they have stopped because they don't need to anymore.

"They now have the capability to target ads effectively without the need for scanning the content of e-mails," he noted.

"Similarly, they don't need to know a user's app and Web history for the last several years - more current behaviour is enough and often more relevant for ad targeting."

As for Facebook, it is simply not ready to cut off access yet.

"They still haven't worked out how to target and contextualise ad content without giving (advertisers) access to extensive user data. Once they figure it out, we will probably see very public announcements from Facebook about it," Mr Mortensen added.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y9V-J651-JBFW-C13D-00000-00Big Brother needs a bigger brother2020-02-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisEDITORIAL COPYPg. A17Every ZoneBig Brother needs a bigger brother

Hank Stuever contended in his Feb. 18 Style article, "Unpacking the worries about Amazon," that the recent PBS "Frontline" episode on the "Amazon Empire" lacked "a wider reflection on the consumer's complicity in" Amazon's somewhat Orwellian presence. It's true that "no one forced us to hand over all our personal data and install Amazon's listening devices or surveillance cameras in our homes." However, equating Amazon's technological capabilities with the party's surveillance state in George Orwell's famous dystopia draws a false equivalence that serves to further shift the accountability from the party responsible - Congress - to corporations and U.S. citizens.

Furthermore, our government - not companies - is more cause for concern regarding a surveillance state with programs such as PRISM. Congress is the body that can and should do something definitive about regulating Big Tech. It has for years discussed privacy concerns and potential antitrust violations but passed little legislation.

Stuever noted that "Amazon is in sore need of some corrective regulation." The best path forward will be regulation to protect individual liberties of Americans while not stifling innovation. Splitting up Amazon and other Big Tech companies would not only pose a legislative nightmare but also be grossly incompatible with continued innovation. (Jeff Bezos, the owner of The Post, is founder and chief executive of Amazon.) Congress needs to find a middle ground and act before it's too late.

Arnav Bansal , Fairfax

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60C8-4P01-JBK9-240K-00000-00Big Brothers Are Watching You2020-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisFocusPg. 4Big Brothers Are Watching YouGabriel Knupfer

Facial recognition In times of Corona, states and companies are expanding the use of the technology. This also increases the danger of abuse.

GABRIEL KNUPFER

Those who often take pictures with the iPhone have been able to follow the rapid development of automatic face recognition. While a few years ago, the assignment of people in the photo collection on the device was almost done on a whim, glasses, make-up and haircuts have long since ceased to be a problem for identification. The smartphone also reliably recognizes its owner and their family members - so reliably that you can unlock the screen with your face.

Behind this is a technological achievement, with many other applications. In law enforcement, computers already match images of suspects with stored photos in a database, thus facilitating the work of the police. In the course of the current protests against racism and police violence in the USA, however, this has been strongly criticized. Due to public pressure, several tech companies terminated their cooperation with the American police authorities, at least temporarily. This is remarkable because it is a lucrative and promising business. During the pandemic there are also new opportunities for use.

The market research company Grand View Research estimated the global market for facial recognition software at $3.4 billion in 2019, with an expected annual growth rate of around 15 percent between 2020 and 2027. However, such figures are speculative and vary depending on the study's design and scope. On the other hand, it is undisputed that facial recognition is gaining in importance and is being used in more and more areas. But what is it all about and what are the problems? Five questions and answers on the controversial future technology.

1 How does the technology work?

Automatic facial recognition is a biometric method of identification and is therefore similar to a fingerprint scan. The software proceeds in three steps: First, a face is recognized as such. Second, this face is compared with a database and third, it is identified. The aim is to uniquely assign it to a name.

Originally, the positions of features such as eyes, nose and mouth were measured. Today, more complex calculations are behind them. Nevertheless, the technology is still more error-prone than other biometric methods. The hit rate depends on the facial expression, the illumination, the angle of the shot and the resolution of the image. This can be seen, for example, in the fact that for identity card photos you still have to have as neutral a facial expression as possible. More recent developments include 3D processes, which are supposed to enable greater accuracy, and programs that recognize and evaluate feelings.

The fact that face recognition is contactless has advantages. The risk of infection - for example with the corona virus - is reduced and in the security area, cooperation of the target person is unnecessary. But exactly this also raises questions regarding privacy and data protection.

2 What are the applications?

Face recognition is used in many areas - and new possibilities are constantly being added. The future of the technology is particularly interesting, says Christian Fehrlin, who offers facial recognition software through Deep Impact in Winterthur. "Starting with the biometric boarding pass, through entrance controls and surveillance, to hotel check-in, we see enormous potential," says the entrepreneur. Then there are payment solutions and ticketing in the event area. The forecast of the study mentioned at the beginning is therefore "very conservative ", Fehrlin believes.

In China, where the technology is already much more widespread than in the West, you can already shop with your face, withdraw money and check in at the airport. In schools, the presence and even the attention of students is monitored. And if you go to the zoo or museum, you have to have your face scanned as well. For access control in offices, facial recognition replaces secret codes and fingerprint scanners; at national borders it complements older biometric methods.

The technology is also being used against Covid-19. In Russia, facial-recognition cameras monitor whether people comply with the quarantine - and in China they identify people who have a fever. This works in both countries, even if people wear a protective mask.

In a test, the police in the Canadian capital Ottawa reduced the average time to identify a suspect using a picture from thirty days to three minutes, according to the Economist. Instead of manually comparing the image with the 50,000 police photos stored in the system or sending it to various branches and asking for information, a quick search on the computer was sufficient. The Chinese police are casting the net even further, searching for suspects using surveillance cameras and data glasses in combination with face recognition.

Another application is the search for missing persons. When Amazon announced a one-year moratorium on the use of its face recognition system by the police authorities, it explicitly excluded the search for victims of human trafficking and missing children. In 2018, Delhi police found nearly 3,000 missing children in just four days by using such software.

3 Which companies and countries are involved?

The big tech companies are involved as well as start-ups and armament companies. A study by the Carnegie Foundation for International Peace examined the largest suppliers of smart surveillance technology in 2019. According to the study, the Chinese companies Huawei, Hikvision, Dahua and ZTE are the leaders. Japan's NEC is the first non-Chinese company to follow suit, having reportedly installed over a thousand larger face recognition systems in more than seventy countries and regions.

The US tech giants are also among the big players in the industry, even if not all of them deliver to the surveillance sector. Google, for example, does not offer the technology for sale. IBM ended its cooperation with the security authorities in the wake of the Black Lives Matter protests. Microsoft and Amazon followed suit and temporarily suspended their deliveries (see point 4).

Apart from numerous companies that need facial recognition for their products, services or locations, states purchase such systems for surveillance or crime prevention. Liberal democracies are leading users of surveillance technology such as facial recognition cameras, writes the Carnegie Foundation. More than half of these countries use them, "but that doesn't necessarily mean that democracies abuse these systems."

4 What is criticized?

Almost as long as the list of applications is the list of criticisms. IBM technology must no longer be used for mass surveillance, racial profiling or the violation of basic human rights and freedoms, wrote CEO Arvind Krishna to the US Congress. "Vendors and users of AI systems have a responsibility to check AI for bias, especially when used in law enforcement." The problem is that technology is less reliable at recognizing black people's faces than white people's. Moreover, the fact that more black people are listed in police databases further increases the risk of members of this population group being falsely identified. This is why the city of San Francisco banned the use of facial recognition by the police even before the current wave of protests.

The way companies and government agencies create their databases is also problematic. The US start-up Clearview collected three billion portrait photos from the Internet by scanning websites and social networks like Facebook. Among the users were numerous US authorities and companies, official bodies in Europe - including Switzerland - and organizations in totalitarian states such as Saudi Arabia, reported "Buzz Feed News" in February. The US civil rights organization Aclu sued Clearview for illegal data collection and accused the company of "destroying privacy ".

On top of all this, there is a danger that government agencies or criminals could misuse facial recognition. Dictatorships use it to pursue their opponents or control the population to an unprecedented extent (see box). There are also opportunities for hackers, although the technology has so far been considered relatively secure in this respect. However, if ever larger amounts of personal data are stored, the risk of identity theft naturally increases. Experts from the Chinese company Tencent, for example, have shown that systems such as Apple's Face ID can be deceived, even though the method is still virtually impossible to use in practice.

5 What happens next?

In the USA, face recognition is currently in a difficult state. But for the technology as a whole this is only a minor setback. First, its use by the police is only one of many applications. And secondly, there is no common line in the industry - even in this area. There are enough companies that can fill the gap that IBM and Co. would leave behind.

Future use in law enforcement will have to be regulated politically and legally in the different countries. In commercial use, however, the genie is probably already out of the bottle. "It will prevail because the convenience is very high," says Fehrlin.

In the end, consumers will decide for which purposes they will make their face available.

Digital surveillance in China

Control While the pros and cons of automatic face recognition are still being discussed in North America and Europe, the use of the technology is already widespread in China and is being continuously expanded. According to IHS Markit, about half of the 770 million surveillance cameras worldwide are installed in China. Combined with facial recognition software, this enables the authorities to exercise unprecedented control over the country's 1.4 billion inhabitants. Meanwhile, a genuine public debate on data protection and surveillance is preventing censorship in China.

Uyghurs Since December 2019, mobile phone users have had to undergo a face scan when they register a new SIM card. This allows the state to create a database of the faces of its inhabitants. Critics fear that this will bring the whole of China into line with the autonomous region of Xinjiang, where people in public places have been under constant surveillance for some time. This surveillance has been accompanied by the arrest of hundreds of thousands to millions of Muslim Uyghurs who are being held in re-education camps because of their religion.

Pillory Everywhere in the country, police are upgrading with data glasses with which suspects can be identified in real time. The software is so advanced that it can recognize and evaluate emotions. Facial recognition is not only used against alleged separatism and extremism: in some cities, people who had crossed the street at red lights were identified and pilloried on huge screens. "Face recognition protects human rights," according to the Global Times, the government's international mouthpiece.

Social credit The expansion of automatic face recognition is part of a larger campaign under ruler Xi Jinping to strengthen social stability in the party's interests. Based on surveillance, artificial intelligence and Big Data, the Communist Party wants to secure its power in the long term. This includes the social credit system, which classifies the population by awarding and withdrawing points for their behavior and rewards or punishes them depending on their score. Those with a low score must expect restrictions in everyday life.

Document original

urn:contentItem:5VG8-W241-F10T-01SG-00000-00Big Brother vs Big Tech2019-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:21:08ZLexisNexisBig Brother vs Big TechDavid Manners

The appetite of the tech giants for peoples’ personal data seems unquenchable. Now it turns out that Google put a microphone into its home alarm system  “The on-device microphone was never intended to be a secret and should have been listed in the tech specs. That was an error on our part,” says an apparently ...

The appetite of the tech giants for peoples’ personal data seems unquenchable.

Now it turns out that Google put a microphone into its home alarm system

 “The on-device microphone was never intended to be a secret and should have been listed in the tech specs. That was an error on our part,” says an apparently contrite Google.

I don’t for a moment think Google is contrite – these guys think they have a right to collect data on us – Facebook feels it can collect and store data on any of its subscribers from any source it likes.

But, despite that, and despite all the negative publicity about Facebook, its subscriber numbers and revenues continue to grow.

It would seem that people don’t care that Facebook et al hoover up data on them. Maybe people are flattered that the techies take such an interest in them.

This gives the politicians a dilemma. The pols are gagging to regulate the tech giants. They want to corral them, tax them and fine them. 

But what if the people, who the pols represent, don’t care if the techies are unregulated, untaxed and unfined?

There’s the dilemma. The trouble is we love our techies and the only ultimate sanction the pols have against the techies is to restrict or close their activities.

 And the pols know that if they restrict or prevent us from buying from Amazon, searching with Google and flocking with Facebook  they’ll come to a sticky end at the polling booths.

Roll up for the next bout: Big Brother vs Big Tech

This story continues at Big Brother vs Big Tech

Or just read more coverage at Electronics Weekly
